1.  Receive requests submitted to the public body; 
2.  Ensure that the public body responds to requests under the time constraints set forth in this chapter; and 
3.  Issue responses to requests. 
B.  Freedom of information officers shall develop a list of documents or categories of public records that the public body shall immediately disclose on request. Resolution No. 2009-75 adopted December 21, 2009 set forth the names of the freedom of information officers. 
C.  The duties of the freedom of information officer upon receiving a request for public records are as follows: 
1.  Note the date the public body receives the written request; 
2.  Compute the day on which the period for response will expire and make a notation of that date on the written request; 
3.  Maintain an electronic or paper copy of a written request, including all documents submitted with the request until the request has been complied with or denied; and 
4.  Create a file for the retention of the original request, a copy of the response, a record of written communication with the requester, and a copy of other communications. 
D.  All newly appointed freedom of information officers shall initially complete an electronic training curriculum administered by the Illinois Attorney General's public access counselor and thereafter successfully complete an annual training program. 
(Ord. No. 2008-53, § 1, 12-15-2008; Ord. No. 2010-02, § 1, 1-19-2010) 
TITLE 2 - PUBLIC SAFETY DEPARTMENTS 
Subject       Chapter 
  
Police Department 1 
Fire Department 2 
CHAPTER 1 - POLICE DEPARTMENT 
SECTION: 

2-1-1: - DEPARTMENT CREATED; COMPOSITION: 
There is hereby created a police department, which shall be an executive department of the city. The police department shall consist of the chief of police, two (2) commanders, seven (7) sergeants, twenty seven (27) patrol officers, and such other members as may be provided from time to time by the city council. 
(Ord. 2006-49, 9-5-2006) 
2-1-2: - CHIEF OF POLICE: 
A.  Office Created: There is hereby created the office of the chief of police. The chief of police shall be appointed by the mayor, with the consent and approval of the city council. 
(1975 Code § 20-35) 
B.  Duties: The chief of police shall be the keeper of the city jail and shall have custody of all persons incarcerated therein. The chief shall keep such records and make such reports concerning the activities of his department as may be required by statute or by the city council. The chief shall be responsible for the performance of the police department in all of its functions, and all persons who are members of the department shall serve subject to the orders of the chief of police. 
(1975 Code § 20-36) 
2-1-3: - APPOINTMENTS AND PROMOTIONS; REQUIREMENTS: 
All appointments to and promotions within the police department, excluding auxiliary (reserve) police officers and the chief of police, shall be made by the board of fire and police commissioners [1] as provided by statute. 
(1975 Code § 20-37) 
A.  Residency Requirements: All police officers appointed by the board of fire and police commissioners, or its successor, shall reside, as their principal place of residence, within twenty (20) miles of the corporate limits of the city (as measured by straight line distances), from and after any applicable probationary period designated by the board of fire and police commissioners. 
(1975 Code § 20-37.1) 
B.  Participation In Illinois Police Training Act: [2] 
1.  The city does hereby elect to participate in the program provided for in the Illinois police training act. 
2.  Before an individual may commence regular employment as a police officer in the city, he must have been certified by the Illinois local governmental law enforcement officers training board as having successfully completed an approved training course, as provided in said act. 
3.  The basic training must be completed by the trainee within his probationary period of six (6) months. 
4.  The board of fire and police commissioners is hereby instructed and directed to make the necessary amendments, so that any person appointed to the police department of the city shall not become a regular member of the police department until and unless that person has completed the approved training course within six (6) months of the date of his initial employment, all pursuant to the Illinois police training act. 
(1975 Code § 20-40) 
C.  Discharge: No police officer, excluding probationary police officers and the chief of police, shall be discharged from the department until after a hearing before the board of fire and police commissioners as provided by law. 
(1975 Code § 20-39) 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
See title 3, chapter 4 of this code. 

--- (2) --- 
50 ILCS 705/1 et seq. 

2-1-4: - DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: 
It shall be the duty of the members of the police department to the enforce all ordinances of the city and all applicable statutes applicable herein; to preserve order; prevent infractions of the law and arrest violators thereof; to obey all lawful orders and to conform with all rules and regulations, general and special orders, policies and procedures and directives of the department as promulgated by the chief of police. 
(1975 Code § 20-38) 
2-1-5: - POLICE PENSION FUND:[3] 
A.  Board Created: There shall be a police pension board consisting of five (5) members. Of these members, two (2) shall be appointed by the mayor; two (2) shall be elected from the regular police force of the city; and one shall be elected from the beneficiaries of the pension. Each member shall serve for two (2) years and elected members shall be selected in the manner provided by law. 
(1975 Code § 20-52) 
B.  Duties: It shall be the duty of the members of the police pension board to manage, invest and control the police pension fund and all monies pertaining thereto in the manner provided by statute and to pay beneficiaries as provided by law. 
(1975 Code § 20-53) 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
40 ILCS 5/3-128. 

CHAPTER 2 - FIRE DEPARTMENT 
SECTION: 

2-2-1: - DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED; COMPOSITION: 
There is hereby created and established a fire department for the city. The fire department shall consist of the fire chief, full time and paid on call firefighters with the following composition of personnel: 
Full time Fire chief Deputy chiefs (2) Lieutenants (6) Firefighters (11) Paid on call Lieutenants (4) Firefighters (40)  
(Ord. 2005-02, 1-18-2005) 
2-2-2: - FIRE CHIEF: 
A.  Office Created: There is hereby created the office of the fire chief of the city. The fire chief shall be appointed by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council. 
(1975 Code § 14-14) 
B.  Supervision Over Department; Equipment: The fire chief shall have the control, subject to the order and direction of the city council, of the fire department and all fire apparatus belonging to the city. Whenever any fire apparatus needs repairing, the fire chief shall cause the same to be done without delay. During the temporary absence or disability of the fire chief, the deputy chiefs shall perform all duties of the fire chief. 
(1975 Code § 14-17) 
2-2-3: - APPOINTMENTS AND PROMOTIONS; REQUIREMENTS: 
A.  Appointments And Promotions: 
1.  Full Time Members: Appointments and promotions of all full time members of the fire department shall be made by the board of fire and police commissioners [4] in accordance with the procedures established by applicable statutory provisions. 
2.  Paid On Call Members: All appointments of paid on call members of the fire department shall be made upon the recommendation of the fire chief and approved by the city council. 
(1975 Code § 14-15) 
B.  Residency Requirements: All firefighters appointed by the board of fire and police commissioners or its successor shall reside, as their principal place of residence, within twelve (12) miles of the corporate limits of the city (as measured by straight line distance) from and after any applicable probationary period designated by the board of fire and police commissioners of the city. 
(Ord. 2003-02, 1-21-2003) 
C.  Fire Protection Training: 
1.  The city hereby elects to participate in the training programs provided for in the Illinois fire protection and training act. [5] 
2.  Before an individual may commence regular full time employment as a firefighter, said individual must have been certified by the Illinois state fire marshal as a firefighter II, as having successfully completed a course approved by the office of the state fire marshal. 
3.  Except for the paid on call personnel, the firefighter II training must be completed by the trainee within the individual's probationary period of one calendar year from the initial date of probationary appointment. 
4.  The board of fire and police commissioners is hereby authorized to make any necessary amendments to the personnel rules, the manual of rules and regulations of the Geneva fire department, and the rules of said board of fire and police commissioners in order to require that any person appointed to the city fire department, shall not become a regular member of the fire department unless and until he shall complete, pursuant to said Illinois fire protection and training act, the approved course within one calendar year of said person's date of probationary appointment. 
(1975 Code § 14-15.2) 
D.  Discharges: No full time officer or member of the fire department shall be removed or discharged except for cause, upon written charges, and after an opportunity to be heard in his own defense before the board of fire and police commissioners, as provided by law. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to prevent the chief of the fire department from suspending, without pay, a full time member of his department for a period of not more than five (5) days, but he shall notify the board of fire and police commissioners in writing of such suspension. Any firefighter so suspended may appeal to the board of fire and police commissioners for a review of the suspension within twenty four (24) hours after such suspension, and upon such appeal, the board of fire and police commissioners may sustain the action of the chief of the fire department, may reverse it with instructions that the firefighter receive his pay for the period involved, or may suspend the officer for an additional period of not more than thirty (30) days, or discharge him, depending upon the facts presented. 
No paid on call firefighter may be discharged from the department, except for cause, and after an opportunity to be heard in his own defense before a hearing before the fire chief and a committee of officers and firefighters of the department and after the findings of said fire chief and committee have been approved by the city council; provided however, nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent the fire chief from suspending, without pay, a paid on call firefighter for a period of not more than thirty (30) days for reasons of insubordination, other violation of departmental rules and/or practices. 
(1975 Code § 14-16) 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
See title 3, chapter 4 of this code. 

--- (5) --- 
50 ILCS 740/1 et seq. 

2-2-4: - MEMBERSHIP; ORGANIZATION AND RECORDS: 
A.  Organization: The fire department may have any organization approved by the mayor and city council, and may hold meetings and engage in social activities with the approval of the mayor and city council. The secretary of the fire department, if any is elected or appointed, shall keep a record of all meetings and shall make a report to the mayor and city council of all meetings and all activities of the fire department. No officer shall be elected or appointed within the organization of the fire department without the approval of the mayor and city council. 
(1975 Code § 14-19) 
B.  Records: The fire chief, or in his absence a deputy chief, shall keep or cause to be kept a record of all meetings of the department and the attendance of the members, a record of all fires, and during the last week in April of each year, shall file with the city clerk a full report of such records and attendance and fires, which report shall be under oath. 
(1975 Code § 14-20) 
2-2-5: - DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: 
A.  General: It shall be the function and duty of the fire department and every member thereof to extinguish accidental or destructive fires and prevent the occurrence or spread of such fires. 
(1975 Code § 14-21) 
B.  Enforcement Of Provisions: It shall be the duty of all officers of the fire department and all police officers of the city to see that the provisions of the fire prevention regulations of this code [6] are enforced and to arrest on view any person who shall be found violating any such provisions of this code or who shall hinder, resist or refuse to obey any such officer in the discharge of his duty, and to that end all such officers are hereby vested with the usual power and authority of police officers. 
(1975 Code § 14-22) 
C.  Command At Fires: In case of fire, the fire chief and the deputy chiefs and their assistants shall rank in the order named and the officer of the highest rank at the fire shall take command of the fire department and direct the management thereof for the suppression of the fire in the best manner possible. When it may be necessary for the protection of other property and to prevent the spread of the conflagration, the officer in command may cause buildings to be removed, torn down or destroyed in the best manner possible. 
(1975 Code § 14-18) 
D.  Unauthorized Use Of Apparatus: Whoever shall use any fire engine, hose, truck or any other apparatus belonging to the city for any private purpose, other than the extinguishment of fires, or whoever shall remove the same or any part thereof from its place of deposit, or having control thereof, shall permit such engine, hose, truck or other apparatus to be used for any private purpose other than aforesaid, shall be deemed guilty for an offense. 
(1975 Code § 14-23) 
E.  Unauthorized Entering Of Fire Stations: It shall be unlawful for any person to enter the fire department station or any place where the equipment and apparatus of the fire department is stored at any time, except on business pertaining to the fire department or other city business. 
(1975 Code § 14-24) 
F.  Service Outside Corporate Limits: Members of the fire department are authorized to go outside the corporate limits of the city for the purpose of rendering aid to other fire departments, or of extinguishing fires and rendering aid in the case of accidents; provided, that the fire department shall not render such services outside the corporate limits except upon order of the chief of the fire department, a deputy chief or the mayor and city council, except where the city has undertaken by contract to render service to property outside the corporate limits, the fire department may leave the corporate limits in the fulfillment of such contract. 
(1975 Code § 14-25) 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
See title 10, chapter 4 of this code. 

2-2-6: - FIREFIGHTER'S PENSION FUND:[7] 
A.  Fund Established: There is hereby established a firefighter's pension fund in and for the city, as provided by state law consisting of such tax accumulations, assessments and deductions as are provided by state statutes. 
(1975 Code § 14-37) 
B.  Board Of Trustees: There is hereby created a board of trustees for the firefighter's pension fund. The board of trustees shall consist of those persons as provided by state law, and the terms of office of the members, the election of the trustees and the powers, duties and obligations conferred upon them shall be as prescribed by applicable state law. 
(1975 Code §§ 14-38, 14-39, 14-40)
