Premise refers to the geographic location where alcohol is permitted to be consumed or sold as depicted and approved on a drawing or diagram which is submitted at the time of application for a liquor license. PRIVATE FUNCTION: A prearranged private party, function, or event for a specific social or business occasion, either by invitation or reservation and not open to the general public, where the guests in attendance are served in a room or rooms designated and used exclusively for the private party, function, or event. PUBLIC ACCOMMODATION: A refreshment, entertainment, or recreation facility of any kind, whether licensed or not, whose goods, services, facilities, privileges, or advantages are extended, offered, sold, or otherwise made available to the public. RESORT HOTEL OR RESORT MOTEL: A hotel or motel, as described above, which provides amenities such as golfing and swimming. RESTAURANT: Any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place where meals are served, and where meals are regularly served, without sleeping accommodations, such space being provided with adequate sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and capacity and having employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employees to prepare, cook and serve suitable food for its guests. The intent of this definition is that the primary business conducted on the premises to be licensed as a restaurant shall be the service of meals. RESTAURANT AND TAVERN: Any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place where meals are served, and where meals are regularly served, without sleeping accommodations, such space being provided with adequate sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and capacity and having employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employees to prepare, cook and serve suitable food for its guests. The intent of this definition is that the primary business conducted on the premises to be licensed as a restaurant and tavern shall be the service of meals. SALE: Any transfer, exchange or barter in any manner, or by any means whatsoever, including all sales made by any person, whether principal, proprietor, agent, servant or employee. SELL AT RETAIL (RETAIL SALES) AND SALE AT RETAIL: Sales for use or consumption and not for resale in any form. "To sell" includes to keep or expose for sale and to keep with intent to sell. SERVICE BAR: A permanent or portable bar which contains alcoholic liquor, mixes and related paraphernalia that may be used in the preparation of alcoholic drinks but does not and shall not have seats or stools or other places for persons to sit or stand while drinking alcoholic beverages. A service bar is a restricted bar solely to be used for the preparation and disbursement of drinks at the food service table or other locations away from the bar. Waitpersons may pick up alcoholic beverages for delivery to food service tables or other locations away from the bar. Patrons shall not be served from a service bar. A service bar may be located indoors or outdoors but shall be upon the licensed premises. SPECIAL EVENT (as it pertains to liquor licenses): An event conducted by an educational, fraternal, political, civic, religious or non-profit organization. SPIRITS: Any beverage which contains alcohol obtained by distillation, mixed with water or other substance in solution, and includes brandy, rum, whiskey, gin, or other spirituous liquors, and such liquors when rectified, blended or otherwise mixed with alcohol or other substances. TAVERN, BAR OR SALOON: Any public place that engages in the retail sale of alcoholic liquors for consumption on the premises with or without food service. TEMPORARY FENCING: Plastic construction fence, snow fencing, or other materials or styles as approved by the city (temporary fencing is allowed for special events only). TO SELL: To keep or expose for sale and to keep with intent to sell. WINE: Any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of the natural contents of fruits, or vegetables, containing sugar, including such beverages when fortified by the addition of alcohol or spirits; provided that the alcohol content thereof does not exceed twenty-four percent (24%) of the alcohol by volume. WINE TASTING: A supervised presentation of wine, in accordance with the rules and regulations of the Illinois State Liquor Commission to the public for the purpose of disseminating product information and education, with consumption of alcoholic products being an incidental part thereof.(Ord. No. 2011-40, § 1(Exh. A), 9-6-2011; Ord. No. 2013-26, § 1, 8-5-2013; Ord. No. 2013-33, § 1, 10-7-2013; Ord. No. 2015-09, § 1, 6-15-2015; Ord. No. 2015-30, § 1, 9-21-2015; Ord. No. 2017-21, § 1, 9-5-2017)  
4-2-2: - LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER-DESIGNATED: 
The mayor of the city is authorized to be the local liquor control commissioner and shall be charged with the administration of the Liquor Control Act, and of such ordinances, resolutions and rules relating to alcoholic liquor as may be enacted. 
The mayor may appoint a person to assist him in the exercise of the powers and the performance of the duties provided for such local liquor control commissioner. 
(Ord. No. 2011-40, § 1(Exh. A), 9-6-2011) 
4-2-3: - LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER-POWERS, DUTIES AND FUNCTIONS: 
The local liquor control commissioner shall have the following powers, duties and functions with respect to local liquor licenses: 
A.  To grant and/or suspend for not more than thirty (30) days or revoke for cause, all local liquor licenses issued to persons or entities for premises within the city, and to impose fines as authorized in this chapter; 
B.  To enter or to authorize any law enforcing officer to enter, at any time, upon any premises licensed hereunder, to determine whether any of the provisions of the Liquor Control Act or city ordinance or any rules or regulations adopted by the city or by the state liquor control commission have been or are being violated, and at such time to examine the premises of the licensee in connection therewith. Any person or persons appointed by the local liquor control commissioner shall have the powers given to the local liquor control commissioner by this subsection; 
C.  To receive complaints from any citizen within the city that any provision of the Liquor Control Act or of this chapter have been or are being violated and to act upon such complaints in the manner provided by law; 
D.  To receive local liquor license fees and pay same to the city. The local liquor control commissioner also has the duty to notify the secretary of state of any convictions or dispositions of court supervision for violation of Section 6-20 of the Liquor Control Act; 
E.  To examine or cause to be examined, under oath, any applicant for a local liquor license or for a renewal thereof, or any licensee upon whom notice of revocation, suspension or fine has been served, or any licensee against whom a citation proceeding has been instituted by the state liquor control commission; to examine or cause to be examined, the books and records of any such applicant or licensee; and to hear testimony and take evidence for his information in the performance of his duties, and for such purposes to issue subpoenas which shall be effective in any part of this state. For the purposes of obtaining any information desired by the local liquor control commissioner, he may authorize his agent to act on his behalf; 
F.  To notify the Secretary of State of Illinois where a club incorporated under the General Not for Profit Corporation Act of 1986 (805 ILCS 105/101.01 et seq., as amended) or a foreign corporation functioning as a club in this state under a certificate of authority issued under that Act has violated this chapter by selling or offering for sale at retail alcoholic liquors without a local liquor license pursuant to this chapter; 
G.  To require fingerprints of any applicant for a local license or for a renewal thereof (235 ILCS 5/4-7). 
(Ord. No. 2011-40, § 1(Exh. A), 9-6-2011) 
4-2-4: - LICENSE REQUIRED-TERM: 
Each local liquor license issued under this chapter shall terminate on April 30 following the date of issuance. 
(Ord. No. 2011-40, § 1(Exh. A), 9-6-2011) 
4-2-5: - LICENSE REQUIRED-RESTRICTIONS: 
It is unlawful to sell or offer for sale at retail in the city any alcoholic liquor (a) without a local retail liquor license ("local liquor license") and a state liquor license issued by the state liquor commission, or (b) be in violation of the terms of such license. The local liquor control commissioner shall keep, or cause to be kept, a complete record of all licenses issued by him under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2011-40, § 1(Exh. A), 9-6-2011) 
4-2-6: - NO ISSUANCE TO DEBTOR: 
No local liquor license shall be authorized for issuance and no initial local liquor license or renewal local liquor license shall be issued if the applicant, or any sole proprietor, partner, co-partner, member, officer, manager, director, or any stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%) of the stock thereof (either individually or in the foregoing capacities) is a debtor to the city for any reason whatsoever, regardless of whether the debt has been discharged such that the city can no longer collect such debt in any legal proceeding and regardless of whether such debt is owed by any of the foregoing: 
A.  Individually/personally; or 
B.  In the capacity as a sole proprietor, partner, co-partner, member, officer, manager, director, or any stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%) of the stock of any other legal entity, other than the applicant, that is a debtor to the city for any reason whatsoever, and regardless of whether the debt has been discharged such that the city can no longer collect such debt in any legal proceeding. 
(Ord. No. 2011-40, § 1(Exh. A), 9-6-2011) 
4-2-7: - DRAM SHOP INSURANCE REQUIRED PRIOR TO ISSUANCE: 
No local liquor license shall be granted to an applicant until such applicant shall furnish evidence satisfactory to the local liquor control commissioner that such applicant is covered by a policy of dram shop insurance issued by a responsible insurance company authorized and licensed to do business in the state insuring such applicant against liability which such applicant may incur under the provisions of 235 ILCS 5/6-21 and specifically designating the city as an additional insured. The evidence of the insurance policy shall indicate that the term of the insurance coverage is of sufficient length to encompass the period of the license sought. Notice of termination of said insurance must be provided to the city. 
(Ord. No. 2011-40, § 1(Exh. A), 9-6-2011) 
4-2-8: - APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS-APPLICATIONS FOR LICENSE: 
A.  Applications for a local liquor license shall be made to the local liquor control commissioner, in writing, signed by the applicant, if an individual, or by a duly authorized agent thereof if not an individual, verified by oath or affidavit, and shall contain the following statements and information: 
1.  In the case of an individual, the full name, age and address of the applicant; in the case of a co-partnership, the persons entitled to share in the profits thereof; in the case of a corporation, the objects for which it is organized, the names and addresses of the officers and directors, and if five percent (5%) or more in interest, in the stock of such corporation is owned by a person or his nominee or nominees, the name and address of each such person or persons; 
2.  The citizenship of the applicant, date and place of birth and, if a naturalized citizen, the time and place of naturalization; 
3.  The character of business of the applicant and in the case of a corporation, the objects for which it was formed; 
4.  The length of time said applicant has been in business of that character, or in the case of a corporation, the objects for which it was formed; 
5.  The amount of goods, wares and merchandise on hand at the time application is made; 
6.  The location and description of the premises or place of business which is to be operated under such license. Such a description shall include a drawing, survey or sketch of the physical boundaries of the premise, indicating which portions of the premises are fully enclosed structure and the locations of entrances and exits thereto; 
a.  If a leased premises, a copy of the lease shall be provided as required and shall be for a term of sufficient length to encompass the period of the license sought. 
b.  The name and address of the owner or owners of the premises and the names and addresses of all the owners of the beneficial interest of any trust if said premises is held in trust; 
7.  A statement whether applicant has made similar application for a similar or other license on premises other than described in this application, and the disposition of such application; 
8.  A statement that applicant has never been convicted of a felony, or a misdemeanor opposed to decency or morality, and is not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or thing contained in the laws of the state or the ordinances of the city; 
9.  Whether a previous license by any state or subdivision thereof or by the federal government has been issued; if so, where and when; or if any such license has been revoked, and the reason therefore; 
10.  The date of incorporation if an Illinois corporation, or the date of becoming qualified under the Illinois Business Corporation Act to transact business in Illinois if a foreign corporation; 
11.  A statement that the applicant will not violate any of the laws of the state, or of the United States, or any ordinance of the city in the conduct of his place of business; 
12.  Such additional information or identification as the local liquor commissioner may deem necessary in order to establish the character of the applicant. Any applicant for a newly created city liquor license or any applicant for a renewal of a city liquor license is to be fingerprinted whether said applicant is an individual or a partnership. Should the applicant be a corporation, the local liquor control commissioner may, within his discretion, require the following to be fingerprinted: the officers, manager or director thereof, or any stockholder or stockholders owning the aggregate of more than five percent (5%) of the capital stock of said corporation. The city police department shall do all such fingerprinting. There shall be a fingerprint fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per person listed on the application to be paid at the time of application and shall be non-refundable, and shall be in addition to all other application fees; 
13.  The local liquor control commissioner shall issue a written acceptance or rejection of such application within sixty (60) days of its receipt by the local liquor control commissioner. 
B.  There shall be an initial application fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) or the total license fee whichever is lower, for all initial license applications which shall be non-refundable and if a license is granted, the application fee shall be applied to the initial license fee. Such application fee shall not be required for renewal licenses. 
C.  If an approved initial license is not issued to the applicant within the same fiscal year in which the license was approved and/or created, the license may be revoked by the liquor control commissioner. 
D.  Certification of the BASSET (beverage alcohol sellers and servers education training) program shall be required of all licensees (including managers, employees, agents, owners, officers or licensees) who sell or serve alcoholic beverages and anyone whose job duties entail the checking of identification, or manages employees whose job duties entail the checking of identification, or who sell or serve alcoholic beverages, pursuant to their license being issued. A "state certified BASSET program" shall be defined as a BASSET program licensed by the state liquor control commission as referenced by 235 ILCS 5/3-12(11.1). A photocopy of certificates of completion for all owners, officers, managers, employees, licensees or agents required to have BASSET training shall be maintained on the premises in a manner that will allow inspection, upon demand, by the local liquor control commissioner, his designee(s), or any designee of the state. Any new officer, owner, manager, employee, or agent requiring BASSET training shall, within one hundred twenty (120) days after the beginning of employment and once every three (3) years thereafter with that licensee, complete an Illinois Liquor Control Commission BASSET approved seller/server training program and shall work under the supervision of a person who has completed BASSET training. All initial BASSET training shall be conducted by a certified BASSET trained instructor provided by the city upon the premises of the city or at an offsite location as approved by the liquor commissioner. Any subsequent or renewal BASSET training may be conducted in person or online. 
(Ord. No. 2011-40, § 1(Exh. A), 9-6-2011; Ord. No. 2016-11, § 1, 3-7-2016; Ord. No. 2017-21, § 2, 9-5-2017) 
4-2-9: - LICENSE RENEWAL DEADLINE: 
Any licensee may renew a local liquor license at the expiration thereof; provided, that licensee is then qualified to receive a local liquor license and the premises for which such renewal local liquor license is sought are suitable for such purpose; provided further, that the renewal privilege set forth in this section shall not be construed as a vested right which, in any case, shall not prevent the local liquor control commissioner from decreasing the number of local liquor licenses to be issued within the city. A liquor licensee shall file an application for renewal of a local liquor license, accompanied by the applicable local liquor license fee and all required documentation, including dram shop insurance coverage and a satisfactory criminal history check of any new or additional owner, shareholder, or manager who meets the criteria as set forth in section 4-2-8, on or before April 1st, in any given year. There shall be a late payment fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for failure to comply with the foregoing. 
(Ord. No. 2011-40, § 1(Exh. A), 9-6-2011; Ord. No. 2018-50, § 1, 12-17-2018) 
4-2-10: - RESTRICTIONS ON ISSUANCE: 
No such license shall be issued to: 
A.  A person who is not a resident of the city for at least one (1) year prior to the date of the license application. For the purpose of this section, a person shall not include a corporation, co-partnership, or limited liability company; 
B.  A person who is not of good character and reputation in the city or in the community in which he resides; 
C.  A person who is not a citizen of the United States; 
D.  A person who has been convicted of a felony under any federal or state law, unless the local liquor control commissioner determines that such person has been sufficiently rehabilitated to warrant the public trust after considering matters set forth in such person's application and the investigation. The burden of proof of sufficient rehabilitation shall be on the applicant; 
E.  A person who has been convicted of being the keeper or is keeping a house of ill fame; 
F.  A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality; 
G.  A person whose license under this chapter or the Liquor Control Act has been revoked for cause; 
H.  A person who at the time of application for renewal of any license issued hereunder would not be eligible for such license upon a first application; 
I.  A co-partnership, or any general partnership thereof, or any limited partnership thereof, owning more than five percent (5%) of the aggregate limited partner interest in such co-partnership would not be eligible to receive a license hereunder for any reason; 
J.  A corporation or limited liability company, if any member, officer, manager or director thereof, or any stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%) of the stock of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license hereunder for any reason; 
K.  A corporation or limited liability company unless it is incorporated or organized in the state, or unless it is a foreign corporation or foreign limited liability company which is qualified under the Business Corporation Act of 1983 or the Limited Liability Company Act to transact business in the state. The local liquor control commissioner shall permit and accept from an applicant for a license under the Illinois Liquor Control Act proof prepared from the secretary of state's website that the corporation or limited liability company is in good standing and is qualified under the Business Corporation Act of 1983 or the Limited Liability Company Act to transact business in the state; 
L.  A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent unless said manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required by the licensee; 
M.  A person who has been convicted of a violation of any federal or state law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor, or who shall have forfeited his bond to appear in court to answer charges for any such violation; 
N.  A person who does not beneficially own the premises for which a license is sought, or does not have a lease thereon for the full period for which the license is to be issued; 
O.  Any law enforcing public official, including members of the local liquor control commission, the mayor or any member of the city council, interested directly or indirectly in the manufacture, sale or distribution of alcoholic liquor whether as an individual or under a corporate entity in such liquor related business, except: 
1.  A license may be granted to such official in relation to premises that are not located within the territory subject to the jurisdiction of that official if the issuance of such license is approved by the state liquor control commission; 
2.  A license may be granted to any member of the city council in relation to premises that are located within the territory subject to the jurisdiction of that official if (i) the sale of alcoholic liquor pursuant to the license is incidental to the selling of food, (ii) the issuance of the license is approved by the state commission, (iii) the issuance of the license is in accordance with all applicable local ordinances in effect where the premises are located, and (iv) the official granted a license does not vote on alcoholic liquor issues pending before the board or council to which the license holder is elected; 
P.  Any person, firm or corporation not eligible for a state retail liquor dealer's license; 
Q.  Any applicant who fails to obtain a state liquor license; 
R.  A person who is not a beneficial owner of the business to be operated by the licensee; 
S.  A person who has been convicted of a gambling offense as proscribed by any of subsections (a)(3) through (a)(11) of Section 28-1 of, or as proscribed by Section 28-1.1 or 28-3 of, the Criminal Code of 1961, approved July 18, 1961, or as proscribed by a statute replacing any of the aforesaid statutory provisions; 
T.  A person or entity to whom a federal wagering stamp has been issued by the federal government, unless the person or entity is eligible to be issued a license under the Illinois Raffles Act or the Illinois Pull Tabs and Jar Games Act; 
U.  A person who intends to sell alcoholic liquors for use or consumption on his or her licensed retail premises who does not have liquor liability insurance coverage for that premises in an amount that is at least equal to the maximum liability amounts set out in the Liquor Control Act; 
V.  A criminal conviction of a corporation is not grounds for the denial, suspension, or revocation of a license applied for or held by the corporation if the criminal conviction was not the result of a violation of any federal or state law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor, the offense that led to the conviction did not result in any financial gain to the corporation and the corporation has terminated its relationship with each director, officer, employee, or controlling shareholder whose actions directly contributed to the conviction of the corporation. The local liquor control commissioner shall determine if all provisions of this subsection V. have been met before any action on the corporation's license is initiated; 
W.  Upon the complaint of the state department of revenue, the local liquor control commissioner shall refuse the issuance or renewal of a local liquor license, or suspend or revoke such license, for any of the following violations of any tax act administered by the state department of revenue: 
1.  Failure to make a tax return; 
2.  The filing of a fraudulent return; 
3.  Failure to pay all or any part of any tax or penalty finally determined to be due; 
4.  Failure to keep books and records; 
5.  Failure to secure and display a certificate or sub-certificate of registration, if required; 
6.  Willful violation of any rule or regulation of the Illinois Department of Revenue relating to the administration and enforcement of tax liability; 
X.  For a premises upon which a sexually-oriented business is located as defined under title 4, chapter 17, "Adult uses of business regulations," of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2011-40, § 1(Exh. A), 9-6-2011; Ord. No. 2016-43, § 1, 12-12-2016) 
4-2-11: - LICENSE CLASSIFICATIONS: 
Local liquor licenses for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor shall be divided into the following classes and sub-classes: 
A.  Class A-Packaged Alcoholic Liquor Licenses: Class A licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquor in original packages only and not for consumption on the premises, except as permitted in conjunction with the Class A-6 license. Class A licenses are divided into the following sub-classes: 
A-1.  Class A-1 licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquors in original packages only and not for consumption on the premises. The primary purpose of the premises shall be the retail sale of alcoholic liquor. No entrance or exit other than for employees shall lead from any other building or portion of building to the area in which alcoholic liquor and incidentals there to shall be sold by a Class A-1 license holder. No other product other than alcoholic liquor and incidentals thereto shall be sold by a Class A-1 license holder. There is a three thousand three hundred dollar ($3,300.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class A-1 license and an annual renewal fee of two thousand two hundred dollars ($2,200.00). 
A-2.  Class A-2 licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquors in original packages only and not for consumption on the premises. The primary purpose of the premises shall be for retail sales other than the retail sales of alcoholic liquor, such as a food store, drug store or mass merchandiser. The premises shall have ten percent (10%) or less, of the gross square footage devoted to the retail sale of alcoholic liquor. If a Class A-2 licensee is located in the same building as a food store or drug store, or is an adjoining building, that portion of the premises designated for sale of alcoholic beverages shall be physically separated from the food store to prohibit access thereto during prohibited hours of operation. The application for a Class A-2 license shall be accompanied with a floor plan of the premises accurately describing the manner in which the food store and liquor department shall be separated. The sale of alcoholic beverages may be permitted at the food store check-out counter, provided that the cashier is at least twenty-one (21) years of age and has completed the beverage alcohol sellers and servers education training (BASSET). The hours of sale of alcoholic beverages shall be not greater than Monday-Saturday, 9:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. and Sunday 10:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. There is a three thousand three hundred dollar ($3,300.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class A-2 license and an annual renewal fee of two thousand two hundred dollars ($2,200.00). 
A-3.  Class A-3 licenses for specialty package stores shall authorize the retail sale for consumption off the premises of bottled beer and wine or alcoholic liquors, provided that the gross receipts from the sale of such alcoholic beverages shall not total more than twenty percent (20%) of the gross dollar sales of other retail sales located within the building where the premises is located. There is a one thousand five hundred dollar ($1,500.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class A-3 license and an annual renewal fee of one thousand two hundred dollars ($1,200.00). 
A-4.  Class A-4 licenses for wine shops shall authorize the retail sale for consumption off premises of wine only. There is a one thousand one hundred dollar ($1,100.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class A-4 license and an annual renewal fee of seven hundred fifteen dollars ($715.00). 
A-5.  Class A-5 licenses for limited specialty package wine and craft beer sales shall authorize the retail sale for consumption off premises only of specialty packaged wines sold by the bottle or case and craft beer sold by the pack or case; and where such sales shall not exceed two percent (2%) of the gross dollar sales of the restaurant establishment in which sold. For purposes of this section, "limited specialty package wines and craft beer" shall mean those wines and beer that are also offered for sale or consumption on the restaurant premises. There is a two hundred dollar ($200.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class A-5 license and an annual renewal fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
A-6.  Class A-6 wine-sampling license shall authorize the sale of wine for consumption on premises only in addition to the product sampling provisions below in subsection 2. There is a two hundred twenty dollar ($220.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class A-6 license and an annual renewal fee of one hundred ten dollars ($110.00). It shall be unlawful for a Class A-6 license holder to sell a sample wine package to any person except under the following conditions: 
1.  The retail sale of wine shall be made in a sampling package. 
2.  The total quantity of the sampling package, regardless of the number of containers in which the wine is served, shall not exceed four (4) ounces of wine. 
3.  Licensee must be a Class A-1, Class A-2, Class A-3, Class A-4 or Class A-5 liquor license holder to qualify for the Class A-6 license. 
The following additional requirements apply to all Class A licenses: 
1.  Beer in containers of sixteen (16) ounces or less shall not be sold to any person in quantities of less than six (6) cans or bottles for consumption. 
2.  A licensee who is a retailer (on-premise or off-premise), distributor, importing distributor, manufacturer and nonresident dealer licensees (on-premise or off-premise) as defined by the Illinois Liquor Control Act of 1934, as amended, may conduct product sampling for consumption at a licensed retail location. Up to three (3) samples, consisting of no more than (i) one-fourth (1/4) ounce of distilled spirits, (ii) one (1) ounce of wine, or (iii) two (2) ounces of beer may be served to a consumer in one (1) day. Such product sampling shall comply with the rules and regulations of the state liquor commission. 
B.  Class B-Restaurant Licenses: Class B licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquors, and beer and wine for consumption on the premises, whose primary purpose is that of a restaurant as defined in this chapter. Live entertainment may be permitted as otherwise provided in this chapter for Class B-3 licenses only. Class B licenses are divided into the following sub-classes: 
B-1.  Class B-1 Restaurants (restricted) licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on premises only without restriction as to the manner served, provided that receipts from the sale of alcohol shall not total more than fifty percent (50%) of the gross dollar sales of the restaurant and provided further that no restaurant licensed as such shall sell alcoholic liquor except with meals, and there shall be no bar within the restaurant. There is a two thousand two hundred dollar ($2,200.00) fee associated with the initial issuance of a Class B-1 license and an annual renewal fee of one thousand six hundred fifty dollars ($1,650.00). 
B-2.  Class B-2 Restaurants (beer and wine only) licenses shall authorize the retail sale of beer and wine only for the consumption on the premises, without restriction as to the manner served, provided that receipts from the sale of alcoholic liquor (beer and wine only) shall not total more than fifty percent (50%) of the gross dollar sales of the restaurant and provided further that no restaurant licensed as such shall sell beer and wine only except with meals and there shall be no bar within the restaurant. There is a one thousand six hundred fifty dollar ($1,650.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class B-2 license and an annual renewal fee of one thousand three hundred twenty dollars ($1,320.00). 
B-3.  Class B-3 Restaurants with cocktail lounge licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquors for consumption on the premises only, without restriction as to the manner served, provided that the sale of alcoholic liquor shall only be made in connection with and in adjunct to a restaurant owned and operated by licensee and located upon the premises; further, the receipts from the sale of alcoholic liquor shall not total more than fifty percent (50%) of the gross dollar sales of the restaurant operation of the premises. Provided further, that for the purposes of this section, "cocktail lounge" shall mean an area within the premises and in conjunction with the restaurant dining area in which there is seating (tables and chairs) for patrons not greater than the seating provided in the restaurant dining area. There is a two thousand seven hundred fifty dollar ($2,750.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class B-3 license and an annual renewal fee of one thousand nine hundred twenty-five dollars ($1,925.00). Class B-3 licenses may be permitted live entertainment if approved by the local liquor control commissioner. Live entertainment may be permitted during the hours that alcoholic liquor may be sold. Notwithstanding the foregoing, outdoor live entertainment is permitted during the following hours: Sunday from 12:00 p.m. to 8:00 p.m.; Monday through Friday from 12:00 p.m. to 10:00 p.m.; Friday and Saturday from 12:00 p.m. to 11:00 p.m. Further, the sound level of any amplified outdoor entertainment shall not exceed sixty (60) decibels at the property line. An outdoor seating license is required in order to serve alcohol outdoors. 
B-4.  Class B-4 Restaurants (wine only) licenses shall authorize the retail sale for the consumption of wine only on the premises, provided that no restaurant licensed as such shall sell wine except with meals. There is a one thousand one hundred dollar ($1,100.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class B-4 license and an annual renewal fee of five hundred fifty dollars ($550.00). 
B-5.  Class B-5 Restaurants with cocktail lounge and brewery authorizes the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises only, without restriction as to the manner served; provided, that the sale of alcoholic liquor shall only be made in connection with and in adjunct to a restaurant owned and operated by licensee and located upon the premises; further, the receipts from the sale of alcoholic liquor shall not total more than fifty percent (50%) of the gross dollar sales of the restaurant liquor operation of the premises. Provided, further, that for the purposes of this section, a "cocktail lounge" shall mean an area within the premises and in conjunction with the restaurant dining area in which there is seating (table and chairs) for patrons not greater than the seating provided in the restaurant area. For the purposes of this section, the term "brewery" shall mean a limited production beer brewery within the premises which manufactures not more than seven hundred (700) barrels of beer per license year (May 1 through April 30) and which product is sold exclusively for consumption on the premises or for carryout (package goods) sales to restaurant customers. There is a three thousand three hundred dollar ($3,300.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class B-5 license and an annual renewal fee of two thousand two hundred dollars ($2,200.00). 
The following additional requirements apply to all Class B licenses: 
1.  Every application for a Class B license, whether an initial application or a renewal application, shall have attached thereto a site drawing of the proposed licensed premises, drawn to scale, showing the following: 
a.  The location of all rooms, segregated areas, including outdoor seating areas and the square footage thereof; 
b.  The designated use of each room or segregated area (e.g. dining room, service bar, kitchen, rest rooms, outdoor seating areas, all rooms and segregated areas, including outdoor areas, where alcoholic liquor may be served or consumed and all locations where live entertainment (Class B-3 only with local liquor control commissioner approval), etc.) may be provided; 
c.  The seating capacity of rooms or segregated areas where the public is permitted to consume food and/or alcoholic beverages and/or live entertainment as allowed in Class B-3 licenses shall be provided. 
2.  The site drawing is subject to the approval of the local liquor control commissioner and building commissioner. The local liquor control commissioner may impose such additional restrictions as he deems appropriate on any licensee by noting same on the approved site drawing or as provided on the face of the license. 
3.  A copy of the approved site drawing shall be attached to the approved license and is made a part of said license. 
4.  It shall be unlawful for any Class B licensee to operate and/or maintain the licensed premises in any manner inconsistent with the approved site drawing. 
5.  See section 4-2-12, "Outdoor seating license." Any outdoor seating area, where alcohol is served, shall be subject to the requirements as stated in section 4-2-12 below. 
6.  Notwithstanding any provision of this chapter to the contrary, Class B licensees shall not permit any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years to enter or remain upon the licensed premises after curfew, unless such person is accompanied by his or her parent or legal guardian at all times. 
7.  A licensee who is a retailer (on or off premise), distributor, importing distributor, manufacturer or nonresident dealer licensee (on-premise or off-premise), as defined by the Illinois Liquor Control Act as amended, may conduct product sampling for consumption at a licensed retail location. Up to three (3) samples, consisting of no more than (i) one-fourth (1/4) ounce of distilled spirits, (ii) one (1) ounce of wine, or (iii) two (2) ounces of beer may be served to a consumer in one (1) day. 
8.  A licensee who is an on-premises retail license holder may offer for sale and serve more than one (1) drink per person for sampling purposes without violating paragraph (1) of subsection (b) of Section 6-28 or paragraph (6) of subsection (c) of Section 6-28 of the Illinois Liquor Control Act of 1934, provided the total quantity of the sampling package, regardless of the number of containers in which the alcoholic liquor is being served, does not exceed one (1) ounce of distilled spirits, four (4) ounces of wine, or sixteen (16) ounces of beer. 
C.  Class C-Tavern; Bar; Saloon Licenses: Class C licenses are divided into the following sub-classes: 
C-1.  Class C-1 licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquors for consumption on the premises of a tavern, bar or saloon. Class C-1 licenses may authorize the sale of alcoholic liquor in outdoor sales areas provided such sales are in conjunction with food service, if approved by the local liquor control commissioner and by the issuance of the additional outdoor seating license as provided in section 4-2-12 of this chapter. Live entertainment may be permitted by the local liquor control commissioner for indoor or outdoor live entertainment Monday through Thursday from 12:00 p.m. to 10:00 p.m.; Friday and Saturday from 12:00 p.m. to 11:00 p.m.; and Sunday noon to 8:00 p.m. The sound level of any amplified outdoor entertainment shall not exceed sixty (60) decibels at the property line. There is a three thousand dollar ($3,000.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class C-1 license and an annual renewal fee of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). 
C-2.  Class C-2 wine bar license shall authorize the sale of wine as follows: a) wine sold by the glass or bottle for consumption on the premises only and b) sale of wine by the bottle and beers (sold warm) for consumption off the premises only. The sale of wine or beer for consumption off the premises must be made in the original sealed bottle or container. There is a two thousand two hundred dollar ($2,200.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class C-2 license and an annual renewal fee of one thousand six hundred fifty dollars ($1,650.00). 
C-3.  Class C-3 licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquors for taverns and certain restaurants, for consumption on or off premises without restriction as to the manner served. The sale of alcoholic liquors must be made in the original sealed bottle or container. There is a three thousand three hundred dollar ($3,300.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class C-3 license and an annual renewal fee of two thousand two hundred dollars ($2,200.00). 
C-4.  Wine and Beer Bar: Class C-4 license shall authorize the sale of wine and beer for consumption on or off the premises. The sale of wine and beer for consumption off the premises must be made in the original sealed bottle or container. There is a three thousand dollar ($3,000.00) fee required with the initial license issuance of a Class C-4 license and an annual renewal fee of two thousand one hundred dollars ($2,100.00). Limited to five (5) licenses. 
C-5.  Reserved for future license designation. 
C-6.  Retail Sale of Beer in Connection With an Onsite Brewery: Authorizes the retail sale of beer (and the samplings as defined below) that is brewed only on the licensed premises, which beer may be either consumed on the licensed premises or in its original package for consumption off the licensed premises; the retail sales of beer shall be only in conjunction with the maintenance of facilities for the manufacture of beer licensed by the Illinois State Liquor Commission, including the storage and distribution of the manufactured beer from the licensed premises. The portion of the licensed premises dedicated to the manufacturing of beer shall be segregated from the remainder of the premises and shall not be generally accessible to the public. Any public tours of the brewery portion of the licensed premises shall be subject to public safety restrictions imposed by the fire department. 
Any samplings of beer, as defined under Section 6-31 of the Illinois Liquor Control Act (235 ILCS 5/6-31), shall be limited to the beer manufactured on the licensed premises under this classification and shall be permitted during the authorized hours of business under the following conditions: 
a.  The location of samplings shall be limited to the retail portion of the licensed premises; 
b.  A Class C-6 licensee may conduct product sampling for consumption at licensed premises only, provided that up to three (3) samples, consisting of no more than two (2) ounces of beer may be served to a consumer in one (1) day. Notwithstanding the foregoing provision to the contrary, a Class C-5 licensee may offer for sale and serve more than one (1) drink per person for sampling purposes provided the total quantity of the beer sampling package, regardless of the number of containers in which the alcoholic liquor is being served, does not exceed sixteen (16) ounces of beer. A price may be set of such samplings but in no event shall samplings be given away; 
c.  All applicable taxes including sales tax shall be collected and paid on all revenue realized from samplings. 
Limited to one (1) license. There is a three thousand five hundred dollar ($3,500.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class C-6 license and an annual renewal fee of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
C-7.  Manufacturer (Craft Distiller): Authorizes a craft distiller, as defined at section 4-2-1 above, to manufacture alcoholic liquors (except beer or wine) in the original package for consumption off the premises only; to sell at retail alcoholic liquors manufactured on the premises; to maintain facilities on the premises for the manufacture of alcoholic liquors as authorized by the Illinois State Liquor Commission; and to store and distribute the manufactured alcoholic liquor on and from the licensed premises. The portion of the licensed premises dedicated to the manufacturing of alcoholic liquors shall be segregated from the remainder of the premises and shall not be generally accessible to the public. Any public tours of the manufacturing portion of the licensed premises shall be subject to public safety restrictions imposed by the Fire Department. 
Any samplings of alcoholic liquors manufactured on the premises, as defined under Section 6-31 of the Illinois Liquor Control Act (235 ILCS 5/6-31), shall be permitted during the authorized hours of business under the following conditions: 
a.  The location of samplings shall be limited to the retail portion of the licensed premises; 
b.  A Class C-7 licensee may conduct product sampling for consumption at licensed premises only, provided that up to three (3) samples, consisting of no more than one-quarter (1/4) ounce of alcoholic liquor may be served to a consumer in one day. Notwithstanding the foregoing provision to the contrary, a Class C-7 licensee may offer for sale and serve more than one drink per person for sampling purposes provided the total quantity of the alcoholic liquor sampling package, regardless of the number of containers in which the alcoholic liquor is being served, does not exceed one (1) ounces of alcoholic liquor. A price may be set of such samplings but in no event shall samplings be given away; 
c.  All applicable taxes including sales tax shall be collected and paid on all revenue realized from samplings. 
Limited to one (1) license. There is a four thousand dollar ($4,000.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class C-7 license and an annual renewal fee of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00). 
The following additional requirements apply to all Class C licenses: 
1.  Every application for a Class C license, whether an initial application or a renewal application, shall have attached thereto a site drawing of the proposed licensed premises, drawn to scale, showing the following: 
a.  The location of all rooms, segregated areas, including outdoor seating areas and the square footage thereof; 
b.  The seating capacity of rooms or segregated areas where the public is permitted to consume food and/or alcoholic beverages and/or live entertainment as allowed in Class C-1 licenses shall be provided. 
2.  The site drawing is subject to the approval of the local liquor control commissioner and building commissioner. The local liquor control commissioner may impose such additional restrictions as he deems appropriate on any licensee by noting same on the approved site drawing or as provided on the face of the license. 
3.  A copy of the approved site drawing shall be attached to the approved license and is made a part of said license. 
4.  It shall be unlawful for any Class C licensee to operate and/or maintain the licensed premises in any manner inconsistent with the approved site drawing. See section 4-2-12, "Outdoor seating license." Any outdoor seating area shall be subject to the requirements as stated in section 4-2-12. 
D.  Class D-Alcoholic Liquor Sales At Site Specific Locations Licenses: Class D licenses are divided into the following sub-classes: 
D-1.  Class D-1 licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquors for consumption on the premises of any resort hotel or inn only and shall be issued only to the operator of said resort hotel or inn. The licensee shall be authorized to sell, at retail, alcoholic liquors as permitted under a Class B or C licenses. Additionally, each of the residence rooms of the resort hotel or inn may have a mini-bar that may be accessed only by a special key obtained from the hotel management by a patron that may be served alcoholic liquors. Class D-1 licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquors for consumption on the premises of any resort hotel or inn only and shall be issued only to the operator of said resort hotel or inn. Live entertainment shall be permitted with local liquor control commissioner approval. It shall be unlawful for licensee to keep open, or permit to be open, any part of the premises which is not within an enclosed structure and where alcoholic liquor is sold or consumed, between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m., Sunday through Thursday, and 10:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m., Friday and Saturday. It shall be unlawful for a licensee of a Class D-1 license to play, or permit to be played, music, or to cause to have performed such other forms of music or entertainment by means of electronic amplification on the premises, except notwithstanding the foregoing, outdoor live entertainment is permitted during the following hours: Sunday from 12:00 p.m. to 8:00 p.m.; Monday through Friday from 12:00 p.m. to 10:00 p.m.; Friday and Saturday from 12:00 p.m. to 11:00 p.m. The sound level of any amplified outdoor entertainment shall not exceed sixty (60) decibels at the property line. For the purposes of this section, "enclosed structure" shall mean a fully enclosed, solid exterior walls, roofed building with all exterior walls constructed of masonry or wood building materials. There is an eight thousand dollar ($8,000.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class D-1 license and an annual renewal fee of four thousand dollars ($4,000.00). An outdoor seating license is required to serve alcohol outdoors. 
D-2.  Class D-2 licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquors for consumption on the premises of any hotel, motel or bed and breakfast and shall be issued only to the operator of said hotel, motel or bed and breakfast. The licensee shall be authorized to sell, at retail, alcoholic liquors as permitted by Class B and C licenses. Additionally, each of the residence rooms of the hotel, motel or bed and breakfast may have a mini-bar that may be accessed only by a special key obtained from the hotel management by a patron that may be served alcoholic liquors. This license permits the sale of alcohol through room service on premises. There is a three thousand three hundred dollar ($3,300.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class D-2 license and an annual renewal fee of two thousand two hundred dollars ($2,200.00). 
D-3.  Class D-3 licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquors for consumption on the premises only of a not-for-profit golf club, tennis club or any other not-for-profit recreational club or entity. Licensee shall not display any outdoor signs, or any signs visible from the exterior of the premises, advertising the sale of alcoholic beverages. There is a two thousand five hundred dollar ($2,500.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class D-3 license and an annual renewal fee of one thousand four hundred dollars ($1,400.00). A D-3 license shall entitle the licensee to serve members and guests: 
1.  Beer and wine daily for consumption on the premises; 
2.  Other alcoholic liquor a maximum of two (2) days each calendar week for consumption on the premises; and 
3.  Licensee shall not display any outdoor signs, or any signs visible from the exterior of the premises, advertising the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
D-4.  Class D-4 licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquors for consumption on the premises only of for-profit clubs in the club house and on the golf course. Class D-4 licenses shall authorize the sale of alcoholic liquors from the club house and from motorized or stationary food and beverage carts operating on the eighteen (18) hole golf course for consumption on said club house or golf course, subject to the following restrictions: all alcoholic liquors shall be served in other than glass containers on the golf course; all carts shall only operate on designated golf cart paths. There is a two thousand two hundred dollar ($2,200.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class D-4 license and an annual renewal fee of one thousand six hundred fifty dollars ($1,650.00). 
D-5.  Class D-5 licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquors for consumption on the premises only, of any general not-for-profit club licensed with the Illinois Secretary of State, provided, that such club shall have been in existence for at least six (6) months prior to the filing of an application for a license under this chapter and shall have maintained clubrooms for such period of time immediately preceding the filing of its application. A club refers to an applicant, whose principal place of operation is within the geographic boundary of the city and which shall have been organized solely for the promotion of some common object other than the sale or consumption of food and alcoholic liquor. There is a five hundred fifty dollar ($550.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class D-5 license and an annual renewal fee of three hundred thirty dollars ($330.00). 
D-6.  Class D-6 licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquors for consumption on the premises only, of any banquet hall. For the purposes of this classification, "banquets, receptions and special events" shall mean such functions where meals are served. There is a three thousand three hundred dollar ($3,300.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class D-6 license and an annual renewal fee of two thousand two hundred dollars ($2,200.00). 
D-7.  Park District license shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquors for service and consumption of alcoholic beverages on all park district-owned premises within enclosed structures only, as well as their leased premises at 321 Steven Street, Suite "P", for the purposes of theater events only within that space. There is a fee of seven hundred dollars ($700.00) required with the initial issuance of a Class D-7 and five hundred dollars ($500.00) annual renewal fee. The Class D-7 license shall entitle the Geneva Park District, as licensee, to serve alcoholic beverages for consumption on property owned by the licensee as follows: 
1.  The service and consumption of alcoholic beverages at park district-owned properties shall be on the premises only and shall be served and consumed within a fully enclosed structure. 
2.  The service and consumption of alcoholic beverages at park district-owned properties shall not be prior to noon, nor later than midnight, and service and consumption of said beverages shall be permitted only on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays. 
3.  The service and consumption of alcoholic beverages at the 321 Stevens Street, Suite "P" location shall only take place on days when adult theater events are taking place on the licensed premises and from one (1) permanent location within the licensed premises. 
D-8.  A.  Class D-8 Kane County Forest Preserve District License for Settler's Hill Golf Course. Class D-8 License for Settler's Hill Golf Course shall be run by a for-profit company. The Class D-8 liquor license shall authorize the retail sale of beer and wine on the premises only. There is a two thousand two hundred dollar ($2,200.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class D-8 license and an annual renewal fee of one thousand six hundred fifty dollars ($1,650.00). A Class D-8 license shall entitle the private liquor license holder, leasing from the Kane County Forest Preserve District, owner of the Settler's Hill golf course, to serve: 
1.  Beer and wine daily for consumption in the golf club house, and 
2.  Beer and wine from a mobile beverage cart. 
B.  Class D-8 Kane County Forest Preserve District License for Fox Valley Ice Arena. Class D-8 License for Fox Valley Ice Arena shall be run by a for-profit company. The Class D-8 liquor license shall authorize the retail sale of beer and wine on the premises only. There is a two thousand two hundred dollar ($2,200.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class D-8 license and an annual renewal fee of one thousand six hundred fifty dollars ($1,650.00). A Class D-8 license shall entitle the private liquor license holder, leasing from the Kane County Forest Preserve District, owner of the Fox Valley Ice Arena to serve: 
1.  Beer and wine from three (3) vending stands located within the ice rink arena. 
2.  Alcoholic beverages for consumption only within the fifteen (15) third floor suites within the Fox Valley Ice Arena. 
3.  The licensee shall not permit any person to purchase more than two (2) alcoholic beverages at one (1) time. 
4.  The sale of alcoholic beverages within the ice rink arena and in the fifteen (15) third floor suites, shall be permitted only at the regularly scheduled Junior Team games and such end of season playoff games in which the Junior Team participates, the regularly scheduled ice hockey games and a maximum of two (2) additional hockey games that may be scheduled in the Ice Arena. 
5.  Alcoholic beverages shall not be sold earlier than thirty (30) minutes prior to the starting time of any hockey game at any of the three (3) vending stands in the ice arena or in any of the third floor fifteen (15) suites and such sales shall terminate prior to the commencement of the third period of play. 
6.  In no event shall any alcoholic beverages be sold in the ice rink arena or in the fifteen (15) third floor suites, after 10:00 p.m. 
7.  Licensee shall not advertise the sale of alcoholic beverages, including, but not limited to, the use of any signs, trademarks, mascots or emblems or any manufacturer of alcoholic beverages, which may be visible from the exterior of the building housing the ice rink arena. 
8.  Licensee shall require that any person over the age of twenty-one (21) years or older who desires to purchase alcoholic beverages within the ice rink arena or in the fifteen (15) third floor suites, to present satisfactory age identification at such age identification stations located in the lobby areas adjoining the ice rink arena and that such person shall received an identifying wristband verifying their proof of age. 
9.  No alcoholic beverages shall be sold or consumed on the second floor of the facility. 
10.  No alcoholic beverages shall be sold at any high school, or college hockey or ice skating event. 
The following requirement applies to all Class D licenses: Every application for a Class D license, whether an initial application or a renewal application, shall have attached thereto a site drawing of the proposed licensed premises, drawn to scale, showing the following: 
1.  The location of all rooms, segregated areas, including outdoor seating areas and the square footage thereof. 
2.  The seating capacity of rooms or segregated areas where the public is permitted to consume food and/or alcoholic beverages as allowed in Class D licenses shall be provided. 
3.  The site drawing is subject to the approval of the local liquor control commissioner and building commissioner. The local liquor control commissioner may impose such additional restrictions as he deems appropriate on any licensee by noting same on the approved site drawing or as provided on the face of the license. 
4.  A copy of the approved site drawing shall be attached to the approved license and is made a part of said license. 
5.  It shall be unlawful for any Class D licensee to operate and/or maintain the licensed premises in any manner inconsistent with the approved site drawing. See section 4-2-12, "Outdoor seating license." Any outdoor seating area shall be subject to the requirements as stated in section 4-2-12. 
E.  Class E-Temporary Licenses: Class E licenses shall authorize the temporary retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises only (unless otherwise specified) and only for one (1) event. Class E licenses are divided into the following sub-classes: 
E-1.  Class E-1 (Not-for-Profit Fundraiser) licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises only. A Class E-1 license may be issued by the local liquor control commissioner provided that all of the requirements of section 4-2-10 above and as set forth herein are satisfied and the applicant obtains a special event license from the state liquor control commission. Class E-1 licenses shall be issued to general not-for-profit applicants only, for special events or catered functions, where the dispensing of food predominates. Applicants for Class E-1 licenses shall be limited to city general not-for-profit organizations or groups. There shall be no Class E-1 licenses issued during any sanctioned city festivals or fairs. In addition to all other conditions and restrictions applicable to Class E-1 licenses, the local liquor control commissioner may impose such additional conditions and/or restrictions as deemed necessary. A qualified applicant for this classification shall be a fraternal, charitable, religious corporation, association, or club organized under the general not-for-profit laws of the state which shall have been in operation and existence for at least three (3) years prior to application, whose principal place of operation is within the geographic boundary of the city and which shall have been organized solely for the promotion of some common object other than the sale or consumption of food and alcoholic liquor. There shall be no maximum number of Class E-1 licenses issued during any fiscal year. There is a one hundred dollar ($100.00) fee required with each issuance of a Class E-1 license. 
A "special event" under this license shall be a fundraising activity exclusively supporting applicants' regular purposes and conducted by its members: 
1.  For a specific date or dates which shall not exceed a total of fifteen (15) days in any fiscal year; and 
2.  Conducted at a premise that shall be named on the application. 
3.  Application for permission to conduct a special event shall be written, signed by the applicant, verified under oath, and shall contain the following information: 
a.  Name and address of applicant; 
b.  Date of incorporation, or date association or club organized; 
c.  Purpose or object for which organized; 
d.  Summary of activity during the past year; 
e.  The person or persons in charge of the event; 
f.  The location and description of the premises or place of business which is to be operated under such license. Such a description shall include a drawing, survey or sketch of the physical boundaries of the premise, indicating which portions of the premises are fully enclosed structures and the locations of entrances and exits thereto; 
i.  If a leased premises, a copy of the lease shall be provided as required and shall be for a term of sufficient length to encompass the period of the license sought. 
ii.  The name and address of the owner or owners of the premises and the names and addresses of all the owners of the beneficial interest of any trust if said premises is held in trust; 
g.  The date or dates and time of the proposed event; 
h.  A brief description of the nature of the event; 
i.  The recipient of the anticipated profits; 
j.  A list of its directors and officers. 
E-2.  Class E-2 (For-Profit Events) licenses shall authorize, the retail sale of alcoholic liquor by a for-profit entity for consumption on the premises only. There shall be no maximum number of Class E-2 licenses issued during any fiscal year. Class E-2 licenses may be issued only to an existing Class B, C, D or F liquor license holder for events or catered functions where the dispensing of food predominates. There shall be no Class E-2 licenses issued during any sanctioned city festivals or fairs. There is a two hundred dollar ($200.00) fee required with each issuance of a Class E-2 license. 
1.  In addition to all other conditions and restrictions applicable to Class E-2 licenses, the local liquor control commissioner may impose such additional conditions and/or restrictions as deemed necessary. 
2.  An event under this class shall be conducted by its owners/members: 
a.  For a specific date or dates, not to exceed three (3) consecutive days; 
b.  Conducted at a premise that shall be named on the application. Said premises shall be on private property. 
3.  Application for permission to conduct a special event shall be written, signed by the applicant, verified under oath, and shall contain the following information: 
a.  Name and address of applicant; 
b.  The person or persons in charge of the event; 
c.  The location and description of the premises or place of business which is to be operated under such license. Such a description shall include a drawing, survey or sketch of the physical boundaries of the premise, indicating which portions of the premises are fully enclosed structure and the locations of entrances and exits thereto; 
i.  If a leased premises, a copy of the lease shall be provided as required and shall be for a term of sufficient length to encompass the period of the license sought. 
ii.  The name and address of the owner or owners of the premises and the names and addresses of all the owners of the beneficial interest of any trust if said premises is held in trust; 
d.  The date or dates and time of the proposed event; 
e.  A brief description of the nature of the event; 
f.  A copy of the certificate of insurance for Dram Shop coverage. 
E-3.  Class E-3 (City Fair - Public property with outdoor sales) licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquor as follows: A Class E-3 license may be issued by the local liquor control commissioner provided that all of the requirements at section 4-2-10 above are satisfied and the applicant obtains a special event license from the state liquor control commission. A maximum of three (3) temporary licenses may be issued concurrently, and subject to prior approval by the city council, either for the sale or delivery of alcoholic liquors, for consumption on city owned property only during the time period of a sanctioned and specific city festival or fair, approved by the city council. There is a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per day, or one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day if live entertainment is being provided, required with each issuance of a Class E-3 license for not-for-profit organizations and four hundred dollars ($400.00) per day or five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day if live entertainment is being provided, required for a for-profit applicant. 
E-4.  Class E-4 (City Fair - Private property, for profit outdoor sales) licenses shall authorize, the retail sale of alcoholic liquor as follows: A Class E-4 license may be issued by the local liquor control commissioner provided that all of the requirements at section 4-2-10 are satisfied and the applicant obtains a license from the state liquor control commission. The license shall permit the temporary retail sale or delivery of alcoholic liquor, by existing licensees from outdoor locations outside of the licensed premises but within the property line for the purpose of consumption on the property or for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor in the original package and not for consumption on the premises. It is the city council's intent that such regulations and controls be established to permit licensees' limited, outdoor sales of such alcoholic beverages during city festivals or fairs, approved by the city council, occurring within the city, while providing certain protections to adjoining or surrounding property owners or occupants. Class E-4 licenses shall only be issued during sanctioned and specific city festivals or fairs. There is a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per day, or one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day if live entertainment is being provided, required with each issuance of a Class E-4 license. Applicants must be a license holder in good standing of a Class B, C, D, or F liquor license under this chapter and obtain a special use license from the state liquor control commission. 
There shall be no more than five (5) E-4 liquor licenses issued at any one time. 
E-5.  Class E-5 (City Fair - private property, for profit off-site with outdoor sales) licenses shall authorize, either the temporary retail sale or delivery of alcoholic liquor from a location, other than a licensee's premises, outside of the licensed premises but within the property lines of the licensed location, for the purpose of consumption on the property. It is the city council's intent that such regulations and controls be established to permit licensees' limited authority for the sale of such alcoholic liquor at a location other than the licensee's customary premises, outside of a building or permanent structure but within the property lines of the licensed premises, during special, designated city festivals or fairs, approved by the city council, which occur within the city, while providing certain protections to adjoining or surrounding property owners or occupants. Class E-5 licenses shall only be issued during sanctioned city festivals or fairs. There is a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per day, or one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day if live entertainment is being provided, with each issuance of a Class E-5 license. Applicants must be a license holder in good standing of a Class B, C, D, or F liquor license under this chapter and obtain a special use license from the state liquor control commission. 
There shall be no more than three (3) E-5 liquor licenses issued at any one time. 
E-6.  Class E-6 (City Fair/Festival - For the Geneva Chamber of Commerce) licenses shall authorize, either the temporary retail sale of beer and/or wine from either private or public property, for the purpose of consumption on the premises. It is the city council's intent that such regulations and controls be established to permit licensees' limited authority for the sale of such beer and/or wine at a location other than the licensee's customary premises, outside of a building or permanent structure but within the property lines of the licensed premises, during special, designated city festivals or fairs, approved by the city council, which occur within the city, while providing certain protections to adjoining or surrounding property owners or occupants. Class E-6 license shall only be issued during sanctioned city festivals or fairs. There is a limit of five (5) E-6 licenses per year. There is a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per festival or fair. 
For Class E temporary licenses, the following restrictions shall apply, in addition to all other requirements: 
1.  It shall be unlawful for any licensee or person, firm, corporation, partnership or club, to sell, or offer to sell, any alcoholic liquor from any indoor or outdoor location without first: 
a.  Obtaining a Class E license as provided in this section; and 
b.  Specifying the exact location where the licensee's sale of alcoholic liquor will be conducted during the temporary event; 
c.  Providing written consent from the property owner of such location that the retail sale and dispensing of alcoholic liquor is acceptable, if applicable. 
d.  Any outdoor area where alcoholic liquor is sold or consumed shall be enclosed or cordoned off by use of a temporary fence which shall be not less than thirty-six (36) inches in height nor more than seventy-two (72) inches in height, and provided with required, unobstructed exits at least thirty-six (36) inches wide, and as prescribed by the fire prevention code. 
e.  The licensee shall provide for pickup of all litter and trash. 
f.  It shall be unlawful for any holder of an E-3, E-4 or E-5 and E-6 license to sell or otherwise dispense alcoholic beverages from an outdoor location on premises except during the following hours upon the following days of the week: 
Sunday 11:00 a.m. - 8:00 p.m. Monday through Thursday 11:00 a.m. - 11:00 p.m. Friday through Saturday 11:00 a.m. - midnight  
g.  Any outdoor area shall have designated entrance and exit points for patrons. 
h.  During the hours of operations, each point of entrance or exit to the outdoor area must have a minimum of one (1) person over the age of twenty-one (21) years acting as an agent of the license holder, to identify persons over the age of twenty-one (21) years. 
i.  A tamper-proof wrist band, of a design and in a color (a separate color must be used for each day) and/or a distinct hand stamp approved by the chief of police, or designee, shall be placed on the wrist/hand of each person eligible to purchase alcoholic liquor prior to that person being given access to the licensed premises. The local liquor control commissioner has the sole discretion and as designated in any Class E license, to permit minors to be present, when accompanied by a parent or legal guardian, in a licensed premise where food is also served. 
j.  The license holder shall provide adequate toilet facilities in accordance with the regulations of the Kane County Public Health Department. 
k.  No application for outdoor retail sale of alcoholic liquor shall be made sooner than the beginning of the fiscal year, in which the requested date(s) for the license takes place, or later than thirty (30) days prior to the requested date(s) for the license. 
l.  Last call for alcoholic liquor shall be announced at least thirty (30) minutes prior to the designated closing time. Dispensing of alcoholic liquor shall cease fifteen (15) minutes prior to the designated closing time. 
m.  It shall be unlawful for any holder of an outdoor liquor license to play or cause to play amplified music or cause to have performed such other forms of entertainment by means or use of electronic amplification except during the following hours upon the following days of the week: 
Sunday 11:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. Monday through Thursday 11:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. Friday through Saturday 11:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m.  
n.  The local liquor control commissioner may, in his sole discretion and as designated in any license, impose such other and further conditions, as the local liquor control commissioner deems necessary. The local liquor control commissioner may permit entertainment as specifically authorized with the issuance of any Class E license. 
The following additional requirements apply to all Class E licenses: 
1.  Holders of Class E licenses may conduct on-premise wine tasting, but only in connection with the bona fide sale of wines in the original package for consumption not on the premises. Wine tasting shall be confined to samples of not more than three (3) one-ounce (1 oz.) pours in conjunction with the anticipated sale of wine. The sample shall be provided without compensation. Class E local liquor license holders may conduct such wine tasting, but only with the written approval of the local liquor control commissioner. 
2.  Class E licenses shall permit live entertainment only as expressly permitted in the approval of any such Class E license. 
F.  Class F-Catering Licenses: Class F licenses are divided into the following sub-classes: 
F-1.  Class F-1 Catering license shall authorize the retail sale and service of alcoholic liquor for consumption only at the location (solely within the corporate limits of the city) where prepared meals and alcoholic liquor are served by the caterer. There is a two thousand dollar ($2,000.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class F-1 license and an annual renewal fee of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). There shall be no more than two (2) Class F-1 licenses at any one time. 
F-2.  Class F-2 Restricted catering license shall authorize the retail sale and service of alcoholic liquor for not more than twelve (12) catered events in a calendar year in which retail sale and service of alcoholic liquor for consumption only at the location (solely within the corporate limits of the city) where prepared meals and alcoholic liquor are served by the caterer. There is a one thousand dollar ($1,000.00) fee required with the initial issuance of a Class F-2 license and an annual renewal fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). There shall be no more than five (5) Class F-2 licenses at any one time. 
The following additional requirements apply to all Class F licenses: 
A.  The holder of an F-1 catering class license or F-2 restricted catering class license must have either a licensed premises within the corporate limits of the city over which such licensee has exclusive control or a restaurant, with a valid restaurant license, within the corporate limits of the city. All sales of alcoholic liquor and all sales of foodstuffs and other items delivered by the holder of an F-1 catering license or F-2 restricted catering license shall be made at the licensed premises or the licensed restaurant premises. The holder of an F-1 catering class license or F-2 restricted catering class license is prohibited from selling and serving alcoholic liquors in a restaurant which is not licensed premises under this chapter. 
B.  The holder of the F-1 catering class license or F-2 restricted catering class license shall have the affirmative obligation to notify the Geneva Police Department, in writing, not less than five (5) business days prior to the catering of any event within the city in which alcoholic beverages are to be served of the date, time and street location of the event. 
C.  The place where alcoholic liquor is served by the holder of the F-1 catering class license or F-2 restricted catering class license may be licensed or unlicensed premises, provided that the location is not otherwise prohibited under section 4-2-23. In the event prepared meals and/or alcoholic liquors are sold pursuant to a contract requiring the caterer's services at the same location for more than seven (7) days per calendar year, a place within that location where the alcoholic liquor is served must be a licensed premise. 
G.  Class G-Bring Your Own (BYO) Licenses: Class G licenses shall authorize customers to carry their own beer and wine into a licensed establishment. Class G licenses are divided into the following classes: 
G-1.  Class G-1 Bring Your Own Restaurant License (BYO-R) authorizes restaurants, without liquor licenses, to permit the customers to carry their own beer and wine into the restaurant for consumption within that restaurant.
