Settlement Of Violations: Any person accused of a violation of this section, may settle and compromise the claim of the violation against him by paying to the city, within ten (10) days of the time such alleged violation or offense was committed, the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00). Consecutive violations of this section shall be treated as separate offenses, and payment of such claims shall be made at the police department. In the event such claim or claims are not paid within thirty (30) days of the time of the alleged offense, a notice to appear or warrant (summons) may be issued for the arrest of the offender. (1975 Code § 5-74) 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
1. 430 ILCS 85/2-1 et seq. 

--- (6) --- 
See section 11-3-8 of this code. 

4-4-7: - MOTION PICTURES AND THEATERS: 
A.  License Provisions: 
1.  Required: It shall be unlawful to give, present or conduct any motion picture or theatrical for admission to which a fee is charged, except performances given solely for the benefit of and under the supervision of a religious, educational or charitable organization, without first securing a license therefor. (1975 Code § 5-120) 
2.  Application: The application for a license required by this section shall be made in conformance with the general provisions relating to such application and shall state in addition to the other information required the place of the intended performance and the seating capacity thereof. (1975 Code § 5-121) 
3.  Fee: The annual fee for a license required by this section shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per screen or stage. Any person securing an annual license for motion pictures or theatricals, naming a specific place or building where the performances are to be presented, may present therein any number of performances, including theatricals, during the year for which the license was secured without having to pay any additional fee. (1975 Code § 5-122) 
B.  Motion Pictures And Theatricals On Unlicensed Premises Prohibited: For motion pictures or theatricals which are to be presented in premises which are not covered by a license required by this section, a fee shall be paid in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00) per day; provided that no such motion picture or theatrical shall be presented in or on any premises or building which does not fully comply with the requirements of the ordinances relating to public gatherings and to maintenance of buildings for such purpose. (1975 Code § 5-123) 
4-4-8: - SKATING RINKS: 
A.  License Provisions: 
1.  Required: It shall be unlawful to operate or maintain a public skating rink in the city without first obtaining a license therefor. (1975 Code § 5-146) 
2.  Application: The application for a license required by this section shall be made in conformance with the provisions of the ordinances relating to licenses and shall specify the location of the proposed skating rink and the person or organization sponsoring the same. 
3.  Investigation: It shall be the duty of the chief of police to make or cause to be made an investigation into the character of each applicant and report the results of such investigation to the city council. No such license shall be issued to a person who is not of good moral character, nor to a corporation or organization which is not represented in the city by a person of good moral character. (1975 Code § 5-147) 
4.  Fee: The fee for a license required by this section shall be as prescribed from time to time by the city council. (1975 Code § 5-148) 
B.  Inspections: No license required by this section shall be issued until an inspection of the premises shall have been made by the chief of police and the building commissioner of the city, and a report made that such premises are in a safe condition, and that proper safeguards have been taken for the protection of patrons and the public. (1975 Code § 5-149) 
4-4-9: - SETTLEMENT OF VIOLATIONS: 
Any person accused of a violation of this chapter may settle and compromise the claim of violation against him by paying to the city, within ten (10) days of the time such alleged violation or offense was committed, the sum of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each such violation or offense. Consecutive violations of this chapter shall be treated as separate offenses. Payment of such claim or claims shall be made at the police station of the city, or in the fine/claim deposit boxes located upon the streets of the city. The funds received from such compromised claims shall be promptly turned over to the city treasurer to be credited to the general corporate fund. In the event such claim or claims are not paid within ten (10) days of the time of the alleged offense, a notice to appear or a warrant (summons) may be issued for the arrest of the offender. (1975 Code §§ 5-7, 5-27, 5-50, 5-124, 5-150) 
CHAPTER 4 
AMUSEMENTS 
ARTICLE A. - COIN OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICES 
SECTION: 

4-4A-1: - DEFINITIONS: 
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article: 
COIN OPERATED 
AMUSEMENT DEVICE: Any machine which, upon the inserting of a coin, card, slug, token, plate or disc may be operated by the public generally for use as a game, entertainment or amusement, whether or not registering a score. It includes such devices as marble machines, pinball machines, electronic games, skill ball, mechanical grab machines and all games, operations or transactions similar thereto under whatever name they may be known. PERSON: Includes any person, firm, corporation or association which owns any coin operated amusement device, the person, firm, corporation or association in whose place of business any such device is placed for use by the public, and the person, firm, corporation or association having control over such device. PINBALL MACHINE: A game, table or implements for any game including, but not limited to, bagatelle, pigeonhole or pin games played with any number of balls or spheres upon a table or board having holes, pockets or cups into which such balls or spheres may drop or become lodged and having arches, pins and springs, or any of them, to control, deflect or impede the direction or speed of the balls or spheres put in motion by the player. (1975 Code § 18-80; amd. 2003 Code)  
4-4A-2: - LICENSE REQUIRED: 
A.  Keeping Or Displaying Machines For Use: No person shall keep or display for operation or patronage by the public within the city any coin operated amusement device without having first obtained a license therefor from the city administrator. No person shall keep or display for operation or patronage by the public within the city more than forty (40) coin operated amusement devices upon a single premises. There shall be no more than one license issued under this article. (1975 Code § 18-81) 
B.  Engaging In Business Of Keeping/Operating Machines: No person shall engage in the business of operating any coin operated amusement device, as defined in section 4-4A-1 of this article, for public use within the city without first having obtained a license therefor from the city administrator. For purposes of this subsection, any person who keeps or provides not more than three (3) coin operated amusement devices on a premises that is devoted to the conduct of another principal business shall be conclusively presumed not to be engaged in the business of keeping or providing coin operated amusement devices for public use. (1975 Code § 18-82; amd. 2003 Code) 
4-4A-3: - LICENSE APPLICATION; ISSUANCE: 
A.  Contents Of Application: Applications for the licenses required in subsection 4-4A-2B of this article shall be filed in triplicate and shall contain the following information: 
1.  If the applicant is a corporation: 
a.  Corporate name and address; 
b.  Names, dates of birth, and addresses of corporate officers and directors; 
c.  Statement of principal kind of business in which corporation engages; 
d.  Statement of whether corporate business will be conducted by a manager, and the name, address and authority of any such manager or agent; 
e.  Names, dates of birth, and addresses of all persons, firms and organizations owning of record five percent (5%) or more of the corporation's stock; 
f.  Statement of whether any officer, manager, director or shareholder owning five percent (5%) or more of the stock of the corporation has ever been convicted of a felony or has ever forfeited an appearance bond on a felony charge; 
g.  The location of the place of business and the place where the coin operated amusement device is to be kept or displayed; 
h.  Statement of personal history of the manager or agent conducting business for the corporation. 
2.  If the applicant is an individual or partnership: 
a.  Name and address, and date of birth of applicant; 
b.  Location of place of business; 
c.  Principal kind of business engaged in; 
d.  Statement of whether the business will be conducted by a manager or agent, and the name and address and date of birth of any such manager or agent; 
e.  The places where coin operated amusement devices are to be displayed and a description of the devices; 
f.  Statement of personal history of the manager or agent conducting business for applicant. (1975 Code § 18-83) 
B.  Investigation; Issuance Of License: The chief of police and the building commissioner shall investigate the information contained in the application, and shall determine if the premises designated by the applicant as the location of the business complies with the provisions of the zoning ordinance of the city. [7] The report of such investigation and determination, together with a copy of the application, shall be transmitted to the mayor. Upon the compliance by the applicant with the requirements of this article and the zoning ordinance of the city, the mayor shall instruct the city clerk to issue the license and, upon payment by the applicant of the license fee required under this article such license shall be issued. (1975 Code § 18-84) 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
See title 11 of this code. 

4-4A-4: - LICENSE FEES: 
A.  Keeping Or Displaying Machines For Use: For licenses required by subsection 4-4A-2A of this article, the following annual fees shall be paid for each device: 
1 to 3 devices $50.00 Over 3 devices 125.00 (1975 Code § 18-85)  
B.  Engaging In Business Of Keeping/Operating Machines: The annual fee for the license required by subsection 4-4A-2B of this article shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) and shall be valid from May 1 to April 30. (1975 Code § 18-86) 
4-4A-5: - TRANSFER OF LICENSE: 
The licenses required in this article may be transferred from one device to another similar device upon application to the city clerk; such application is to include a description and serial number of the new device and the payment of a fee of three dollars ($3.00). (1975 Code § 18-87) 
4-4A-6: - RULES OF OPERATION: 
A.  Required By All Licensees: In addition to any other condition or regulation contained in this article or in the statutes of the state, the following conditions and regulations shall be applicable to and shall govern and control the business of keeping or providing coin operated amusement devices for public use within the city: 
1.  The walls, ceiling or floor, or any combination thereof, of the building or structure, or portion thereof, containing such devices shall be insulated or otherwise constructed so that no noise or vibration that is detectable without the aid of any mechanical device or instrument will be allowed beyond the outer perimeter of the licensed premises. 
2.  No coin operated amusement device shall be used for purposes of or in connection with the wagering of money, goods or merchandise upon the outcome of the use or manipulation of such device or otherwise used for purposes of gambling as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/28-1. 
3.  At all times during the hours of operation of the licensed premises there shall be present a manager or other employee of the licensee, at least one of whom provides adequate control and supervision of the licensed premises and the use of the coin operated amusement devices present therein. 
4.  Licensee shall be responsible for maintaining full compliance with the rules and regulations of this article and the terms of its license. 
B.  Required By Licensees Operating More Than Three Coin Operated Devices: In addition to any of the conditions or regulations contained in this article, or in the statutes of the state, the following conditions and regulations shall be applicable to and shall govern and control the business of keeping or providing coin operated amusement devices for public use within the city under subsection 4-4A-2B of this article: 
1.  Licensee, except for licensees of alcoholic beverages for the same premises, shall provide bicycle parking racks equal to one and one-half (11/2) spaces per licensed coin operated device. 
2.  Licensee shall not allow smoking of tobacco products or the possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages upon the premises, unless specifically licensed for the sale of alcoholic beverages under chapter 2 of this title. 
3.  No building or structure in which a licensed premises is located shall be within one hundred feet (100') of a church or school (private or public), as measured from building line to building line. 
4.  Except for premises which are licensed for the sale of alcoholic beverages, a licensed premises shall maintain a clear, open and unencumbered view of the interior of the premises from street view. 
5.  Licensee, except for licensees permitted to sell alcoholic beverages upon the premises, shall operate said business only within the following hours of the day: 
On days in which elementary or secondary schools are in session 3:30 P.M. to 10:00 P.M. Nonschool days (including Fridays after schools close) and Saturdays 10:00 A.M. to 11:00 P.M. Sundays 12:00 noon to 10:00 P.M. (1975 Code § 18-89)  
C.  Noncompliance: It is unlawful for any person licensed to engage in the business of keeping or providing coin operated amusement devices for public use within the city to fail to comply with the conditions and regulations set forth in this section or to suffer or permit noncompliance with such conditions and regulations on or within the licensed premises. (1975 Code § 18-90) 
4-4A-7: - SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE: 
Nothing in the provisions of this article shall preclude the right of the mayor to suspend or revoke the license of the licensee, as follows: 
A.  The mayor may temporarily suspend any license issued under the terms of this article when he has reason to believe that the continued operation of a particular licensed premises will immediately threaten the welfare of the community or create an imminent danger of violation of applicable law. In such case, he may, upon the issuance of a written order stating the reason for such determination, and without notice or hearing, order the licensed premises closed for not more than seven (7) days; provided, that the licensee shall be given an opportunity to be heard in a public hearing during the seven (7) day period; and further provided, that if such licensee is also engaged in the conduct of other businesses on the licensed premises, such order shall not be applicable to such other businesses. 
B.  The mayor may suspend or revoke any license issued under the terms of this article upon: 1) due notice to the licensee of the time and place of a public hearing; and 2) if the mayor determines upon hearing that the licensee has failed or refused to comply with the terms of this article, has failed or refused to comply with other laws applicable to the business of keeping or providing coin operated amusement devices, or has been convicted by a court of competent jurisdiction of a violation of any provision of this article. (1975 Code § 18-88) 
4-4A-8: - VIOLATIONS; PENALTY: 
A.  Violations: Any person convicted of a violation of this article shall be subject to a fine as provided in the general penalty in section 1-3-1 of this code. (1975 Code § 18-91; amd. 2003 Code) 
B.  Settlement Of Violations: Any person accused of a violation of this article may settle and compromise the claim of violation against him by paying to the city, within ten (10) days of the time such alleged violation or offense was committed, the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each such violation or offense. Consecutive violations of this article shall be treated as separate offenses. Payment of such claim or claims shall be made at the police station of the city, or in the fine/claim deposit boxes located upon the streets of the city. The funds received from such compromised claims shall be promptly turned over to the city treasurer to be credited to the general corporate fund. In the event such claim or claims are not paid within ten (10) days of the time of the alleged offense, a notice to appear or a warrant (summons) may be issued for the arrest of the offender. (1975 Code § 18-92) 
CHAPTER 5 - CABLE COMMUNICATIONS 
The city hereby adopts by reference ordinance 2006-58 and all amendments thereto. The complete ordinance is on file in the city and on the city's web page. 
CHAPTER 5 
CABLE COMMUNICATIONS 
ARTICLE A. - POLE ATTACHMENTS 
SECTION: 

4-5A-1: - ADOPTION OF RECITAL OF FACTS AND PURPOSE: 
The recitals of facts and purpose herein made are hereby adopted by reference as if fully set forth herein. (1975 Code § 81/2-80) 
4-5A-2: - APPLICATION: 
A.  Upon the granting of a franchise under the city's cable television ordinance and prior to making any attachments to any city or joint pole, a grantee shall make application to the city, by and through its superintendent of electrical services, for a permit. The application to be submitted shall be substantially in the form as set forth on exhibit A, on file with the city clerk's office and made a part hereof by reference. In the event any proposed attachment shall be upon a joint pole, grantee also shall make application to Ameritech, its successor and assign, upon an application substantially in the form as set forth at exhibit D, on file with the city clerk's office and made a part hereof by reference and obtain such necessary consents or approvals from the Illinois commerce commission as may be required. 
B.  No attachment shall be made upon any city or joint pole unless grantee has first obtained a permit therefor, and in the case of a joint pole, a permit has been issued by both the city and Ameritech. 
C.  The city reserves unto itself, its successors and assigns, the right to deny an application if in the judgment of the city's superintendent of electrical services any attachment requested would unreasonably or adversely interfere with, or adversely impair, the city's electrical service or operations, including, but not limited to, safety of service or operations, economy of service and operations, infringement upon the rights of existing easements, rights of way or other public utilities. 
D.  All applications shall indicate grantee's specific requested locations of attachments of cables, wires or equipment necessary to accommodate any proposed attachment. Thereafter, the city shall indicate suggested replacements or rearrangements of poles, cables, wires and equipment and shall furnish an estimate of cost for any such replacements, additions, changes or rearrangements needed. Grantee shall pay, in advance and prior to the issuance of the permit, the city's estimated costs for city engineering expenses (including, but limited to, analysis, surveying, inspection of proposed cable routes, or any attendant drawings, specifications or estimates) which may be required for any proposed replacements, changes and rearrangements of the city's or Ameritech's poles and facilities required to accommodate grantee's attachments. In the event the estimates do not meet actual costs, grantee shall pay any difference to the city or receive repayment from the city based on the estimates as the case may be. 
E.  Prior to the issuance of any permit hereunder, grantee shall tender to the city a construction performance bond, with surety acceptable to the city, guaranteeing the complete and satisfactory performance of construction for any costs incurred by the city for the replacement or rearrangement of any city poles, cables, wires and/or equipment. The amount of such bond shall be not less than the city's estimate of cost as hereinabove provided. 
F.  Additionally, and prior to the issuance of any permit or permits, grantee shall furnish to the city a fidelity performance bond in the face amount required under the bond schedule which is on file in the city clerk's office and made a part hereof by reference. The terms of the bond shall provide for the payment of all sums which may at any time become due from grantee to the city, including, but not limited to, rental fees, inspection fees, work performed for the benefit of the grantee, or removal of attachments. The amount of such bond shall be determined based upon the number of city or joint poles to which grantee requests permission for attachment and the form of said bond shall be guaranteed by a surety acceptable to the city. In the event the number of poles utilized by grantee shall exceed the number of poles, city and joint, covered by a bond, grantee shall furnish such additional bond or bonds, with surety, to satisfy the requirements set forth in the aforesaid bond schedule. (1975 Code § 81/2-81) 
4-5A-3: - STANDARD OF CARE: 
A.  Grantee shall, at its own expense, construct and maintain any attachments permitted hereunder in a safe and good workmanlike manner. Such attachments shall at all times be maintained in a safe condition and free from interference with any other use of a city or joint pole. Further, grantee shall pay, in advance, the city's estimated cost for any engineering work required by city for the correction of improper attachments of grantee's facilities, including, but not limited to, preparation of engineering documentation, work orders, drawing for any replacements, changes and rearrangements of the city's poles and facilities or of the facilities of any other person required to accommodate grantee's attachments. Provided, however, grantee shall be permitted to correct, in an expeditious manner, any improper attachments. 
B.  Further, grantee shall erect and maintain its cables, wires and equipment in accordance with the national electrical code, the national electric safety code and Illinois commerce commission general order 160 or any amendments, revisions or successors thereof, as well as any requirements imposed by a governmental agency or body having jurisdiction of this subject matter. 
C.  Further, grantee shall reimburse the city, at the prorata share rate of one-third ( 1/3) expense of trimming trees, bushes and other foliage done by the city or contracted by the city for areas where grantee's attachments or equipment are located however, grantee shall be responsible for its own such trimming at such poles where grantee is initially installing its cable, wires or other facilities. 
D.  Further, grantee, its employees, agents, contractors and subcontractors, shall exercise such care and duty as may be required to fulfill all of the standards set forth in the aforesaid national electric code, national electric safety code or the provisions of Illinois commerce commission general order 160, to avoid damage to facilities of the city and Ameritech, and shall promptly reimburse the city or Ameritech, as the case may be, for any losses incurred in repairing or replacing facilities damaged or destroyed, if such damage or destruction is caused, in whole or in part by, or connected with the presence of such poles of grantee's facilities, or caused, in whole or in part, by, or connected with an act or failure to act on the part of grantee, its agents, employees, contractors or customers. (1975 Code § 81/2-82) 
4-5A-4: - REPLACEMENT, RELOCATION AND REPAIR: 
A.  Upon prior notice from the city or Ameritech, as the case may be, grantee shall at all times, at its sole expense, replace, relocate or renew its facilities, including, but not limited to, cables, conduits, wires, amplifiers, and shall: 
1.  Transfer same to substitute poles; 
2.  Perform any work in connection with such cable facilities as required by the city, in order to satisfy the standard of care set forth at section 4-5A-2 of this article; or 
3.  Reimburse the city or Ameritech, as the case may be, for replacing such poles, as determined by the city or Ameritech, which are inadequate to support any facilities of grantee or which are inadequate to provide required cable or wire clearances. 
However, in the event the city shall determine that its own electrical service or operations require the relocation, replacement, removal or disconnection of any of the grantee's facilities located on city or joint poles, due to an emergency situation, the city may, without notice, relocate, replace, remove or disconnect any of such cable facilities and may transfer such facilities to substitute poles or perform any other work which may be required in the maintenance, replacement, removal or relocation of the poles, the facilities thereon, or as may be otherwise required to meet the city's own electrical service or operational needs. 
B.  If, in the city's judgment, grantee's attachments can be accommodated on existing poles by way of rearrangement of the city's facilities, grantee shall reimburse the city for the cost of such rearrangement. 
C.  In the event that the city or Ameritech shall require the pole space occupied by grantee, and said pole has not been previously replaced for such purposes, then the provisions of section 4-5A-2 of this article shall apply with respect to notification, prior approval and reimbursement of costs, except that grantee may elect to remove its attachments from such pole if it does not approve such replacement pole. 
D.  In the event any such replacement, relocation, repair or work is accomplished by the city under this section, grantee shall reimburse the city for any of its. expenses, including, but not limited to, the cost incurred to replace a pole with extra height or strength for grantee's facilities, and the cost of removal of the former pole. 
E.  Grantee, however, may at any time remove its attachments from any pole or poles of the city, but shall immediately give the city written notice thereof upon the form depicted at Exhibit B, on file with the city clerk's office and made a part hereof by reference. No refund of any rental fee will be due to grantee on account of such removals. 
F.  Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to require or compel the city to maintain or retain any city pole or joint pole for a period longer than is required by the city's own service requirement. (1975 Code § 81/2-83) 
4-5A-5: - STANDARDS FOR CONSTRUCTION: 
In addition to the requirement of section 4-5A-2 of this article, grantee shall meet the following standards of construction for attachment of its cable, wires and equipment: 
A.  Grantee shall adhere to the minimum standards or construction set forth in the drawings marked group exhibit C on file with the city clerk's office and made a part hereof by reference. 
B.  Grantee shall bond at the first, last and every tenth pole of each cable run. 
C.  Each metallic covering of grantee's cable or wire shall be bonded to a city or joint pole's multigrounded neutral system in accordance with the city's instructions. 
D.  In no event shall grantee make cable attachments or such other attachments to a city or joint pole at more than one level without the express written permission of the city, and all such cable or wires shall be attached flush with the pole except where extension arms or other construction is deemed required by the city. 
E.  Any strengthening of poles by means of the use of guy wires in order to accommodate grantee's attachments shall be at grantee's expense. (1975 Code § 81/2-84) 
4-5A-6: - RENTAL PAYMENTS: 
Grantee shall pay to the city, as and for attachments made to city poles and/or joint poles provided under this article, a rental fee of twenty-seven dollars and ninety-nine cents ($27.99) per pole attachment per calendar year, provided that the rental fee shall be adjusted annually by adding an amount equal to three percent (3.0%) thereto. Said rental fee shall be payable biannually, in advance, on or before January 1 and July 1 of each year during which grantee maintains its cable, wires, equipment or other facilities upon such poles. The annual rental fees shall be determined upon the number of city poles for which permits are issued hereunder and which are in effect on December 1 of the year preceding the aforesaid rental period. The first rental period for each attachment after December 1 of any year shall commence on the date of the granting of the permit by the city. If there are more than six (6) months remaining between such date and the following January 1, the rental fee will be twenty dollars and ninety-nine cents ($20.99) per city or joint pole attachment payable at the time the permit hereunder is tendered to grantee; if there is less than six (6) months, the rental fee for such period shall be seven dollars ($7.00). Notwithstanding the annual adjustment in the rental fee set forth above, the city council reserves the right to increase or otherwise modify the rental fee per pole attachment from time to time; provided, however, that such increases or modifications shall not be made unless the city gives written notice to the grantee at least ninety (90) days prior to the effective date of such increases or modifications; and provided further, that no more than one (1) increase in the rental fees shall be made in each calendar year. (1975 Code § 81/2-85; Ord. No. 2012-28, § 1, 8-20-2012) 
4-5A-7: - INDEMNIFICATION AND INSURANCE: 
A.  Except for the city's own negligence, grantee shall indemnify, protect, defend and save harmless the city, its successors, assigns, employees, officials (elected and appointed) and agents from, against and arising out of any and all claims and demands for: 
1.  Damages to property and injury or death to persons, including payments made under any workers' compensation law, or under any plan for employee's disability and death benefits (including, but not limited to, claims and demands which may be asserted by employees, agents, contractors, and subcontractors of grantee); 
2.  Claims or losses from or to grantee's customers for any interruption of service or for interference with grantee's cable, wires or equipment, which may arise out of or be caused by the erection, maintenance, presence, use or removal of grantee's attachments or facilities to city or joint poles, or by reason of the proximity of or contact between such cable, wires, apparatus or appliances of the parties hereto or other users; or 
3.  By reason of any act or omission of grantee, its employees, agents, contractors, subcontractors or customers on or in the area of such city or joint poles, or otherwise arising out of this article, all to the maximum extent permitted by law. 
B.  In all events, grantee shall notify the city immediately of any such damages, injury or death, and shall provide the city with a written report of same, including the names and addresses of persons involved, the date of injury or damage and the location of such incident. The city shall notify, in writing, grantee of any claim or suit against the city which, by the terms of this article, grantee shall be obligated to defend or against which the grantee shall save and keep harmless. Further, the city shall furnish to the grantee all information in its possession relating to any such claim or suit and shall cooperate with the grantee in the defense of each said claim or suit. The city may, if it so desires, assist in defending any such claim or suit, but solely under the direction of the licensee or its attorneys, and the licensee shall not be required to reimburse the city for expenses incurred by it in case of the election so to assist. 
C.  Grantee shall carry policies of insurance with a company or companies authorized to do business in the state of Illinois insuring grantee and the city from and against any and all claims, demands, actions, judgments, costs, expenses and losses of every kind and nature which arise or may arise out of, directly or indirectly, grantee's attachment of its cables, wires, equipment or other facilities to city or joint poles. The amount of such policy or policies insuring against liability due to damage to property shall not be less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00), and against liability or loss due to injury or death of persons the sum of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) as to any one person and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) as to any one accident. Grantee shall also carry such insurance as will protect it from all claims under any workers' compensation law in effect. All policies hereunder shall include endorsements naming the city as an additional insured and all such policies shall remain in full force and effect for the period of grantee's franchise or any renewal period thereof. Grantee shall submit to the city certificates of insurance by each company insuring grantee prior to the commencement of any attachments to any city or joint poles; such certificates shall include an endorsement thereon covenanting that said insurance company will not cancel or modify its policy or policies without first giving the city thirty (30) days' prior written notice. (1975 Code § 81/2-86) 
4-5A-8: - INSPECTIONS: 
The city and Ameritech reserve unto themselves, their respective successors and assigns, the right to inspect each new or existing attachment facility and the vicinity of such facilities. Such inspections may be made at any time and grantee shall reimburse the city the customary expense thereof. Such inspections, whether made or not, shall not operate to relieve grantee from any responsibility, obligation or liability under this article. (1975 Code § 81/2-87) 
4-5A-9: - RIGHTS OF WAY, EASEMENTS AND PUBLIC WAYS: 
A.  Prior to making any attachments to any pole located upon any private property, right of way or easement, grantee shall give notice to such property owner, or his duly authorized agent, of the grantee's intent to attach its facilities upon such pole or poles, and in the event said property owner objects to such attachment, grantee shall not proceed with any construction work or attachments upon any pole or poles, until the dispute is mutually resolved between the grantee and the property owner. Nothing in this article shall be construed or deemed to be a representation or guarantee by the city that the city's right to use any property for public utility purposes is sufficient cause, acquiescence or permission sufficient to permit grantee's use of such poles without the property owner's consent. 
B.  In the event the attachment to or the use of any city pole or joint pole is prohibited by any governmental authority or property owner, the permit issued hereunder for the use of such pole or poles by grantee shall be deemed to be immediately terminated and any cables, wires, equipment or other facilities of grantee shall be removed within thirty (30) days from notice of such prohibition. (1975 Code § 81/2-88) 
4-5A-10: - PROHIBITED ATTACHMENTS: 
In the event grantee makes any attachments to a city or joint pole without first having obtained a permit therefor (or any charges incident thereto), or without paying the rental fees required hereunder, the city or Ameritech, as the case may be, shall have the right to remove such attachments or other incidental equipment, and said city or Ameritech, as the case may be, shall be exculpated by grantee from any liability (except, respectively, the city's or Ameritech's own negligence) therefor and the expense of any such removal shall be paid by grantee within thirty (30) days after receipt of billing from the city or Ameritech, as the case may be. (1975 Code § 81/2-89) 
4-5A-11: - PENALTY: 
A.  In the event grantee shall fail to comply with any of the provisions of this article, or if grantee uses the attachments for any purpose other than cable television service, and grantee fails to cure such failures or deficiencies within thirty (30) days after written notice by the city to correct same, the city may, at its option, terminate the permits issued relating to such city or joint poles to which such default or noncompliance may be related. Further, the remedies provided for in this section shall not be exclusive, but are in addition, but not limited to, all other penalties that may be imposed by the city pursuant to the Illinois municipal code and this code, respectively. However, in the event any grantee has entered into a franchise agreement with the city, subsequent to the date of the original enactment of this article, October 4, 1982, which franchise agreement provides for penalties to be imposed against grantee (franchisee) for failure to comply with city ordinances, including this article, then such penalty provisions in the franchise agreement shall pertain and are hereby adopted by reference as if fully set forth herein. The failure to enforce or insist upon compliance with any of the terms and conditions of this article shall not constitute a waiver or relinquishment of any such terms or conditions, but the same shall be and remain at all such times in full force and effect. 
B.  In addition to the foregoing provisions of this section, all statements for rental fees, inspection fees, and any other charges made by the city under this article shall be payable within thirty (30) days after presentation. Nonpayment of such statements within said period shall constitute a default under this section. (1975 Code § 81/2-90) 
4-5A-12: - ASSIGNMENT: 
Grantee shall not assign, sell or transfer any permits issued hereunder without first obtaining the written consent of the city and/or Ameritech. (1975 Code § 81/2-91) 
4-5A-13: - LIMITATION ON USE: 
A.  Nothing contained in this article shall be construed as limiting the rights and privileges held by the city to use any city pole or joint pole and the city shall have the right to continue and extend those rights and privileges pertaining thereto. Further, the granting of a permit for the use of a city or joint pole to the grantee shall not create or vest in grantee any ownership or property rights in said poles, but grantee's rights herein shall be construed as a license therefor. Nothing herein contained shall be construed as affecting the rights of the city to make other and additional contracts with other persons, firms, corporations or associations for the joint use of any pole or facilities. 
B.  Upon the termination of any permit hereunder, grantee shall immediately remove its cable, wires and equipment from all poles of the city or any joint poles affected by such termination, not later than sixty (60) days after said termination. However, upon the termination of all permits hereunder, grantee shall remove its cable, wires and equipment from all poles, not later than two hundred ten (210) days from notice of said termination by the city. If not so removed, the city shall have the right to remove said wires, cable and equipment and/or attachments at the sole customary cost of grantee and without any liability therefor by the city. (1975 Code § 81/2-92) 
4-5A-14: - AMENDMENTS: 
This article shall become effective from and after its passage as in accordance with law. The city council reserves unto itself, its successors and assigns, the right to amend the provision for increases or modifications of the rental fees under section 4-5A-6 of this article, modifications of the standards of care provisions under section 4-5A-3 of this article in the manner prescribed by the statutes of the state of Illinois, or as provided herein, and reasonable modifications of the construction standard provisions under section 4-5A-5 of this article as such shall apply to all parties attaching to city (owner) poles. (1975 Code § 81/2-93) 
4-5A-15: - NOTICES: 
Any notice required to be given to the city shall be sent by first class mail, postage prepaid, to: 
City of Geneva Electric Department 
Attn: Superintendent of Electrical Services 
22 South First Street 
Geneva, IL 60134 
AT&T Broadband 
2001 York Road, Suite 200 
Oak Brook, IL 60523 
(1975 Code § 81/2-94; amd. 2003 Code) 
CHAPTER 6 - FOOD AND FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS 
SECTION: 

4-6-1: - DEFINITIONS: 
As used in this chapter: 
FOOD: Includes beverages. FOOD DEALER: Includes every person engaged in the sale of unprepared or packaged food or beverage, other than intoxicating liquor, intended for human consumption off the premises. (1975 Code § 15-1)  
4-6-2: - LICENSE PROVISIONS: 
A.  Required; Application: It shall be unlawful for any food dealer to engage in or do business in the city without first having secured a license therefor. Applications for such licenses shall be made in compliance with the general provisions of this code relating thereto [8] and shall state the kind of food intended to be sold or handled. (1975 Code § 15-2) 
B.  Fees: The annual license fee for a license required by subsection 4-6-2A of this section shall be in accordance with the following schedule: 
For the sale of unprepared or packaged food or beverage other than alcoholic liquor intended for human consumption, over the counter $50.00 For the sale of unprepared or packaged food, beverage other than alcoholic liquor, or tobacco intended for human consumption, to be sold from vending machines 50.00 For the sale of unprepared or packaged food, beverage other than alcoholic liquor, or tobacco intended for human consumption, to be sold from vending truck or vehicle, per vehicle 500.00 (1975 Code § 15-3; amd. 2003 Code)  
C.  Revocation: Any food dealer's license may be revoked by the mayor and city council for repeated violations of the provisions of this chapter or for any violation of any other provision of this code or ordinances of the city relating to the conduct of such business, the condition of the premises, the articles sold or to the license required. 
(1975 Code § 15-4) 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
See chapter 1 of this title. 

4-6-3: - SANITARY CONDITIONS: 
A.  Maintenance Of Food Establishments: Premises used for the sale or storage of food intended for human consumption must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. It shall be unlawful to permit any accumulation of refuse or waste of any kind to remain therein for more than twenty four (24) hours, and it shall be unlawful to permit any decaying animal or plant material to remain on such premises. No dogs, cats or other animals, except for guide or hearing dogs under the control of a handicapped person, shall be permitted on such premises. (1975 Code § 15-7) 
B.  Unwholesome Foods: No person shall offer for sale or keep for the purpose of selling or offering for sale, any food of any kind intended for human consumption which is spoiled or tainted or is unwholesome and unfit for human consumption for any reason. 
(1975 Code § 15-5) 
C.  Adulterated Foods: It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale, or keep for such purpose, any food or drink intended for human consumption which has been adulterated by any material harmful in any way, or which does not comply with the statutes governing the same. (1975 Code § 15-6) 
D.  Flies And Vermin Prohibited: Premises used for the storage, preparation or sale of food intended for human consumption shall be kept free from flies, vermin and rodents. (1975 Code § 15-8) 
E.  Food Handlers: 
1.  All persons engaged in handling or coming in contact with food intended for sale for human consumption shall keep themselves clean, both as to person and clothing. 
2.  It shall be unlawful for any person who is afflicted with or is a carrier of any infectious or contagious disease to handle or be engaged in the care of or preparation of food, and it shall be unlawful to permit any such person to be employed in or about any premises where food is stored, prepared or sold, or to deliver such food. (1975 Code § 15-9) 
4-6-4: - RESTAURANTS: 
A.  Definitions: The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this section: 
EMPLOYEE: Any person who handles food or drink during preparation or serving or who comes in contact with any eating or cooking utensils. FOOD: All articles used for food, drinks, confectionery or condiments, whether simple, mixed or compound, and all substances or ingredients used in the preparation thereof. ITINERANT 
RESTAURANT: A restaurant operating for a temporary period in connection with a fair, carnival, circus, public picnic or public exhibition. RESTAURANT: Any restaurant, coffeeshop, cafeteria, short order cafe, luncheonette, tavern, sandwich stand, drugstore and soda fountain serving food, and all other eating or drinking establishments, as well as kitchens or other places including bakeries in which food or drinks are prepared for sale elsewhere. SANITARIAN: The Kane County department of health. UTENSILS: Any kitchenware, tableware, glassware, cutlery, utensils, containers or other equipment with which food or drinks come in contact during storage, preparation or serving. (1975 Code § 15-21; amd. 2003 Code)  
B.  License Requirements: 
1.  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a restaurant in the city who does not possess an unrevoked license from the sanitarian, which license shall be posted in a conspicuous place. Only persons who comply with the requirements of this section shall be entitled to receive and retain such a license. A person conducting an itinerant restaurant shall also be required to secure a license, except as hereinafter provided. 
2.  Every applicant for a license to operate a restaurant shall pay to the city administrator a fee or fees for each such establishment in accordance with the following schedule: 
Restaurants, annually $50.00 Itinerant restaurants, daily or as provided 6.00 Total fee not to exceed for any one continuous operation 30.00  
A restaurant license issued under this section includes the right to sell milk at retail without an additional fee. (1975 Code § 15-22; amd. 2003 Code) 
C.  Contagious Disease Control: 
1.  No person while affected with a disease in a communicable form or while a carrier of such disease or while afflicted with boils, infected wounds or acute respiratory infection, shall work in a restaurant in an area and capacity in which there is likelihood of transmission of disease to patrons or to fellow employees, either through direct contact or through the contamination of food or food contact surfaces with pathogenic organisms. No such person shall be employed in such an area and capacity in a restaurant. 
2.  If the restaurant manager suspects or should reasonably suspect that any employee has contracted any disease in a communicable form or has become a carrier of such disease, he shall immediately notify the state of Illinois department of public health. 
3.  All employees shall thoroughly wash their hands and arms with soap and warm water before starting work, and shall wash hands during work hours as often as may be required to remove soil and contamination. 
4.  Hand washing signs shall be posted in each toilet room used by employees. 
5.  Hairnets, headbands, caps or other effective hair restraints shall be used by employees engaged in the preparation and service of food to keep hair from food and food contact surfaces. (1975 Code § 15-29) 
D.  Building Construction, Reconstruction And Alteration: All restaurants which are hereafter constructed, reconstructed or extensively altered shall conform in their construction to the requirements of this section for grade A restaurants. Properly prepared plans for all restaurants which are hereafter constructed, reconstructed or extensively altered shall be submitted to the building commissioner for approval before work is begun. (1975 Code § 15-31) 
4-6-5: - BAKERIES: 
A.  Definition: A "bakery" is any place where bread, pastries, etc., are baked and sold at retail. (1975 Code § 15-40) 
B.  License Requirements: 
1.  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a bakery in the city that does not possess an unrevoked license from the sanitarian, which license shall be posted in a conspicuous place. Only persons who comply with the requirements of this article shall be entitled to receive and retain such a license. 
2.  Every applicant for a license to operate a bakery shall pay to the city administrator an annual fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each such establishment. (1975 Code § 15-41) 
CHAPTER 6 
FOOD AND FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS 
ARTICLE A. - SIDEWALK CAFES 
SECTION: 

4-6A-1: - PERMIT REQUIRED; APPLICATION AND FEE: 
A.  Permit Required: Notwithstanding any other provision in this code, it is unlawful for any person to use the public sidewalk for any commercial purpose of any kind without obtaining a permit. Permits will be issued only to licensed restaurant businesses and owning or leasing property immediately adjacent to the sidewalk. Such permits may be purchased at any time during a calendar year but all permits shall expire on December 31 of the same calendar year. No permit shall be issued to any business which is not in compliance with all provisions of this code. (1975 Code § 18-181) 
B.  Application: All applicants for sidewalk cafe permits must complete an application in a form approved by the city and submitted to the building commissioner. All applications shall include the following information: 
1.  A dimensioned plan drawn to scale and done in a professional manner showing the sidewalk and all public improvements such as light posts, benches, planters, trees and tree grates in the area, location of the curb relative to the building, and the proposed location of all care furniture, furniture described by height, color and type of materials, to be placed on the sidewalk. 
2.  Certificate of insurance naming the city as an additional insured with a minimum coverage of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00). 
3.  A signed indemnification statement on a form provided by the city. 
4.  Furniture items (sometimes referred to herein as "items") may include the following: tables, chairs, benches, trash receptacles, ashtrays, planters or other articles of a character, nature, material and color conducive to an attractive outdoor care atmosphere as determined by the building commissioner. An application denied by the building commissioner may be appealed to the city council. (1975 Code § 18-182) 
C.  Fee: The fee for a permit for a sidewalk cafe shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00). (1975 Code § 18-186) 
4-6A-2: - INSPECTIONS: 
An inspection of the property to document existing conditions of public improvements shall be performed by the city prior to issuance of a permit. Applications should be filed at least two (2) weeks prior to scheduled use to allow sufficient time for such inspection. (1975 Code § 18-183) 
4-6A-3: - REGULATIONS: 
All permit holders shall be subject to the following regulations: 
A.  Items on the sidewalk shall at all times be placed in accordance with the approved plan. 
B.  The sidewalk shall be kept clean and free of refuse and clutter at all times by the permit holder regardless of the source of such refuse and clutter, including, but not limited to, overflowing trash receptacles (private or public), cigarette and paper refuse. 
C.  All items shall be removed from the sidewalk and placed indoors at the end of each business day. 
D.  All public improvements on the sidewalk including, but not limited to, benches, light poles and trees shall be maintained in the condition in which they existed immediately prior to the issuance of the permit, excluding normal wear and tear. Permit holder shall immediately report any damage to such improvements to the director of public works. The city shall repair or replace such improvement at its discretion and shall charge the cost of repair or replacement to the permit holder unless the damage can be clearly shown to have resulted from a cause not related to the issuance of the sidewalk use permit. 
E.  Operations of the sidewalk cafe shall be conducted in a manner that does not interfere with pedestrians, parking or traffic. 
F.  The area and materials must be maintained and in good condition at all times. Broken, rusting, torn or tattered furnishings shall be removed promptly. 
G.  The permit shall be posted in a conspicuous place inside the business so as to be visible from an adjacent window. (1975 Code § 18-184) 
4-6A-4: - RESTRICTIONS: 
A.  Items shall be placed so that a five foot (5') wide unobstructed pedestrian walkway is maintained at all times; clearances will be maintained when any chair is pulled out from a table, particularly where chair backs face the street or pedestrian walkway. 
B.  A five foot (5') clear zone shall be maintained at corner locations of two (2) public sidewalks. No item shall be placed within five feet (5') of the corner of the building on either side. 
C.  Items shall be immediately adjacent to the building and shall not extend beyond the permit holder's storefront on any side. 
D.  Items shall not obstruct normal ingress and egress from the business or from other businesses. 
E.  Items shall be at least twenty inches (20") in height and tables shall not exceed twenty two inches (22") in diameter, and shall be of a design and/or weight that will not create a windblown hazard. 
F.  Umbrellas shall be prohibited as intrusionary and may pose a health risk to pedestrians or break free on windy days. 
G.  The consumption of alcoholic beverages in the area shall be prohibited. The proprietor shall be responsible for monitoring this provision. 
H.  Hours of outdoor operation shall coincide with the hours of operation of the principal establishment. 
I.  Tables and chairs must be removed during Swedish Days Festival due to the volume of pedestrian traffic and other uses on the public sidewalks. 
J.  Amplified music and music speakers shall be prohibited for the area. (1975 Code § 18-185) 
4-6A-5: - ENFORCEMENT: 
A.  Failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall result in a fine of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each day on which the violation occurs or continues to occur and revocation of the permit. 
B.  The prohibition on consumption of alcoholic beverages within the area, as provided in subsection 4-6A-4G of this chapter, shall be the responsibility of the permit holder. Two (2) violations of this provision shall result in the immediate revocation of the permit and permit holder shall be prohibited from reapplication for a period of twelve (12) months. Violations of subsection 4-6A-4G of this chapter shall be subject to review by the local liquor control commissioner. 
C.  The enforcement of all other sections of this chapter, including, but not limited to, the maintenance provisions and restrictions, shall be the responsibility of the permit holder. Any three (3) violations of the provisions shall result in the revocation of the permit and permit holder shall be prohibited from reapplication for a period of twelve (12) months. (1975 Code § 18-187; amd. 2003 Code) 
CHAPTER 7 - SALES 
SECTION: 

4-7-1: - FINDINGS AND DECLARATIONS: 
It is hereby found and declared by the city council: 
A.  That sales to be licensed and regulated pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, and pursuant to the fraudulent sales act, [9] have often been conducted and advertised in such a manner as to mislead and defraud the public and otherwise to result in harm to the public interest; 
B.  That such fraud and imposition on the public has included, by way of partial enumeration only, the misrepresentation of the condition or the necessity which is the occasion of such sale; the misrepresentation of the identity of the person conducting such sale and/or the name and style in which such sale is to be conducted; and the excessive valuation and misrepresentation of the quality and ownership of goods to be sold at such sale; 
C.  That in order to prevent such fraud and imposition, the public interest requires the regulation of such sales of the duration and conduct thereof; and 
D.  That the public interest therefore requires that no such sale should be conducted without a license as provided in this chapter. (1975 Code § 18-140) 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
815 ILCS 350/1 et seq. 

4-7-2: - DEFINITIONS: 
For the purposes of this chapter, unless the context or subject matter otherwise requires, the following terms and words shall have the meanings set out by this section: 
GOING OUT OF 
BUSINESS SALE: Any sale, whether described by such name or by any other name (such as, but not limited to, "closing out sale", "liquidation sale", "lost our lease sale" or "forced to vacate sale"), held in such a manner as to induce a belief that upon disposal of the stock of goods on hand the business will cease and be discontinued at the premises where the sale is conducted. GOODS: Includes all goods, wares, merchandise and other personal property, excepting those in action and money. PERSON: A person, firm, partnership, association or two (2) or more persons having a joint or common interest. REMOVAL SALE: Any sale held in such a manner as to induce a belief that upon disposal of the stock of goods on hand the business will cease and be discontinued at the premises where the sale is conducted, and thereafter will be moved to and occupy another location. (1975 Code § 18-141)  
4-7-3: - LICENSE REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS AND FEE: 
A.  License Required: No person shall directly or indirectly advertise or cause to be advertised, represent or cause to be represented, or hold out to the public in any manner that any sale of goods is an insurance, salvage, removal, going out of business, insolvent's, assignee's, or creditor's sale of goods, or that it is a sale of goods which have been damaged by fire, smoke, water or otherwise, unless such person shall first have obtained a license to conduct such sale under one of such descriptive names from the city clerk, if such sale is to be conducted within the corporate limits of the city. 
B.  Exceptions: This chapter shall not apply to any sales directly ordered by any court or trustee in bankruptcy, or to any person acting under the direction and supervision of state or federal courts in the course of their official duties; provided, further, that this chapter shall not apply to any sales by a person regularly engaged in insurance or salvage sales of goods, or sales of goods which have been damaged by fire, smoke, water or otherwise, who acquired the goods for the account of others as a result of fire or other casualty. (1975 Code § 18-142) 
C.  Fee: A fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) shall accompany an application for a license and for the renewal of a license. (1975 Code § 18-145) 
4-7-4: - APPLICATION FOR LICENSE: 
Any applicant for a license under this chapter shall file an application in writing and under oath with the city clerk setting out the following facts and information regarding such a proposed sale: 
A.  The name and address of the applicant for the license, who must be the owner of the goods to be sold; and in addition, if the applicant is a partnership, corporation, firm or association, the name and position of the individual filing such application. 
B.  The name and style in which such sale is to be conducted, and the address where such sale is to be conducted. 
C.  The dates and period of time during which the sale is to be conducted. 
D.  The name and address of the person or persons who will be in charge of and responsible for the conduct of such sale. 
E.  A full explanation with regard to the condition or necessity which is the occasion for such sale, including a statement of the descriptive name of the sale and the reasons why such name is truthfully descriptive of the sale. If the application is for a license to conduct a going out of business sale, it shall also contain a statement that the business will be discontinued at the premises where the sale is to be conducted upon termination of the sale. If the application is for a license to conduct a removal sale, it shall also contain a statement that the business will be discontinued at the premises where the sale is to be conducted upon the termination of the sale, in addition to the location of the premises to which the business is to be moved. If the application is for a license to conduct a sale of goods damaged by fire, smoke, water or otherwise, it shall also contain a statement as to the time, location and cause of such damage. 
F.  A full, detailed and complete inventory of the goods that are to be sold, which inventory shall: 
1.  Itemize the goods to be sold and contain sufficient information concerning each item, including make and brand name, if any, to clearly identify it; 
2.  List separately any goods which were purchased during a sixty (60) day period immediately prior to the date of making application for the license; and 
3.  Show the cost price of each item in the inventory together with name and address of the seller of the item to the applicant, the date of purchase, the date of delivery of each item to the applicant and the total value of the inventory at cost. 
G.  A statement that no goods will be added to the inventory after the application is made or during the sale and that the inventory contains no goods received on consignment. 
H.  A statement that the applicant has in the past maintained a place of business within the corporate limits of the city for not less than four (4) months prior to the time of making application for such license. However, this subsection shall not apply to any applicant who acquired a right, title or interest in the goods as an heir, devisee, legatee or surviving joint tenant, or an executor, administrator, trustee, guardian or conservator, or pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
I.  The application for license shall be subscribed and sworn to under the oath by the applicant and shall, directly above the space reserved for the signature of the applicant, contain the following legend: 
WARNING TO APPLICANT 
This application must be fully and accurately completed. False or misleading statements may subject applicant to the penalties of perjury in addition to other penalties provided by law. 
(1975 Code § 18-143; amd. 2003 Code) 
4-7-5: - ISSUANCE OF LICENSE: 
A.  Upon receipt of an application giving fully and completely the information under oath as required by the section 4-7-4 of this chapter and upon receipt of the fee herein provided for, the city clerk shall issue a license to the applicant therefor, authorizing such applicant to advertise, represent, and to sell the particular goods so inventoried at the time and place stated in the application and in accordance with this chapter. A license issued under this chapter shall be granted and valid only for the sale of the inventoried goods which are the property of the licensee. Such license shall only apply to the premises specified in the application, and it may not be transferred or assigned. If a licensee under this chapter is engaged in business in other locations, advertising or offering of goods on behalf of such locations shall not represent or imply any participation in or cooperation with the sale on the premises specified in the license, nor shall any advertising or any other offering of goods on behalf of the premises where the licensed sale is being conducted represent or imply any participation in or cooperation with such sale at other locations. 
B.  No license under this chapter shall be issued to any person: 
1.  To conduct a sale in the trade name or style of a person in whose goods the applicant for the license has acquired a right or title to within six (6) months prior to the time of making application for such license; 
2.  To continue a sale in the name of licensee under this chapter whose goods such person acquired a right or title which such a sale is in progress; or 
3.  To conduct a sale, other than an insurance sale, a salvage sale or a sale of damaged goods, on the same premises within one year from the conclusion of a prior sale of the nature covered by this chapter. 
C.  The previous subsection, including subsections B1, B2 and B3 of this section, shall not apply to any person who acquired a right, title or interest in goods as an heir, devisee or legatee, or pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction. (1975 Code § 18-144) 
4-7-6: - CONDITIONS OF LICENSE: 
A.  Duration Of Sale: A license to conduct a sale pursuant to this chapter shall not be issued or valid for a period of more than sixty (60) days from the start of such sale, and such sale may be conducted only during the period set forth in such license; provided, however, that such license may be renewed once only for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days upon affidavit of the licensee that the goods listed in the inventory have not been disposed of and that no new goods have been or will be added to the inventory previously filed pursuant to this chapter by purchase, acquisition on consignment, or otherwise. Any application for renewal of the license shall be made not more than fourteen (14) days prior to the time of the expiration of the license and shall contain a new inventory of goods remaining on hand at the time of the application for renewal is made, which new inventory shall be prepared and furnished in the same manner and form as the original inventory. No renewal shall be granted if any goods have been added to the stock listed in the inventory since the date of the issuance of the license. (1975 Code § 18-145) 
B.  Post License: All licensees hereunder shall post a copy of the application for a license and the inventory filed therewith in a conspicuous place in the sales room or place where the inventoried goods are to be sold; provided, however, that such copy of the inventory need not show the purchase price of the goods. In addition, the licensee shall attach to the front door of the premises where the sale is conducted a duplicate copy of the license issued hereunder, said duplicate copy being clearly visible from the street. It should further be the duty of the licensee, when any advertisement or announcement is published in connection with the sale, to conspicuously show on the face of such advertisement or announcement the number of the license and the date of its expiration. (1975 Code § 18-146) 
C.  Substitution, Addition And Commingling Of Goods: Any substitution for or addition to goods described in an inventory filed pursuant to this chapter, or any change in the time or place for a sale conducted pursuant to this chapter, shall be unlawful and shall void any license issued to conduct a sale pursuant to this chapter, and such license shall cease to apply to such sale. In the case of a sale of goods damaged by fire, smoke, water or otherwise, or in the case of an insurance sale or a salvage sale, the goods to be sold at such sale shall be clearly and distinctly segregated, marked or identified, and advertised, if at all, so that both on display and in advertising such goods may be readily distinguished from other stocks, and their identity readily ascertained. Any commingling of such goods with other stocks of the licensee in such a manner to cause the goods to lose their separate identity, either on display or in advertising, shall be unlawful and shall void any license issued to conduct such sale pursuant to this chapter, and such license shall cease to apply to such sale. 
D.  Purchases Prohibited: No person in contemplation of conducting any going out of business, removal, assignee's or creditor's sale, or during the continuation of such a sale, shall order or purchase any goods for the purpose of selling them at such sale, and any unusual purchase, or additions to the stock of any such goods within sixty (60) days before the filing of such application for a license to conduct such sale, shall be presumptive evidence that such purchases or additions were made in contemplation of such sale and for the purpose of selling them at such sale. (1975 Code § 18-147) 
4-7-7: - VIOLATIONS; PENALTY: 
A.  Penalty: Any person, including both the applicant and an individual filing on behalf of an applicant, who shall procure from the city clerk a license to conduct a sale under the descriptions of one of the names set forth in section 4-7-4 of this chapter, which name shall be a misrepresentation of the true description or character of such sale or of the kind or condition of goods to be sold under such license, or any such person violating any of the other provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a violation as provided in the general penalty in section 1-3-1 of this code. Each false statement of fact in an application or inventory required to be filed hereunder shall constitute a separate offense under this chapter. (1975 Code § 18-148; amd. 2003 Code) 
B.  Settlement Of Violations: Any person accused of a violation of this chapter may settle and compromise the claim of violation against him by paying to the city, within ten (10) days of the time such alleged violation or offense was committed, the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each such violation or offense. Consecutive violations of this chapter shall be treated as separate offenses. Payment of such claim or claims shall be made at the police station of the city, or in the fine/claim deposit boxes located upon the streets of the city. The funds received from such compromised claims shall be promptly turned over to the city treasurer to be credited to the general corporate fund. In the event such claim or claims are not paid within ten (10) days of the time of the alleged offense, a notice to appear or a warrant (summons) may be issued for the arrest of the offender. (1975 Code § 18-149) 
CHAPTER 8 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS 
SECTION: 

4-8-1: - DEFINITIONS: 
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words shall be construed to have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
PEDDLER: Every person who shall sell or offer for sale, barter or exchange any goods, wares, merchandise or other commodities of any type. RESIDENCE: Every separate living unit occupied for residential purposes by one or more persons, contained within any type of building or structure. SOLICITING: Any one or more of the following activities:  
A.  Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs or services of any kind, character or description for any kind of consideration; 
B.  Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase of insurance of any type, kind or character; 
C.  Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals, newspapers and every other type or kind of publication; or 
D.  Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any other valuable thing for the support or benefit of any charitable or nonprofit association, organization, corporation or project. (1975 Code § 18-52; amd. Ord. 89-80, 11-6-1989) 
4-8-2: - STATEMENT OF CITY POLICY: 
It is hereby declared to be the policy of the governing body of this city that the occupants of the residences in this city shall make the determination of whether peddlers or solicitors shall be or shall not be invited to their respective residences. (1975 Code § 18-53; amd. Ord. 89-80, 11-6-1989) 
4-8-3: - NOTICE REGARDING SOLICITING: 
Every person desiring to secure the protection intended to be provided by the regulations pertaining to peddling or soliciting contained in this chapter shall comply with the following directions: 
A.  Notice Posted: Notice of the determination by the occupant of giving invitation to peddlers or solicitors, or the refusal of invitation to peddlers or solicitors, to any residence shall be given in the following manner: a weatherproof card, approximately three inches by four inches (3" × 4") in size, shall be exhibited upon or near the main entrance door to the residence, indicating the determination by the occupant, containing applicable words as follows: 
NO PEDDLERS OR SOLICITORS INVITED 
The letters shall be at least one-third inch ( 1/3 ") in height. For the purpose of uniformity the cards shall be provided by the city administrator to persons requesting them at the cost thereof. Such card so exhibited shall constitute sufficient notice to any solicitor of the determination by the occupant of the residence of the information contained thereon. (1975 Code § 18-54; amd. Ord. 89-80, 11-6-1989) 
B.  Duty Of Peddlers Or Solicitors: It shall be the duty of every peddler or solicitor, upon going onto any premises in the city upon which a residence is located, to first examine the notice provided for in subsection A of this section, if any is attached, and be governed by the statement contained in the notice. If the notice states NO PEDDLERS OR SOLICITORS INVITED, or such similar words, then the peddler or solicitor, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises. Any peddler or solicitor who has gained entrance to any residence, whether invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when requested to do so by the occupant. (Ord. 89-80, 11-6-1989) 
4-8-4: - TIME LIMITS ON SOLICITING: 
It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person, whether registered under this chapter or not, to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door of a residence located thereon, or rap or knock upon any door or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof to engage in peddling or soliciting prior to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. or after nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and on any Sunday or holiday. (1975 Code § 18-57; amd. 2003 Code) 
4-8-5: - UNINVITED PEDDLING OR SOLICITING PROHIBITED: 
A.  Unlawful: It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof to engage in peddling or soliciting in defiance of the notice exhibited at the residence in accordance with the provisions of subsection 4-8-3A of this chapter. 
B.  Penalty: Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a petty offense. Except for the offenses in this section, upon conviction of such offense a person shall be fined in an amount as provided in the general penalty in section 1-3-1 of this code, and each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be deemed punishable as such hereunder. Any person violating this section shall be deemed guilty of a petty offense and upon conviction thereof shall be fined as follows: 
First violation $50.00 Second violation within 72 hours of a first violation 100.00 Third violation within 72 hours of a first violation 200.00 Fourth violation within 72 hours of a first violation 400.00 Subsequent violations within 72 hours of the first violation Subject to a complaint for a permanent injunction (Ord. 2006-56, 10-2-2006)  
CHAPTER 9 - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS AND ITINERANT VENDORS 
SECTION: 

4-9-1: - DEFINITIONS: 
For purposes of this chapter, the words and terms defined in this section shall have the following meanings: 
ITINERANT 
VENDORS: Any person who transports tangible personal property for retail sale within the city who does not maintain in this city an established office, distribution house, in-sales house, warehouse, service center or residence from which such business is conducted. However, this chapter does not apply to any person who delivers tangible personal property within this city who is fulfilling an order for such property which was solicited or placed by mail or other means. This chapter also does not apply to any person holding a valid license, issued by the city, to engage in retail sales. TRANSIENT 
MERCHANT: Any person who is engaged temporarily in the retail sales of goods, wares or merchandise in the city and who, for the purpose of conducting such business, occupies any building, room, vehicle, structure of any kind, or vacant lot. However, this chapter does not apply to any person selling goods, wares or merchandise which are raised, produced or manufactured by him; to any person selling vegetables, fruits or perishable farm products at any established city market; to any person operating a store or refreshment stand at a resort; to any person operating a stand or booth on or adjacent to property owned by him or upon which he resides. This chapter does not apply to any person holding a valid license, issued by the city, to engage in retail sales. (1975 Code § 18-160)  
4-9-2: - PREREQUISITES TO CONDUCTING BUSINESS: 
A.  Compliance Requirements: It is a violation of this chapter for any person, either as a principal or agent, to conduct business as a transient merchant or itinerant vendor in this city without first: 
1.  Complying with the requirements of section 2a of the retailers' occupation tax act [10] by obtaining a certificate of registration and by posting bond or other approved security; and 
2.  Complying with all regulations of the zoning district under the zoning ordinance; [11] and 
3.  Having obtained a license under this chapter. (1975 Code § 18-161) 
B.  Prima Facie Evidence: It shall be prima facie evidence that a person is a transient merchant or itinerant vendor under this chapter if the person does not transact business from a fixed location or if the person does not own, or lease for a term of at least six (6) months, the property from which business is conducted. (1975 Code § 18-164) 
Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
35 ILCS 120/2a. 

--- (11) --- 
See title 11 of this code. 

4-9-3: - LICENSE REQUIREMENTS: 
A.  Required: Any person who wishes to obtain a license as a transient merchant or itinerant vendor shall file a written license application with the police department of the city, which department is designated as the licensing agency. 
B.  Application: A completed license application must be submitted to the licensing agency not less than thirty (30) days prior to the requested date to commence sales hereunder. 
C.
