D.  The city will accept applications for a pedicab operator business license(s) at any time of the year if pedicab operator business licenses are available. The administrator will collect all required information and submit a recommendation to issue the license to the city council for approval if all requirements are met. The administrator is authorized to reissue pedicab operator business license(s), after the initial approval by city council, on an annual basis. 
E.  No pedicab operator business license holder shall assign his or her license to another. 
F.  A copy of the pedicab operator business license shall be displayed in each pedicab. 
(Ord. No. 2011-53, § 1, 11-21-2011) 
4-18-5: - FEES: 
A.  The annual fees authorized under the provisions of this chapter include: 
1.  Pedicab Operator Business License: One hundred dollars ($100.00). 
2.  Pedicab Permit Per Pedicab: Twenty dollars ($20.00). 
(Ord. No. 2011-53, § 1, 11-21-2011) 
4-18-6: - DRIVER REQUIREMENTS: 
A.  Pedicab drivers shall hold a valid state driver's license which will be maintained on file with the application in the city administrator's office. 
B.  Operators and drivers must be at least eighteen (18) years of age. 
(Ord. No. 2011-53, § 1, 11-21-2011) 
4-18-7: - PUBLIC PASSENGER SERVICES: 
A.  Each pedicab shall clearly post the rates within the pedicab. 
B.  Every pedicab shall clearly post the pedicab company's name and telephone number. 
(Ord. No. 2011-53, § 1, 11-21-2011) 
4-18-8: - PEDICABS AND EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS: 
A.  Every pedicab providing public must display the pedicab permit issued by the city. 
B.  Every pedicab shall: 
1.  For safety reasons, permissible pedicabs shall be a bicycle with a singular unarticulated frame that is directly attached to a passenger cab. Trailer-type pedicabs, best described as a passenger cab connected to a normal bicycle via a tow bar often attached to the driver's seat riser bar, are not allowed. 
2.  Pedicabs shall have hydraulic disc brake systems for the rear wheels. 
3.  Be maintained to assure that it is mechanically dependable, clean, and safe. 
4.  Have a battery-operated headlight capable of projecting a beam of white light for a distance of five hundred (500) feet shall be permanently affixed to the pedicab. Such lights may be removable and recharged. 
5.  Have taillights permanently affixed on the right and the left at the same level on the rear exterior of the passenger compartment. Taillights shall be red in color and plainly visible from all distances within five hundred (500) feet to the rear of the pedicab. Such light may be removable and recharged. 
6.  Have turn signal indicators. 
7.  Provide a seat belt for every passenger. 
8.  Be designed and manufactured so every passenger may enter and exit without crossing any interior barriers. 
9.  Each pedicab may have one two-foot by three-foot area for advertising or other signage purposes. 
10.  Pedicabs will be inspected each year at the time of issuance of the annual pedicab operator business license and pedicabs to ensure compliance with the terms of the ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2011-53, § 1, 11-21-2011) 
4-18-9: - GENERAL OPERATION: 
A.  All pedicabs shall be operated in a safe manner and in conformity with the regulations of this chapter and all other city traffic and parking regulations. 
B.  All pedicabs shall operate according to the provisions in this chapter, the applicable provisions of city code governing the operation of bicycles, and all other applicable state and laws. No pedicab shall be operated in weather conditions that pose an unreasonable safety risk to the drivers or passengers of the pedicab, or to other motorists or pedestrians. 
C.  For the purposes of immediately loading or unloading passengers, a pedicab may remain standing upon a street if the pedicab is in any legal parking stall, designated loading zone or any other location that does not impede pedestrian or vehicular traffic. Otherwise, a pedicab may not be left parked or standing in specifically designated spaces, such as those for taxis, buses, handicapped drivers, and the like. The city manager or his/her designee may set forth specific additional locations where pedicabs are allowed to park or stand. No pedicab, while in operation for the solicitation or transportation of passengers, shall be left unattended by the pedicab driver for a period of more than fifteen (15) minutes at a time unless parked in one of those specific locations identified by the city. 
D.  Pedicab drivers may not provide passenger service on major or minor arterial roadways within the city. Pedicabs are prohibited to operate for business on arterial roadways, but may cross them from intersecting streets. Prohibited streets include state and county roadways (IL Route 25, IL Route 31, IL Route 38, Randall Road, Kirk Road, Fabyan Parkway, Keslinger Road), though the cabs may cross these roads at intersections, except for designated bike routes. 
(Ord. No. 2011-53, § 1, 11-21-2011) 
4-18-10: - ACCIDENTS: 
A.  A pedicab driver shall immediately report to the city police department any accident or collision in which he or she is involved while operating a pedicab, which results in property damage or personal injury of any kind, to the owner of the pedicab involved in the accident or collision. 
B.  A pedicab owner whose pedicab is involved in an accident or collision resulting in property damage or personal injury of any kind shall within forty-eight (48) hours of being informed of the accident or collision give a written report thereof to the pedicab business operator and the city police department. 
(Ord. No. 2011-53, § 1, 11-21-2011) 
4-18-11: - PENALTIES: 
A.  Any person found to have violated a provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Fines may be imposed in addition to any other action authorized under this chapter. 
B.  Any violation of the restrictions and conditions contained herein may result in the revocation of the license by the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. 2011-53, § 1, 11-21-2011) 
CHAPTER 19 - HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGE REGULATIONS[17] 
SECTION: 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, adopted March 4, 2013, amended chapter 19 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, chapter 19, §§ 4-19-1-4-19-5, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 2012-20, § 1, adopted June 4, 2012. 

4-19-1: - DEFINITIONS: 
For the purpose of this chapter: 
ADMINISTRATOR: City Administrator or his/her designee for the City of Geneva, Illinois. CARRIAGE: Any device in, upon or by which any person is or may be transported or drawn upon a public way, designed to be or capable of being drawn by a horse and carrying no more than seven (7) passengers including the driver. CARRIAGE/WAGON/TROLLEY STAND: That portion of a curb lane designated by the city for loading and unloading of passengers to be transported by or having been transported by carriages, wagons, and trolleys. CITY: The City of Geneva, Illinois. CITY FESTIVAL: City-recognized festival, i.e. Swedish Days, Festival of the Vine, Christmas Walk, etc. HORSE: An animal of the genus equus and shall be a draft or draft-cross horse. More than fifty percent (50%) of the horse's blood line must be from a draft horse breed. PERSON: A natural person, partnership, firm, corporation or other legal entity. PLACE OF BUSINESS: A business office, with a separate telephone number and listing. TROLLEY: A motorized vehicle resembling a street car that is intended to transport tourists, shoppers and residents during a specified time period. WAGON: Any non-motorized device by which more than seven (7) passengers may be transported upon a public way and is propelled by animals or a motor vehicle excluding parades and those used in non-entertainment activities. (Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 3-4-2013)  
4-19-2: - HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGE COMPANY REQUIREMENTS: 
A.  Permit Required. No entity may conduct business as a for-hire horse-drawn carriage company on approved city streets without a valid, current horse-drawn carriage company permit issued by the city under section 4-19-2. Permits shall be issued annually for the period May 1 through April 30 of each year. Horse-drawn carriage company permit fees are one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for a year, includes the fee for the first carriage safety sticker, and must be renewed annually. 
B.  Number of Permits Issued. Only two (2) horse-drawn carriage company permits shall be issued each year (May 1 to April 30). 
C.  Background Check. Each applicant(s) must submit each fiscal year to a background check (including finger printing) by the police department and be found to be of good moral character in the eyes of the law. The non-refundable fee for a background check is thirty-five dollars ($35.00). 
D.  Rates. Each horse-drawn carriage must prominently display the rate or other charge to be made for its service. This may be done by placing placard on the inside of the carriage or handing out a document with the rates attached. 
E.  Insurance Requirements. Company permit holders must secure and maintain a commercial general liability policy reflecting limits of no less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence and two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) aggregate for covered claims arising out of, but not limited to, bodily injury, property damage, personal and advertising injury, and contractual liability in the course of the permit holder's work under a horse-drawn carriage company permit. The insurance policy must allow for written notice to the administrator thirty (30) days before a policy is cancelled, will expire or be reduced in coverage. 
F.  Special Event Festival Carriage Permit. A special event festival carriage permit is required for any carriage to operate during an approved Geneva festival and shall be covered in the festival applicant's special event/festival application. The fee for the special event festival permit is one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day per carriage if the applicant is charging the riders or working for tips and waived if the rides are free to the consumer and no tips are solicited and includes one (1) safety sticker fee. Only one (1) special event festival carriage permit is allowed per city festival. Up to three (3) carriages are allowed to operate under each special event festival carriage permit. If the carriage company has a horse drawn carriage company permit then the fee is waived. The festival applicant will need to supply in their special event application, the proposed carriage stand locations, proposed route or area the carriage will operate in and the necessary insurance unless covered by the festival. The carriage drivers must pass a background check each fiscal year and each carriage must have a valid carriage safety sticker. 
G.  Special Event One-Day Carriage Permit. A special event one-day carriage permit is required for a carriage to operate in Geneva if the applicant does not possess a horse-drawn carriage company permit or wants to operate outside the approved route area. The special event one-day carriage permit is for pre-paid ride(s) to a specific destination from a designated starting point. The special event one-day permit may not operate in an area covered by a city festival without the permission of that city festival applicant. The fee for the special event one-day carriage permit is fifty dollars ($50.00) per day. If the company has a current horse drawn carriage company permit then the fee is waived. The applicant will need to supply the specific route, time of the ride(s) and insurance as part of the special event/festival application. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 3-4-2013) 
4-19-3: - HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGE REQUIREMENTS AND OPERATING REGULATIONS: 
A.  Carriage Safety Sticker. Each horse-drawn carriage company must display a city safety sticker for each horse-drawn carriage being used in the operation. A safety sticker will be issued by the city police department upon a successful inspection of a carriage regarding the requirements put forth in subsections 4-19-3 B. and C. No horse-drawn carriage may carry more than seven (7) passengers at one (1) time, including the driver or the maximum allowed weight for the carriage, whichever is less. The fee for the first carriage safety sticker is included in the cost of the horse-drawn carriage company permit, which must be renewed annually. However, each subsequent carriage safety sticker shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) a year and must be renewed annually. The total number of carriage safety stickers issued each fiscal year for horse-drawn carriage company permits shall be three (3). If the city administrator determines that a permitted carriage(s) is not being utilized by the carriage company then the carriage safety sticker(s) will be forfeited so they can be used by other carriage companies. 
B.  Mechanically Sound. Each horse-drawn carriage shall be mechanically sound, and not in a state of disrepair, with all equipment functional in the manner for which it was constructed and shall be equipped with all other equipment not specifically mentioned in this chapter but required by the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
C.  Safety Equipment. All carriages shall be equipped with: two (2) electrified white lights visible for one thousand (1,000) feet to the front of the vehicle, two (2) electrified red lights visible for one thousand (1,000) feet and one (1) flashing amber light visible from five hundred (500) feet to the rear of the vehicle. All lights must be operational from sunset to sunrise and during the times of lessened visibility. Electrified directional signals are required at all times and to be visible from three hundred (300) feet to the rear of the vehicle. Each horse-drawn carriage shall be equipped with working brakes that are capable of stopping the loaded vehicle on at least a ten-degree incline. Each horse-drawn carriage shall also be equipped with mirrors so located as to reflect to the driver a view of the street for a distance of at least two hundred (200) feet to the rear of the wagon. 
D.  Driver Requirements. Each horse-drawn carriage company shall ensure that the driver(s) of their carriage(s) has in his or her possession a current and valid Illinois driver's license, completed a background check (including finger printing) by the city police department and is at least twenty-one (21) years of age. The fee for a background check is thirty-five dollars ($35.00). 
E.  Passenger Conduct. All passengers must remain seated during the ride. No open alcohol will be allowed in the carriage. 
F.  Hours of Operation. The commercial horse-drawn carriages shall not be operated for hire between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. 
G.  Signage. Each horse-drawn carriage may display a sign of no more than four (4) square feet on its exterior which identifies the horse drawn carriage permit holder and a contact phone number or a single sponsor and the contact phone number. 
H.  Horses. The horses used to pull the horse-drawn carriages must meet the definition of horse in section 4-19-1, be in good health and wear horse shoes in good condition. 
I.  Sanitation Requirements. Each horse-drawn carriage shall be equipped with a container placed to catch all horse droppings. Such containers shall be large enough to hold and retain all droppings during a drive until return to the starting point of each trip. All containers shall be emptied and sanitized daily. Waste catchers must be in place and functioning properly at all times. It shall be the responsibility of the horse-drawn carriage operator to clean up any spillage and to dilute and eliminate accumulated agents and odors upon the urination of any horse. Cleaning solution to be approved by the city administrator or his/her designee. The manure must be properly disposed of in the country and not in Geneva garbage receptacles. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 3-4-2013) 
4-19-4: - HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGE TRAFFIC REGULATIONS: 
A.  Traffic Laws. Carriage drivers shall obey all traffic-control devices and rules of the road. 
B.  Location on Street. All vehicles shall be driven in the right-hand lane available for traffic or as close as practicable to the right-hand curb or edge of the roadway. Each driver operating a horse-drawn carriage shall maintain the horse at a speed no faster than a walk or slow trot. Passenger loading and unloading will not be allowed on Third Street unless the horse-drawn carriage is in approved carriage stand locations. Double parking should be avoided to the greatest extent feasible. Unless approved through the special event application process, no carriages may operate during a festival. 
C.  Approved Locations. Horse-drawn carriages may only operate on approved local streets that have a posted speed limit of twenty-five (25) mph or less, unless crossing over an unauthorized street in accordance with the rules of the road and at a signalized intersection or with the specific assistance of an on-duty city police officer. The city will designate the approved streets or areas that horse drawn carriages may operate in by developing an approved map. The administrator will also designate appropriate carriage stand locations where carriages can park as they load and unload passengers and may designate temporary carriage stands and routes as necessary. The carriage company is responsible for supplying, installing and removing cones or A-frame signs to reserve their designated stand location. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 3-4-2013) 
4-19-5: - CITY RIGHT TO REVOKE CARRIAGE PERMITS: 
In the event that the administrator or his/her designee determines that the continued operation of a horse-drawn carriage company, special event festival carriage permit, or a special event one-day carriage Permit constitutes an unreasonable safety hazard or is otherwise contrary to the interest of the city, or for good cause shown, the city reserves the right to revoke or suspend any permits issued and, in that event, may issue a pro rata refund of the permit fee paid. The city may also exercise the option to impose a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first offense, a one hundred dollar ($100.00) fine for the second offense and for any subsequent offense pursuant to a summons or notice to appear in court on said offense, not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 3-4-2013) 
4-19-6: - SPECIAL EVENT WAGON PERMIT APPLICANT REQUIREMENTS: 
A.  No entity may utilize a "wagon" on approved city streets without a valid special event wagon permit issued by the city under section 4-19-6. The fee for a special event wagon permit is one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day, if the applicant is charging the riders or working for tips and waived if the rides are free to the consumer and no tips are solicited. The applicant will need to show their proposed wagon stand locations and the proposed route or area the wagon will operate in on their special event/festival application. 
B.  Number of Permits Issued. Only one (1) special event wagon permit shall be issued per day unless approved by the administrator. Each special event wagon permit will allow the applicant to have up to three (3) wagons in use at the same time if approved as part of the special event/festival application and having the necessary safety stickers. 
C.  Background Check. Each applicant(s) must submit each fiscal year to a background check (including finger printing) by the police department and be found to be of good moral character in the eyes of the law. The non-refundable fee for a background check is thirty-five dollars ($35.00). 
D.  Rates. Each wagon that is charging its customers shall prominently display the rate for its service. This may be done by placing a placard on the inside of the carriage or handing out a document with the rates attached. 
E.  Insurance Requirements. Special event wagon permit holders must secure and maintain a commercial general liability policy reflecting limits of no less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence and two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) aggregate for covered claims arising out of, but not limited to, bodily injury, property damage, personal and advertising injury, and contractual liability in the course of the permit holder's work under a special event wagon permit. The insurance policy must allow for written notice to the administrator thirty (30) days before a policy is cancelled, will expire or be reduced in coverage. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 3-4-2013) 
4-19-7: - SPECIAL EVENT WAGON REQUIREMENTS AND OPERATING REGULATIONS: 
A.  Wagon Safety Sticker. Each special event wagon permit holder must display a current city safety sticker for each wagon being used in the operation. A safety sticker will be issued by the city police department upon a successful inspection of a carriage regarding the requirements put forth in subsections 4-19-7 B. and C. No wagon may exceed its manufacturer's recommended maximum allowed weight. The fee for the first wagon safety sticker is included in the cost of the wagon permit, which must be renewed annually (May 1-April 30). However, each subsequent wagon safety sticker shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) a year and also must be renewed annually. 
B.  Mechanically Sound. Each wagon shall be mechanically sound, and not in a state of disrepair, with all equipment functional in the manner for which it was constructed and shall be equipped with all other equipment not specifically mentioned in this chapter but required by the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
C.  Safety Equipment. All wagons shall be equipped with: two (2) electrified white lights visible for one thousand (1,000) feet to the front of the vehicle, and two (2) electrified red lights visible for one thousand (1,000) feet and one (1) flashing amber light visible from five hundred (500) feet to the rear of the vehicle. All lights must be operational from sunset to sunrise and during the times of lessened visibility. Electrified directional signals are required at all times and to be visible from three hundred (300) feet to the rear of the vehicle. Each wagon shall be equipped with working brakes that are capable of stopping the loaded vehicle. Each wagon shall have at least two (2) means of egress and load from the side of the wagon. Each wagon shall also be equipped with mirrors so located as to reflect to the driver a view of the street for a distance of at least two hundred (200) feet to the rear of the wagon. 
D.  Driver Requirements. No wagon shall be operated with only one (1) person. Each wagon shall have a driver and a handler. Each wagon permit holder shall ensure that the driver(s) of their wagon(s) has in his or her possession a current and valid Illinois driver's license, completed a background check each fiscal year (including finger printing) by the city police department and is at least twenty-one (21) years of age. The handler, who is to ride in the wagon, shall ensure ride safety and help with the hitching of the horses and the loading and unloading of passengers. The handler will also need to pass a background check but is not required to have a driver's license unless the handler will also be driving the wagon. The fee for a background check is thirty-five dollars ($35.00). 
E.  Passenger Conduct. All passengers must remain seated during the ride. No open alcohol will be allowed in the carriage. 
F.  Hours of Operation. The wagons shall not be operated between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. without prior authorization from the administrator. 
G.  Signage. Each wagon possessing a safety sticker may display a sign of no more than six (6) square feet on its exterior which identifies the wagon permit holder and a contact phone number or a single sponsor and the contact phone number. 
H.  Horses. The horse(s) used to pull the wagons must meet the definition of horse in section 4-19-1, be in good health and wear horse shoes in good condition. The number and size of the horses used to draw a wagon shall be commensurate with the number of passengers being transported. 
I.  Sanitation Requirements. Each horse-drawn wagon shall be equipped with a container placed to catch all horse droppings. Such containers shall be large enough to hold and retain all droppings during a drive until return to the starting point of each trip. All containers shall be emptied and sanitized daily. Waste catchers must be in place and functioning properly at all times. It shall be the responsibility of the horse-drawn carriage operator to clean up any spillage and to dilute and eliminate accumulated agents and odors upon the urination of any horse. Cleaning solution to be approved by the city administrator or his/her designee. The manure must be properly disposed of in the country and not in city garbage receptacles. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 3-4-2013) 
4-19-8: - SPECIAL EVENT WAGON TRAFFIC REGULATIONS: 
A.  Traffic Laws. Wagon drivers shall obey all traffic-control devices and rules of the road. 
B.  Location on Street. All wagons shall be driven in the right-hand lane available for traffic or as close as practicable to the right-hand curb or edge of the roadway. Each driver operating a horse-drawn or motorized wagon shall maintain a speed no faster than a walk or slow trot of a horse. Passenger loading and unloading will not be allowed on Third Street unless the wagon is in approved wagon stand locations. Double parking should be avoided to the greatest extent feasible. Unless approved through the special event application process, no carriages may operate during a city festival. 
C.  Approved Locations. Wagons may only operate on approved local streets that have a posted speed limit of twenty-five (25) mph or less, unless crossing over an unauthorized street in accordance with the rules of the road and at a signalized intersection or with the specific assistance of an on-duty city police officer. The city will designate the approved streets or areas that wagons may operate in by developing an approved map. The administrator will also designate appropriate wagon stand locations where carriages can park as they load and unload passengers and may designate temporary wagon stands and routes, as necessary. The wagon company is responsible for supplying, installing and removing cones or A-frame signs to reserve their designated stand location. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 3-4-2013) 
4-19-9: - CITY RIGHT TO REVOKE SPECIAL EVENT WAGON PERMIT: 
In the event that the administrator or his/her designee determines that the continued operation of a wagon permit constitutes an unreasonable safety hazard or is otherwise contrary to the interest of the city, or for good cause shown, the city reserves the right to revoke or suspend any permits issued and, in that event, may issue a pro rata refund of the permit fee paid. The city may also exercise the option to impose a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first offense, a one hundred dollar ($100.00) fine for the second offense and for any subsequent offense pursuant to a summons or notice to appear in court on said offense, not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 3-4-2013) 
4-19-10: - TROLLEY PERMIT REQUIREMENTS: 
A.  No entity may utilize a "trolley" on approved city streets without a valid, trolley permit issued by the city under section 4-19-10. The fee for a trolley permit is one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day, if the applicant is charging the riders or working for tips, and waived, if the rides are free to the consumer and no tips are solicited. All trolleys shall submit a special event/festival application or be covered by the festival applicant's special event/festival application. The applicant will need to show their proposed trolley stand locations and the proposed route or area the trolley will operate in on a special event/festival application. 
B.  Number of Permits Issued. There is no set number of trolley permits issued. 
C.  Rates. Each trolley that is charging its customers shall prominently display the rate for its service. This may be done by placing a placard on the inside of the carriage or handing out a document with the rates attached. 
D.  Insurance Requirements. Trolley permit holders must secure and maintain a commercial general liability policy reflecting limits of no less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence and two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) aggregate for covered claims arising out of, but not limited to, bodily injury, property damage, personal and advertising injury, and contractual liability in the course of the permit holder's work under a trolley permit. The insurance policy must allow for written notice to the administrator thirty (30) days before a policy is cancelled, will expire or be reduced in coverage. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 3-4-2013) 
4-19-11: - TROLLEY REQUIREMENTS AND OPERATING REGULATIONS: 
A.  Mechanically Sound. Each trolley shall be mechanically sound, and not in a state of disrepair, with all equipment functional in the manner for which it was constructed. 
B.  Safety Equipment. All trolleys shall be equipped with at least two (2) emergency exits. No trolley may exceed its manufacturer's recommended maximum allowed weight. 
C.  Driver Requirements. Each trolley permit holder shall ensure that the driver(s) of their trolley(s) has in his or her possession a current and valid Illinois driver's license and is at least twenty-one (21) years of age. 
D.  Passenger Conduct. All passengers must remain seated during the ride or have a secure post that they can hold on to during the ride. No open alcohol will be allowed in the carriage. 
E.  Hours of Operation. The trolleys shall not be operated between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. without prior authorization from the administrator or the city council. 
F.  Signage. Each trolley may display a sign of no more than six (6) square feet on its exterior which identifies the trolley permit holder, contact phone number, and website or a single sponsor, the contact phone number and website. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 3-4-2013) 
4-19-12: - TROLLEY TRAFFIC REGULATIONS: 
A.  Traffic Laws. Trolley drivers shall obey all traffic-control devices and rules of the road. 
B.  Location on Street. All vehicles shall be driven in the right-hand lane available for traffic or as close as practicable to the right-hand curb or edge of the roadway. Passenger loading and unloading will not be allowed on Third Street unless the trolley is in approved trolley stand location. Double parking should be avoided to the greatest extent feasible. Unless approved through the festival applicant's special event/festival application process, no trolleys may operate during a festival. 
C.  Approved Locations. The city will designate the approved streets or areas that trolleys may operate in. The administrator will also designate appropriate trolley stand locations where trolleys can park as they load and unload passengers and may designate temporary trolley stands and routes as necessary. The trolley company is responsible for supplying, installing and removing cones or A-frame signs to reserve their designated stand location. 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 3-4-2013) 
4-19-13: - CITY RIGHT TO REVOKE TROLLEY PERMITS: 
In the event that the administrator or his/her designee determines that the continued operation of a trolley permit constitutes an unreasonable safety hazard or is otherwise contrary to the interest of the city, or for good cause shown, the city reserves the right to revoke or suspend any permits issued and, in that event, may issue a pro rata refund of the permit fee paid. The city may also exercise the option to impose a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first offense, a one hundred dollar ($100.00) fine for the second offense and for any subsequent offense pursuant to a summons or notice to appear in court on said offense, not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 3-4-2013) 
TITLE 5 - HEALTH AND SANITATION 
Subject       Chapter 
  
General Health Regulations 1 
Garbage, Refuse And Junk 2 
Noise Control 3 
CHAPTER 1 - GENERAL HEALTH REGULATIONS 
SECTION: 

5-1-1: - NUISANCE PROPERTY: 
It shall be unlawful for any person to permit or maintain the existence of any nuisance on any property under his control. The chief of police and the building commissioner and zoning enforcement officer are each hereby authorized to abate any nuisance existing in the city, whether it is specifically recognized or not. 
(1975 Code § 19-1) 
5-1-2: - WATER POLLUTION: 
A.  Obstruct Or Pollute Watercourses: It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person to obstruct or pollute any watercourse or source of water supply in the city. 
(1975 Code § 17-1) 
B.  Stagnant Waters: Any stagnant pool of water in the city is hereby declared to be a nuisance. It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any such nuisance to remain or exist on any property under his control. 
(1975 Code § 17-2) 
5-1-3: - DANGEROUS PREMISES: 
It shall be unlawful to permit any building, structure or place to remain in such a condition as to be dangerous to the public health in any way. Any such structure, building or place is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(1975 Code § 17-3) 
5-1-4: - DENSE SMOKE: 
A.  It shall be unlawful to cause or permit the emission of dense smoke from any fire, chimney, engine, oil burner or other agency in the city so as to cause annoyance or discomfort to the residents thereof. 
B.  For the purpose of testing and grading the density of smoke, the Ringelmann smoke chart, as published and used by the United States geological survey, shall be and is hereby adopted as a standard for such grading. Smoke is hereby declared to be "dense" when it is of a degree of density of number three (3) of said chart, or greater, for more than six (6) minutes in any one hour, whether such period of time is consecutive or not. 
(1975 Code § 17-4) 
5-1-5: - SEWAGE AND REFUSE: 
It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain, permit, cause, create or contribute to, in any way, an open drain, sewer or cesspool, and it shall also be unlawful for any person to permit, create, cause or contribute to any unsightly, nauseous or unhealthful condition by failing to properly dispose of sewage or refuse, both within the limits of the city and at any point within one-half (1/2) mile of the city limits. [1] 
(1975 Code § 17-5; amd. 2003 Code) 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
65 ILCS 5/7-4-1. 

5-1-6: - SETTLEMENT OF VIOLATIONS: 
Any person accused of a violation of this chapter may settle with the city, within ten (10) days of the time such alleged violation or offense was committed, the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each such violation or offense. Consecutive violations of this chapter shall be treated as separate offenses. Payment of such claim or claims shall be made at the police station of the city, or in the fine/claim deposit boxes located upon the streets of the city. The funds received from such compromised claims shall be promptly turned over to the city treasurer to be credited to the general corporate fund. In the event such claim or claims are not paid within ten (10) days of the time of the alleged offense, a notice to appear or a warrant (summons) may be issued for the arrest of the offender. 
(1975 Code § 17-6) 
CHAPTER 2 - GARBAGE, REFUSE AND JUNK 
SECTION: 

5-2-1: - DEFINITIONS: 
CURBSIDE: The parkway adjacent to the street pavement and gutter and within five feet (5') thereof. DISPOSAL UNIT: Shall include the following: A. For the purposes of refuse collection: 1) one watertight metal or plastic reusable waste container with handles, no larger than thirty two (32) gallons in capacity or sixty (60) pounds in weight; 2) one plastic or paper bag, box, carton or other disposable container not to exceed thirty three (33) gallons in capacity and sixty (60) pounds in weight, containing refuse or household construction and demolition debris, as herein defined, securely tied or closed in such a fashion so as to prevent the littering, leaking or scattering of refuse or debris; or 3) one securely tied bundle of refuse or debris which is not placed in a container that does not exceed two feet (2') in diameter, four feet (4') in length and sixty (60) pounds in weight; or 4) one single miscellaneous or odd shaped item of refuse or debris that does not exceed sixty (60) pounds in weight. A large household item, as is herein defined, is to be considered a disposal unit. Household construction and demolition debris, as herein defined, shall be considered a disposal unit. B. For the purposes of yard waste collection, one biodegradable two-ply, fifty (50) pound wet strength kraft paper bag designed for yard waste collection not to exceed thirty three (33) gallons in capacity and sixty (60) pounds in weight, containing yard waste, as herein defined, or one securely tied bundle of brush or branches using biodegradable cord, string, rope or twine that does not exceed sixty (60) pounds in weight, two feet (2') in diameter and four feet (4') in length, and is manageable by one person; neither of which contains branches exceeding three inches (3") in diameter. A "live" Christmas tree shall also be considered one disposal unit, and may exceed the dimension and weight limitations herein and need not be placed in a yard waste bag nor have its branches bundled. HOUSEHOLD: Each dwelling, church and parsonage or portion thereof, including homes, apartment buildings, apartment buildings containing stores and apartments, but shall not include commercial or industrial buildings. The number of households shall be determined and evidenced by the number of separate electric light meters or separate housekeeping units appertaining to said building. HOUSEHOLD 
CONSTRUCTION AND 
DEMOLITION DEBRIS 
OR DEBRIS: Waste materials from "do it yourself" scale interior and exterior household construction, remodeling and repair projects, including, but not limited to, drywall, plywood and paneling pieces, lumber and other building materials; windows and doors; cabinets; carpeting; disassembled bathroom and kitchen fixtures; and small amounts of sod, earth, clay, sand, concrete, rocks and similar materials. Such debris shall conform to the following: loose small items shall be placed in suitable disposable containers not exceeding sixty (60) pounds in weight, or in bundles not exceeding two feet (2') in diameter, four feet (4') in length, and sixty (60) pounds in weight. Materials not so conforming shall not be considered as household construction and demolition debris. Debris from new residential, commercial or industrial construction is specifically excluded. LARGE HOUSEHOLD 
ITEM OR BULK ITEM: Any discarded and unwanted large household appliances and furnishings, including, but not limited to: refrigerators, freezers, stoves, trash compactors, washers, dryers, dishwashers, hot water heaters, air conditioners, furnaces, humidifiers, dehumidifiers, microwaves, water softeners, televisions, pianos, organs, tables, chairs, mattresses, box springs, bookcases, sofas and similar furniture. RECYCLABLES OR 
RECYCLABLE 
MATERIALS: Newsprint (ONP); aluminum cans (foils and tins); steel containers (tin and bimetal cans, empty paint cans, empty aerosol cans, oversize cans); glass bottles and jars (flint, amber and green); all PET (polyethylene terephthalate) plastic containers; all HDPE (high density polyethylene) plastic containers (oil and antifreeze containers excluded); all PS (polystyrene) plastic containers and pieces, LDPE (low density polyethylene) plastic 6-pack rings and carrier straps; all chipboard (boxboard); all corrugated cardboard (OCC and kraft paper grocery bags); coated paper (magazines and catalogs); mixed paper (white ledger, color ledger, junk mail and computer paper); phone books; gable top cartons (coated milk and juice containers); multilayered juice boxes; household batteries (car batteries excluded). All recyclables placed for collection shall be free of foodstuffs or food or dirty residues. REFUSE: All discarded and unwanted putrescible and nonputrescible household and kitchen wastes, including, but not limited to, foods, food residues and materials necessarily used for packaging, storing, preparing and consuming same, usually defined as "garbage"; and all combustible and noncombustible waste materials resulting from the usual routine of domestic housekeeping, excluding hazardous and radioactive materials, including, but not limited to, aluminum and steel cans; glass containers; plastic containers; crockery and other containers; metal; paper of all types, including newspapers, books, magazines and catalogs; boxes and cartons; cold ashes; furniture, furnishings and fixtures; household appliances of all kinds; tires, textiles and leather; dead animals and animal waste; toys and recreational equipment; and similar items. "Live" Christmas trees shall be considered refuse. For the purposes of this chapter, the terms "garbage", "refuse", "rubbish", "solid waste", "trash" and "waste" shall be synonymous unless otherwise more specifically defined (for example, "yard waste"). YARD WASTE OR 
LANDSCAPE WASTE: Grass clippings, leaves, branches and brush; other yard and garden trimmings; vines; garden plants and flowers; weeds; tree droppings (for example pine cones and crabapples); and other similar organic waste materials accumulated as the result of the cultivation and maintenance of lawns, shrubbery, vines, trees and gardens. Sod and greenery from wreaths and garlands shall not be considered yard waste and shall be disposed of as refuse.  
(1975 Code § 16-1) 
5-2-2: - WEEKLY COLLECTIONS REQUIRED: 
A.  Dwellings: The current accumulation of refuse, recyclables, yard waste and household construction and demolition debris shall be collected not less than once each week from each dwelling and household in the city. Said collection shall be made by the city or by a scavenger with whom the city has contracted for such collection for each house or apartment building with less than four (4) dwelling units. 
B.  Multiple Dwellings, Offices And Commercial Uses: 
1.  It shall be the responsibility of the owner or tenant, as the case may be, to provide for such collection for each apartment house with four (4) or more dwelling units or any office or commercial use. 
2.  Notwithstanding the foregoing, apartment houses with more than four (4) dwelling units shall have the option to participate under the city's contract for refuse and recyclable disposal at the rates set forth at section 5-2-3 of this chapter; in the event the owner of such apartment house elects to participate under said contract, the owner shall notify the director of public works at 1800 South Street, Geneva, Illinois, in writing, not less than thirty (30) days prior to the proposed commencement date. Upon receipt of such notification, the city shall inspect the apartment house refuse area and determine the number of dwelling units to be assessed a service charge. Refuse and recycling services shall be accomplished by use of dumpsters provided by the city contractor. Upon exercise of the election to use the city contracted services, said apartment house shall be obligated to use said service during the remaining term of the city contract with the scavenger. 
(1975 Code § 16-2) 
5-2-3: - COLLECTION CHARGES: 
A.  The charges for collection, removal and/or disposal for refuse, yard waste, household construction and demolition, and appliances and large household items (also referred to as "white goods") are published on the city website or available upon request. 
B.  Each household will be provided a recycling cart at no charge. The charges for large volume recycling generators who elect to rent a wheeled cart beyond the free cart from the city's solid waste services contractor are published on the city website or available upon request. 
C.  Except for charges billed directly by the city's solid waste services contractor to the household requesting a refuse cart, the charges for collection of each refuse and yard waste disposal unit shall be assessed upon the purchase of a designated waste sticker to be attached to each disposal unit placed at curbside for collection. Said sticker may be purchased from the city and various retail outlets in the city. 
D.  City environmental collection charges. The monthly rate for services administered by the city to maintain the public streets free of debris and provide disposal services to the public shall be as follows: 
1.  Four dollars and thirty cents ($4.30) per month for each customer for the city's cost of administering the solid waste and recycling program, household hazardous waste, bulk leaf collection and disposal, brush pick up, and street sweeping on city streets. 
2.  Said charges shall be assessed to all customers that receive a City of Geneva utility bill. 
3.  Only households along public streets shall receive bulk leaf collection, brush pick up, and street sweeping. 
(Ord. 2003-31, 6-16-2003; Ord. No. 2008-19, § 1, 4-7-2008; Ord. No. 2008-26, § 1, 5-19-2008; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-2-2009; Ord. No. 2013-18, § 1, 5-6-2013; Ord. No. 2016-17, § 1, 5-2-2016; Ord. No. 2018-21, § 1, 7-9-2018) 
5-2-4: - CONTAINER SPECIFICATIONS AND PLACEMENT: 
A.  Refuse, Yard Waste And Debris Collection: All refuse, yard waste and debris for collection and disposal must be placed at the curbside, readily accessible, as follows: 
1.  All refuse, yard waste and debris for collection and disposal from single-family dwellings and apartment dwellings with less than four (4) units shall be placed in containers, bags or otherwise packaged and secured as specifically described in the definition of "disposal unit" in section 5-2-1 of this chapter. 
2.  All owners of property within the corporate limits of the city upon which there are at least four (4) multiple-dwelling units shall install standard, rear loading, covered containers for the storage of garbage, which containers are to be constructed to be used in connection with the pick up of garbage by compacting garbage trucks. These containers shall have either one or two (2) yard capacities. No other form of garbage depository will be permitted on any tract of land which is occupied by at least four (4) multi-dwelling units. 
3.  All owners of property within the corporate limits of the city upon which the city has placed a commercial or industrial electric meter must install covered garbage containers, rectangular in shape, constructed upon movable wheels so that the occupants of the improvements located on such property can deposit garbage in the containers. No other form of garbage depository will be permitted on any property owned by a landowner upon which the city has placed a commercial or industrial electric meter. 
(1975 Code § 16-4) 
B.  Garbage And Refuse Containers: All garbage and refuse to be collected shall be placed, by each owner or tenant of a household, in a covered container upon the curbside adjacent to the dwelling, as the requirement may be, no earlier than the day preceding the day on which collection is scheduled and no later than six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on the day of collection. The containers shall be so placed in a manner that is readily accessible for the collection on the day or days which are scheduled for the area in which said dwelling or household is located. Empty containers shall be removed as soon as possible, but in no event later than eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. on the day of collection. 
(1975 Code § 16-5) 
5-2-5: - RECYCLING SERVICES: 
A.  Collection: In addition to the collection of garbage and refuse, curbside collection of recyclable material shall be made for each household where garbage and refuse is collected at the curbside under contract with the city. The city's contractors shall collect recyclable materials from a fourteen (14) gallon recycling bin provided by the city on a once a week basis and on the same day in which refuse is collected from said household. 
(1975 Code § 16-6) 
B.  Title To Containers: All recycling bins shall remain the property of the city and shall not be removed from the property upon which a household is located without prior written consent of the director of public works. 
(1975 Code § 16-7) 
C.  Replacement Of Recycling Bins: Any damage to, destruction of, or loss of a recycling bin shall be reported to the department of public works by the owner or occupant of said household within twenty four (24) hours of said damage, destruction or loss. The cost of repair or replacement of any such recycling bin shall be the obligation and responsibility of the owner or occupant of said household. 
(1975 Code § 16-9) 
D.  Damage To City Recycling Containers: It shall be unlawful for any person to remove any recycling bin from a household or to cause damage or destruction of said recycling bin. 
(1975 Code § 16-8) 
E.  Theft Of Recyclable Materials: It shall be unlawful for any person to collect, possess, pick up or obtain unauthorized control over any recyclable materials placed at or adjacent or in a recycling bin after said recyclable materials are placed for collection at the curbside of a household (or in an alley adjacent to said household) or to otherwise remove said recyclable materials from a recycling bin after said recyclable material is placed in a recycling bin for collection, unless and provided that such person is under contract with the city for the purposes of collection of recyclable materials. Any person in violation of this chapter shall be fined in an amount as set forth in sections 1-3-1 and 1-3-2 of this code. 
(1975 Code § 16-10) 
5-2-6: - PROHIBITED STORAGE ON PROPERTY: 
A.  Definitions: 
ABANDONED 
AUTOMOBILE: An automobile not located within a carport or garage and without a current license plate from the state. JUNK, TRASH AND REFUSE: Includes any and all waste matter, whether reusable or not, which is offensive to the public health and safety in the neighborhood and is specifically intended to include, but not be limited to, worn out, wrecked and/or abandoned automobiles, trucks, tractors, machinery of any kind, any parts thereof, old iceboxes, refrigerators and stoves. [2]  
(1975 Code § 16-28) 
B.  Storage Prohibited; Nuisance Declared: The storing of junk, trash and refuse on private property within the city where such storage is not otherwise authorized is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(1975 Code § 16-29) 
C.  Notice Of Violation: Any police officer, the building commissioner and zoning enforcement officer or city administrator, upon observing any violation of this section, shall issue a notice directed to the owner of record of the property on which such nuisance occurs, as shown in the records of the recorder of deeds of Kane County, or to the occupant of such property, or to both, which notice shall describe the violation and shall establish a reasonable time limit for the abatement thereof by such owner or occupant which time shall not be less than two (2) days nor more than ten (10) days after service of such notice. 
(1975 Code § 16-30) 
D.  Procedure For Citizen's Complaint: Any citizen of the city who observes a violation of this section may file his affidavit setting forth in detail the violation, its location and the name of the owner and occupant of the property on which such nuisance is alleged, and may file the affidavit with the building commissioner and zoning enforcement officer or the city administrator, who shall investigate such charge, and if such nuisance exists, shall issue a notice to the owner or occupant of the property as provided in subsection C of this section. 
(1975 Code § 16-31) 
E.  Service Of Violation Notice: Any police officer, the building commissioner and zoning enforcement officer or city administrator shall serve the notice provided for in this section upon the owner or occupant of the property where such nuisance exists, or upon both of them, and shall make his return upon a copy of such notice, showing the time of service, the person upon whom it was served or the manner in which it was served. 
(1975 Code § 16-32) 
F.  Investigation Relative To Nuisance Abatement: Immediately upon the termination of the time allowed in the notice for the abatement of a nuisance as provided in this section, the police officer, building commissioner and zoning enforcement officer or city administrator who served such notice, or any other police officer or inspector who shall be assigned by the building commissioner and zoning enforcement officer or city administrator, shall investigate to determine whether or not the nuisance has been abated. 
(1975 Code § 16-33) 
G.  Failure To Abate: Complaint: In the event the owner or occupant of the property where a nuisance exists as provided in this section has failed within the prescribed time to abate such nuisance, then the police officer, building commissioner and zoning enforcement officer or city administrator who served such notice, or the citizen of the city who filed an affidavit with the building commissioner and zoning enforcement officer or city administrator under the provisions of this section, shall file a complaint charging violation of this article with the circuit court for the sixteenth judicial circuit, or a magistrate thereof, demanding that the owner of the property or the occupant thereof, or both, be punished as provided in this section. 
(1975 Code § 16-34) 
H.  Prosecution By City Required: The city shall prosecute all complaints of violation of this section. 
(1975 Code § 16-35) 
I.  Penalty For Violation: Any property owner or any occupant of property who allows storage as prohibited by this section on property owned or occupied by him shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-3-1 of this code. Any person who shall neglect to abate and remove such nuisance, after notice thereof, shall, for each twenty four (24) hours thereafter during which such nuisance continues, be subject to a like penalty as that originally incurred. 
(1975 Code § 16-36) 
Footnotes: 

5-2-7: - LITTERING: 
A.  Depositing Of Litter Prohibited; Exceptions: It shall be unlawful for any person, by himself or by his agent, employee or servant, to cast, throw, sweep, sift or deposit in any manner in or upon any public way or other public place in the city, or any river, canal, public water, drain, sewer or receiving basin within the jurisdiction of the city, any kind of dirt, rubbish, waste article, thing or substance whatsoever, whether liquid or solid. Nor shall any person cast, throw, sweep, sift or deposit any of the aforementioned items anywhere within the jurisdiction of the city in such a manner that it may be carried or deposited in whole or in part by the action of the sun, wind, rain or snow into any of the aforementioned places; provided, that this subsection shall not apply to the deposit of material under a permit authorized by any ordinance of the city; or to goods, wares or merchandise deposited upon any public way or other public place temporarily in the necessary course of trade and removed therefrom within two (2) hours after being so deposited; or to articles or things deposited in or conducted into the city sewer system through lawful drains in accordance with the ordinances of the city relating thereto. 
(1975 Code § 16-15) 
B.  Vehicles To Be Covered; Exceptions: It shall be unlawful for any person, by himself or by his agent, employee or servant, to use any vehicle to haul any kind of dirt, rubbish, waste articles or things or substance, whether liquid or solid, unless such vehicle is covered to prevent any part of its load from spilling or dropping at all times while such vehicle is in motion on any street or alley in the city, except that when such vehicle is on State Street, it shall be covered at all times, except while actually being loaded or unloaded; provided, however, that the requirements herein for covering such vehicles shall not apply to vehicles carrying brush cuttings, tree trimmings, branches, logs or similar waste material, if such matter is securely lashed to such vehicle to prevent spilling or dropping as aforesaid. 
(1975 Code § 16-16) 
5-2-8: - SETTLEMENT OF VIOLATIONS: 
Any person accused of a violation of this chapter may settle and compromise the claim of violation against him by paying to the city, within ten (10) days of the time such alleged violation or offense was committed, the sum of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each such violation or offense. Consecutive violations of this chapter shall be treated as separate offenses. Payment of such claim or claims shall be made at the police station of the city, or in the fine/claim deposit boxes located upon the streets of the city. The funds received from such compromised claims shall be promptly turned over to the city treasurer to be credited to the general corporate fund. In the event such claim or claims are not paid within ten (10) days of the time of the alleged offense, a notice to appear or a warrant (summons) may be issued for the arrest of the offender. 
(1975 Code §§ 16-11, 16-17, 16-37) 
CHAPTER 3 - NOISE CONTROL 
SECTION: 

5-3-1: - DEFINITIONS: 
For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. All technical definitions are in accordance with American National Standards Institute: 
"A" BAND LEVEL: The total sound level of all noise as measured with a sound level meter using the "A" weighting network. The unit of measurement is the dB(A). AMBIENT NOISE: The all encompassing noise associated with a given environment, being usually a composite of sounds from many sources, near and far. BEL: A unit of level which the base of logarithm is ten (10). Use of BEL is restricted to levels of quantities proportional to power. CYCLE: The complete sequence of values of a periodic quantity that occur during a period. DECIBEL: One-tenth (0.1) of a BEL and is a unit of level when the base of the logarithm is the tenth root of ten (10) and the quantities concerned are proportional to power. EMERGENCY WORK: Work made necessary to restore property to a safe condition following a public calamity, or work required to protect persons or property from an imminent exposure to danger. PERIOD OF A 
PERIODIC 
QUANTITY: The smallest increment of time for which the function repeats itself. PERIODIC 
QUANTITY: An oscillating quantity, the values of which recur for equal increments of time. PERSON: Any person, person's firm, association, copartnership, joint venture, corporation or any entity public or private in nature. SOUND ANALYZER: A device for measuring the band pressure level or pressure spectrum level of a sound as a function of frequency. SOUND LEVEL METER: An instrument including a microphone, an amplifier, an output meter, and frequency weighting networks for the measurement of noise and sound levels in a specified manner. SOUND PRESSURE 
LEVEL IN DECIBELS 
OF SOUND: Twenty (20) times the logarithm to the base-10 of the ratio of the pressure of this sound to be the reference pressure, which reference pressure must be explicitly stated.  
(1975 Code § 17-30) 
5-3-2: - NOISES PROHIBITED: 
It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue, or cause to be made or continued any excessive, unnecessary or unusually loud noise which either annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others within the corporate limits of the city. 
(1975 Code § 17-31) 
5-3-3: - NOISE LEVEL TESTS: 
The standards which shall be considered in determining whether a violation of section 5-3-2 of this chapter exists shall include, but shall not be limited to, the following: 
A.  The volume of the noise. 
B.  The intensity of the noise. 
C.  Whether the nature of the noise is usual or unusual. 
D.  Whether the origin of the noise is natural or unnatural. 
E.  The volume and intensity of the background noise, if any. 
F.  The proximity of the noise to residential sleeping facilities. 
G.  The nature and zoning of the area within which the noise emanates. 
H.  The density of inhabitation of the area within which the noise emanates. 
I.  The time of the day or night the noise occurs. 
J.  The duration of the noise. 
K.  Whether the noise is recurrent, intermittent or constant. 
L.  Whether the noise is produced by a commercial or noncommercial activity. 
(1975 Code § 17-32) 
5-3-4: - NOISE LEVELS BETWEEN PROPERTIES: 
A.  It shall be unlawful to project a sound or noise excluding noise emanating from cars, trucks or motorcycles from one property into another, which exceeds the limiting noise spectra set forth in this subsection, with the classification of land being by use. Sound or noise projecting from one use district into another use district with a different noise level limit shall not exceed the limits of the district into which the noise is projected. 
NOISE LEVELS FOR USE DISTRICTS 
Maximum permissible sound pressure level (dB) of sound emitted to any of the following use districts: 
Hours Residential Commercial Industrial Between 7:00 A.M. and 10:00 P.M. 65 84 85 Between 10:00 P.M. and 7:00 A.M. 60 79 80  
_______ 
Residential: All single-family and multi-family dwelling units under R1, R2, R3, R4, R5, R6, R7, RR and RE zoning districts. 
Commercial: All business and commercial uses under B1, B2, B3, B3(E) B4, B5, B6 and GO and all nonresidential special uses granted under R1 through R4 zoning districts. 
Industrial: All industrial uses including uses under OR, I1 and I2. 
(1975 Code § 17-33; amd. 2003 Code) 
B.  The measurement of such sound or noise shall be made with a sound level meter and octave band analyzer meeting the standards prescribed by the American National Standards Institute, or its successor. The instruments shall be maintained in calibration and good working order. Octave band corrections may be employed in meeting the response specification. A calibration check shall be made of the system prior to the time of any noise measurement and thereafter. Measurements recorded shall be taken so as to provide a proper representation of the noise source. The microphone during measurement shall be positioned so as not to create any unnatural enhancement or diminution of the measured noise. A windscreen for the microphone shall be used when required. Traffic, aircraft and other transportation noise sources and other background noises shall not be considered in taking measurements except where such background noise interferes with the primary noise being measured. 
C.  The slow meter response of the sound level meter shall be used in order to best determine that the average amplitude does not exceed the limiting noise spectra set forth in subsection A of this section. 
D.  The measurement shall be made at the property line of the property on which such noise is received, five feet (5') aboveground, but such measurement shall not be made closer than twenty five feet (25') from such noise source. 
E.  In the case of an elevated or directional sound or noise source, compliance with the noise limits is to be maintained at any elevation at the boundary, but not closer than twenty five feet (25') from said noise source. 
(1975 Code § 17-33) 
5-3-5: - MOTOR VEHICLE NOISE: 
A.  It shall be unlawful to operate a motorized vehicle within the city limits which creates a noise or sound which exceeds the noise level limits set out below:

B.  The measurement of sound or noise shall be made with a sound level meter and octave band analyzer meeting the standards prescribed by the American National Standards Institute. The instruments shall be maintained in calibration and good working order. Octave band corrections may be employed in meeting the response specifications. A calibration check shall be made of the system prior to the time of any noise measurement and thereafter. Measurements recorded shall be taken so as to provide a proper representation of the noise source. The microphone during measurement shall be positioned so as not to create any unnatural enhancement or diminution of the measured noise. A windscreen for the microphone shall be used when required. Traffic, aircraft and other transportation noise sources and other background noises shall not be considered in taking measurements except where such background noise interferes with the primary noise being measured. 
(1975 Code § 17-34) 
5-3-6: - EXEMPTIONS FROM NOISE LEVEL RESTRICTIONS: 
The following uses and activities shall be exempt from noise level regulations: 
A.  Noises or safety signals, warning devices and emergency pressure relief valves installed. 
B.  Noises resulting from any authorized emergency vehicle, when responding to an emergency call or acting in time of emergency. 
C.  Noises resulting from "emergency work", as defined in section 5-3-1 of this chapter. 
D.  Noises resulting from work performed by governmental agencies or their agents (road, street, water, sewer repairs or construction) to promote the public health, welfare and safety. 
E.  Noises resulting from community events including, but not limited to, parades, festivals, July 4th celebrations, sponsored in whole or part by local governments, schools, charitable or service organizations. 
F.  Noises in the course of business controlled or within the jurisdiction of another governmental agency including, but not limited to, FAA, airplanes and the like. 
G.  Any organized amateur or professional sporting activity. 
(1975 Code § 17-35) 
5-3-7: - VARIANCES: 
A.  Applications for a permit for relief from the noise level designated in this chapter on the basis of undue hardship may be made to the city council through the city administrator. Any permit granted by the city council hereunder shall contain all conditions upon which said permit has been granted and shall specify a reasonable time that the permit shall be effective. 
B.  The city council may grant the relief as applied or if it finds: 
1.  The activity, operation or noise source will be of temporary duration, and cannot be done in a manner that would comply with other sections of this chapter; 
2.  No other reasonable alternative is available to the application; and 
3.  The city council may prescribe any conditions or requirements it deems necessary to minimize adverse effects upon the community or the surrounding neighborhood. 
(1975 Code § 17-36) 
5-3-8: - ENFORCEMENT: 
A.  Violations of this chapter shall be prosecuted in the same manner as other violations of this city code. [3] 
B.  As an additional remedy, the operation or maintenance of any device, instrument, vehicle, or machinery in violation of any provision hereof which causes discomfort or annoyance to reasonable persons of normal sensitiveness or which endangers the comfort, repose, health or peace of residents in the area shall be deemed, and is declared to be a public nuisance and may be subject to abatement summarily by a restraining order or injunction issued by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(1975 Code § 17-37) 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
See the general penalty in section 1-3-1 of this code. 

5-3-9: - VIOLATIONS; PENALTY: 
A.  Penalty: Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a petty offense. Except for the offenses in section 5-3-4 of this chapter, upon conviction of such offense a person shall be fined in an amount as provided in the general penalty in section 1-3-1 of this code, and each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be deemed punishable as such hereunder. Any person violating section 5-3-4 of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a petty offense and upon conviction thereof shall be fined as follows: 
First violation $ 50.00 Second violation within 72 hours of a first violation  100.00 Third violation within 72 hours of a first violation  200.00 Fourth violation within 72 hours of a first violation  400.00 Subsequent violations within 72 hours of the first violation Subject to a complaint for a permanent 

injunction  
(1975 Code § 17-38; amd. 2003 Code) 
B.  Settlement Of Violations: Any person accused of a violation of this chapter, except for violations of section 5-3-4 of this chapter, may settle and compromise the claim of violation against him by paying to the city, within ten (10) days of the time such alleged violation or offense was committed, the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each such violation or offense. Consecutive violations of this chapter shall be treated as separate offenses. Settlement of violations of section 5-3-4 of this chapter shall be in conformance with the fine structure specified in subsection A of this section. Payment of such claim or claims shall be made at the police station of the city, or in the fine/claim deposit boxes located upon the streets of the city. The funds received from such compromised claims shall be promptly turned over to the city treasurer to be credited to the general corporate fund. In the event such claim or claims are not paid within ten (10) days of the time of the alleged offense, a notice to appear or a warrant (summons) may be issued for the arrest of the offender. 
(1975 Code § 17-39; amd. 2003 Code) 
TITLE 6 - POLICE REGULATIONS 
Subject       Chapter 
  
Animal Control 1 
Miscellaneous Offenses 2 
Minors 3 
Police Alarm Systems 4 
Bicycles 5 
Fair Housing 6 
Parades 7 
Seizure and Impoundment of Vehicles 8 
CHAPTER 1 - ANIMAL CONTROL 
SECTION: 

6-1-1: - PURPOSE: 
It is the purpose of this chapter to protect animals from neglect and abuse, to protect residents from annoyance and injury by animals, and to discourage the excessive multiplication of animals. 
(1975 Code § 6-1) 
6-1-2: - DEFINITIONS: 
As used in this chapter, the following shall be defined as follows: 
ANIMAL: Any living, vertebrate creature, domestic or wild, not including humans. ANIMAL SHELTER: Any facilities operated, owned or maintained by a duly incorporated humane society, animal welfare society or other nonprofit organization licensed under the animal welfare act of the state of Illinois [1] whose purpose is to provide for and promote the welfare, protection and humane treatment of animals. BITE: Seizure with the toenails or teeth or jaws of an animal so that the skin of the human being seized has been pierced or broken and further includes contact of the saliva of the said animal with any open and unhealed break or abrasion of the skin of said human being. CAT: Any animal of the family felidae. DANGEROUS OR 
VICIOUS ANIMAL: Any animal that attacks or bites a person, or that is known to have attached or bitten a person on a previous occasion when said person was peacefully conducting himself where he lawfully was entitled to be. DOG: Any animal of the family canidae. FOWL: Any pigeons, poultry or waterfowl. IDENTIFIED ANIMAL: Any animal wearing a Kane County, Illinois rabies tag or emblem of identification that is securely fastened to a collar or harness worn by the animal which identifies the owner of the animal and the owner's current telephone number and address. KENNEL: Any establishment wherein any person engages in the business of boarding, breeding, buying, grooming, letting for hire, training for a fee or selling dogs or cats; provided, however, that the ownership of dogs or cats which are part of the household shall not constitute the operation of a kennel. Kennel also shall not include any animal control center or any pound or similar facility operated by a subdivision of local, state or federal government. OWNER: Any person who has a right of property in an animal, who keeps or harbors an animal, who has an animal in his care, who acts as custodian of an animal, or who knowingly permits any domestic animal to remain on or about any premises occupied by him. PERSON: Any person, family, household group, firm, corporation, partnership, association or other legal or social entity. PET SHOP: Any establishment, other than a kennel, as defined in this section, wherein any person engages in the business of selling animals represented as suitable for use as pets. POUND: Any facility owned by, or operated under contract with the city for the purpose of impounding, housing or harboring seized, stray, homeless, abandoned or unwanted animals. RESTRAINT: An animal shall be deemed under restraint if: A. It is under the control of its owner or other responsible person by means of a leash, cord, rope, strap, chain or lead held by such owner or person and securely fastened to the collar or harness attached to the animal; or B. It is securely enclosed, confined or restrained on premises where it lawfully may be so as to be unable to enter upon the public way or to molest persons lawfully using the public way. STRAY ANIMAL: Any animal not under restraint and not in the presence of or within the property of its owner.  
(1975 Code § 6-2) 
Footnotes: 

6-1-3: - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT: 
The city is responsible for the administration and enforcement of this chapter, in cooperation with the city police department and such other public or private agencies as may be sanctioned for in the care and control of animals. 
(1975 Code § 6-21) 
6-1-4: - LICENSING AND ZONING REQUIREMENTS: 
It shall be unlawful for a person to engage in the business of a pet shop, kennel, animal shelter, or pound operator, or any combination thereof, without being licensed by the state of Illinois in accordance with the Illinois animal welfare act, or its successor enactment and such person must also be in compliance with all building, zoning and other applicable provisions of this code. 
(1975 Code § 6-23) 
6-1-5: - REGULATIONS FOR KEEPING: 
A.  Limit On Number Of Dogs And Cats Per Household: It shall be unlawful for a person to have more than a total of four (4) dogs and/or cats in any household, apartment or other dwelling unit within the city, except that a litter of dogs or cats may be kept for a period of time not exceeding four (4) months from birth. Any dwelling unit containing more than a total of four (4) dogs and/or cats is hereby deemed a nuisance, and any person who violates this section shall be subject to the enforcement provisions under this chapter. 
(1975 Code § 6-18) 
B.  Restraint Of Animals Required: Each owner of any animal shall keep such animal exclusively on such owner's property, except that any such animal may be off said property if restrained by a substantial leash, chain or other appropriate physical device and under the direct supervision and immediate control of a competent person. Any animal not under restraint shall be considered a stray animal, and shall be taken up and impounded. 
(1975 Code §§ 6-3, 6-4) 
C.  Females In Heat; Staking Out Unattended Animals: It shall be unlawful for an owner to chain or stake out unattended, or leave unrestrained outside and unattended, any bitch in season, i.e., while she is in heat, or to take out any animal, male or female, in such manner that said animal may go beyond the owner's property. 
(1975 Code § 6-5) 
D.  Owner's Responsibility To Remove Excreta: It shall be unlawful for an owner to fail to immediately remove excrement deposited by his pet upon the public ways, or within the public places of the city, or upon the property of any other person without that person's consent. When accompanying an animal off of his property, the owner or his agent shall have on his person a plastic or paper bag or container suitable for the removal of such excrement. This restriction shall not apply to a blind person while walking his guide dog. 
(1975 Code § 6-7) 
6-1-6: - NUISANCE ANIMALS: 
A.  Acts Declared Nuisances: An animal shall be determined to be a nuisance, and it shall be unlawful for an owner held in violation of this section, when such animal shall commit and repeat any of the following acts: 
1.  Molesting persons or moving vehicles by chasing or barking or otherwise encumbering them; 
2.  Attacking other animals that are being restrained in a manner authorized by this chapter; 
3.  Damaging property other than that of the owner; 
4.  Barking, whining, howling, or otherwise emitting loud noises excessively for an extended and uninterrupted period while on the property of the owner or within the confines of the owner's residence or other enclosed building on the owner's property. 
(1975 Code § 6-8) 
B.  Dead Animals: It shall be unlawful as a nuisance for any person to leave in, or throw into, any public way, public place or public water, or to bury within the city the body, or any part thereof, of any dead or fatally sick or injured animal, or to display the unpreserved body or any unpreserved part of the dead animal in a place where it may be dangerous to the life or detrimental to the health of any animal or person. 
(1975 Code § 6-9) 
6-1-7: - CRUELTY TO ANIMALS: 
It shall be unlawful for a person to do any of the following: 
A.  Beat, torture, torment, bait or incite toward fighting, mutilate or cruelly kill any animal, or cause or knowingly allow the same to be done; 
B.  Wilfully fail to provide any animal in his charge or custody with proper food, water, air and sanitary shelter; such shelter to be sufficient to provide natural light or artificial illumination during reasonable hours, protecting from drafts, reasonable safeguards against chilling and overheating caused by temperature extremes, and space within that is sufficient for the animal to stand in an upright position and lie down stretched out so that no part of its body need touch the top or sides of the shelter structure; 
C.  Carry, keep, drive, or cause to be carried, driven or kept, any animal in a cruel manner; 
D.  Leave for any length of time any animal unattended in a motor vehicle and/or trailer when the outside temperature is such that the animal may suffer from excessive heat, cold or physical stress; 
E.  Have, keep or harbor any animal that is infected with any disease transmissible to other animals or human beings, or that is afflicted with any painful disease or injury, including severe parasitism, unless such animal shall be under the care of a licensed veterinarian; 
F.  Abandon any animal on any public way or in any place where it may suffer or become a public charge. 
(1975 Code § 6-13) 
6-1-8: - PROHIBITED ANIMALS, ACTS AND CONDITIONS: 
A.  Animals Prohibited In City: It is unlawful to keep any pigs, swine, sheep, cattle, horses, goats, fowl or similar animals, or any naturally wild animals other than birds and fish within the city unless: a) allowed by the zoning ordinance of the city; [2] or b) properly and safely confined in zoological parks, performing animal exhibitions, education institutions, veterinary hospitals, or animal shelters licensed under the animal welfare act of the state. 
(1975 Code § 6-10) 
B.
