The building permit applicant may designate trees other than class A or class B trees to be protected by initial protective measures. Any tree may be removed or relocated if it interferes with the construction of buildings or structures that are otherwise in conformity with this code. (Ord. 2004-10, 2-17-2004, eff. 5-3-2004) 
8-5C-6: - TREE LOCATION SKETCH SUBMISSION REQUIREMENTS: 
A building permit applicant shall provide the following documents to the community development building department: 
A.  Three (3) copies of all required documents. 
B.  A sketch (tree location sketch) showing the location, size and species (if known) of all existing trees ten inches (10") in diameter (measured 4.5 feet above the ground) that are located in a construction activity zone or tree preservation zone, including municipal trees and border trees. The tree location sketch shall show the trees within a tree preservation zone that are designated by the building permit applicant to be removed, relocated or protected, and trees located in the construction activity zone that are designated by the property owner for initial protection measures. (Ord. 2004-10, 2-17-2004, eff. 5-3-2004) 
8-5C-7: - TREE PROTECTION PLAN SUBMISSION REQUIREMENTS: 
The building permit applicant shall provide the following documents to the community development building departments: 
A.  Application Fee: The fee charged for tree preservation reviews shall be determined by the community development department based upon the actual costs incurred for application processing, site inspections, and consulting arborist/horticulturalist services. A schedule of fees is on file at the building division of the community development department. 
B.  Copies: Three (3) copies of all required documents. 
C.  Location Of Trees: The location of all trees within a tree preservation zone that are designated by the building permit applicant to be removed, relocated or protected, and the location of all trees within construction activity zones that area designated by the building permit applicant for initial tree protection measures. 
D.  Critical Root Zones: The extent of the critical root zone of trees, which are designated by the building permit applicant to be protected within the tree preservation zone or initially protected in the construction activity zone. 
E.  Protective Measures; Location And Type: The location and type of protective measures to be placed on the lot. 
F.  Protective Measures; Parties Responsible: The parties responsible for the construction, erection and maintenance of temporary fencing or other physical barrier around the trees designated by the owner to be retained. 
G.  Development Dimensions: Location, shape and spatial arrangement of existing and proposed buildings, walls, improvements and structures within or abutting the construction activity zone. (Required information for the building permit application.) 
H.  Accessory Development Dimensions: Location, shape and spatial arrangement of temporary material storage areas and all permanent driveways, parking areas, and accessways. 
I.  Utilities: Any new utility services including water, sanitary sewer, storm sewer, gas, electric, telephone, and cable TV, and any existing utility services that will be removed or modified. 
J.  Grading: Existing and proposed grading showing elevations with contour lines at one foot (1') intervals if a grading plan is required by another part of this code as part of a building permit application. 
K.  Preparation Assistance: The community development department staff member, or a professional forester employed by the city shall, if requested, assist the building permit applicant in preparing the tree location sketch or tree preservation plan. (Ord. 2004-10, 2-17-2004, eff. 5-3-2004) 
8-5C-8: - BUILDING PERMIT APPROVAL FOR TREE PROTECTION PLAN: 
A.  No building permit shall be issued by the building division of the community development department for the construction, addition, alteration or replacement of a principal structure on a lot, the construction, addition or alteration of a new garage or other accessory structure, impervious surface additions (sidewalks, patios, and driveways), decks, porches, tennis courts, swimming pools, grading or regarding of the lot or lawn sprinkler/irrigation systems unless the following conditions are fulfilled: 
1.  Tree protection plan is approved by the community development department, and 
2.  The community development department has inspected and approved the tree protection measures. 
B.  A proposed tree protection plan shall be subject to review by the community development department and may require, as determined by the director of the department, review by a professional forester. Protective measures shown on the tree protection plan for trees on adjacent properties (border trees) and municipal trees shall be approved by the community development department, but the measures shall not supersede the right of the applicant to build if the applicable setback requirements are met. 
C.  During review of the tree protection plan and tree location sketch, the department staff and/or professional forester shall identify any class A key specimen trees or class B significant trees for the city of Geneva. It is especially important that every effort be made to preserve and protect these trees when possible. 
D.  The department staff or professional forester shall recommend modifications to the tree protection plan in order to provide for additional protection and preservation of trees. Notwithstanding the foregoing, a tree protection plan shall be approved if it otherwise is in conformity with this article. 
E.  The tree protection plan shall be reviewed concurrently with the building permit application. The building division of the community development department shall not issue a building permit until it has been determined that the initial tree protection measures shown on the tree protection plan have been implemented on the project site. 
F.  Upon the issuance of a building permit, the building permit applicant shall maintain the tree protection measures for protected trees during the entire construction period through finish grading. Any required fencing shall not be removed prior to the issuance of final certificate of occupancy. 
G.  A copy of the approved tree protection plan shall be located on the project site before work commences and always during construction of the project at all times. The building permit applicant shall be responsible for notifying all other contractors working on the project regarding the provisions of the tree protection plan. (Ord. 2004-10, 2-17-2004, eff. 5-3-2004) 
8-5C-9: - PRECAUTIONS DURING CONSTRUCTION: 
During construction, all reasonable measures necessary to prevent the destruction or damage of protected trees shall be taken, including, but not limited to, the following: 
A.  No construction activity, movement, and/or placement of equipment or material or spoils storage shall be permitted within the critical root zone of any protected tree shown on the approved tree protection plan. No excess soil, additional fill, liquids or construction debris shall be placed within the critical root zone of a protected tree. 
B.  Appropriate protective fencing shall be installed around the critical root zone of protected trees. Examples of fencing include: wooden slat snow fencing, orange PVC construction fencing or chainlink fencing with metal posts. 
C.  No attachments, fences, or wires, other than those approved for bracing, guying or wrapping, shall be attached to protected trees during the construction period. 
D.  Other protection measures such as mulching, construction pruning, root pruning, crown pruning, trunk wrapping, directional boring, root zone bridges and fertilization, may be approved by the department of community development and completed in accordance with the "Arboricultural Specifications Manual". 
E.  Unless otherwise shown on the approved tree protection plan, no soil shall be added to or removed from the critical root zone of any protected trees. (Ord. 2004-10, 2-17-2004, eff. 5-3-2004) 
8-5C-10: - MONITORING OF TREE PROTECTION PLANS: 
A.  Construction work shall be in accordance with the approved tree protection plan. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to violate terms of any tree protection plan that is approved as part of the issuance of a building permit. 
B.  A stop work order shall be authorized for violations of an approved tree protection plan. In the event an authorized member of the community development department staff or a professional forester observes the protection measures specified in the approved tree protection plan are not undertaken before construction commenced or are not maintained during construction, a stop work order may be issued. The stop work order shall remain in force until the building permit applicant complies with the approved tree protection plan. (Ord. 2004-10, 2-17-2004, eff. 5-3-2004) 
8-5C-11: - AMENDMENTS TO AN APPROVED TREE PROTECTION PLAN: 
A.  The building permit applicant may apply to the community development department to amend an approved tree protection plan. No amendment shall be approved which requests deletion of a protected tree which has been damaged or where provisions of the approved tree protection plan have not been complied. 
B.  An application for an amendment may be approved upon the submission of new facts or changed circumstances, which were not within the control of the building permit applicant and demonstrates a hardship in complying with the tree protection plan. In the event a protected tree has been damaged such that its removal is required, the director of the community development department may provide written authorization of such removal to the building permit applicant. (Ord. 2004-10, 2-17-2004, eff. 5-3-2004) 
8-5C-12: - VIOLATION AND PENALTY: 
A.  Any person who violates any provision of this article, upon being found guilty of the violation, shall be subject to a fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each violation. Each day during which any such violation shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. 2004-10, 2-17-2004, eff. 5-3-2004) 
CHAPTER 6 - CEMETERIES 
SECTION: 

8-6-1: - CEMETERIES ESTABLISHED: 
The city hereby establishes as municipal cemeteries Oak Hill cemetery and West Side cemetery, and will manage, care for, operate and control said cemeteries. (Ord. 2000-34, 5-1-2000) 
8-6-2: - ADMINISTRATION: 
A.  Corporate Authorities Act As Board Of Managers: From and after the effective date of this chapter, the corporate authorities of the city shall manage, care for, operate and control cemeteries owned by the city. (Ord. 2000-34, 5-1-2000) 
B.  Administration: The corporate authorities may, from time to time, adopt rules and regulations governing the city cemeteries. The city treasurer shall deposit in such financial institutions designated by the corporate authorities all money received from the sale of lots or blocks or any monetary donations made on behalf of the cemeteries. (Ord. 2000-34, 5-1-2000; amd. 2003 Code) 
C.  Powers And Duties: The corporate authorities shall have the management, care, operation and control of the city cemeteries known as Oak Hill cemetery and West Side cemetery. The corporate authorities are authorized and empowered to sell, from time to time, places for single graves, also lots or blocks of ground for burial purposes in the city cemeteries and to receive payment therefor. They may receive in trust from the proprietors or owners of any lot in the cemetery, or any person interested in the maintenance of the cemetery, and gift or legacy of any money or property, either real, personal or mixed, which may be donated to the city for the use and maintenance of the lot or cemetery. The corporate authorities may convert property donated into money and invest the same in the endowed care funds, as provided in section 8-6-5 of this chapter. All conveyances of lots, blocks or single graves so sold shall be signed by the mayor and city clerk. 
D.  Maintenance: The city cemeteries shall be maintained and cared for by the department of public works under the supervision and direction of the director of public works. (Ord. 2000-34, 5-1-2000) 
8-6-3: - PROHIBITED ACTS: 
It shall be unlawful for any person to establish a cemetery or to bury any person within the city limits, or within one mile thereof, except in an established cemetery. (Ord. 2000-34, 5-1-2000) 
8-6-4: - SALE OF CEMETERY LOTS: 
A.  All prices for the sale of single graves, lots or blocks in city cemeteries shall be fixed and regulated by the corporate authorities. 
B.  One-half (1/2) of the amount realized form the sales of lots or blocks in the cemeteries shall be used for the general care and upkeep of such cemeteries. The remaining one-half (1/2) of the purchase price shall be placed in the endowed care funds as provided for in section 8-6-5 of this chapter. The portion of sales placed in the endowed care fund shall be invested by the city treasurer and the income therefrom shall be used for the upkeep of the lots and blocks so sold. (Ord. 2000-34, 5-1-2000) 
8-6-5: - ENDOWED CARE FUNDS: 
The corporate authorities are hereby authorized and empowered to receive, in trust, from the proprietors or owners of any grave, lot or block of ground in the city cemeteries, or any person interested in the maintenance of the same, any sum of money, by gift or bequest, which sums shall be deposited with the city treasurer and shall be kept separate and apart from all other city funds. Such funds shall be known as the "Endowed Care of Oak Hill and West Side Cemeteries". The city treasurer shall, from time to time, invest said endowed care fund in interest bearing securities as may be approved by the corporate authorities. The income derived from such investments shall be used only for the perpetual care and maintenance of the graves, lots or blocks of ground, respectively, in the city cemeteries. (Ord. 2000-34, 5-1-2000) 
CHAPTER 7 - PARKING FACILITIES NEAR RAILROAD STATION 
SECTION: 

8-7-1: - DEFINITIONS: 
Whenever in this chapter the following terms are used, they shall have the following meanings: 
PARKING AREA: The said area as shown on the map on file with the office of the city clerk, which map is made a part of this chapter. PARKING METERS: A mechanical device located upon the parking meter zone in a place regularly designated as a parking zone and as hereinafter defined in subsection 8-7-4A of this chapter, for which parking privileges may be extended to the person depositing coins. PARKING METER 
ZONE: A certain designated and marked off section of the parking area with marked boundaries where the vehicle or vehicles may be temporarily parked and allowed to remain for such period of time as the parking meter thereto may designate. PERMIT PARKING 
ZONE: A certain designated and marked off section of the parking area with marked boundaries where the vehicle or vehicles may be temporarily parked and allowed to remain for such periods of time as set forth in subsection 8-7-5A of this chapter, provided a valid parking permit is displayed. VEHICLE: Any device by which any person or property may be transported upon a public street, except those operated upon rails, permanent tracks, or with more than two (2) axles. (1975 Code App. B § 1)  
8-7-2: - INTENT: 
It is the intent and purpose of the city council to provide within the parking area certain sections which require either: 
A.  The payment of a per diem fee for the privilege to park a vehicle during designated hours by use of parking meters; or 
B.  A parking permit for the privilege to park a vehicle on a monthly basis during designated hours and days of the month. (1975 Code App. B § 2) 
8-7-3: - TIME LIMITS ESTABLISHED: 
The city council shall fix the time limitations for legal parking in parking meter zones and parking permit zones and the hours during the day when the parking meters or permits must be used and when the time limitations shall be effective, in compliance with the provisions of this chapter, and shall indicate the time limitations by designating the same on the parking meter or meters, or by appropriate signs posted in proximity to said meters in said zone or in proximity to said parking permit zone. (1975 Code App. B § 3) 
8-7-4: - PARKING METER ZONES: 
A.  Placement Of Parking Meters: The parking meters shall be designated and placed so as to provide one central location ("meter panel") for several individual meters. Each individual parking place shall be marked with a sign or placard indicating the specific number of said place, which shall correspond with a numbered individual meter within the meter panel. Each parking meter panel shall indicate by proper legend the legal parking time established by the city and shall indicate the duration of the period of legal parking time, and the expiration of such period shall indicate that parking in such location is illegal. 
B.  Areas Marked: The director of public works shall have markings painted or placed (in front of or adjacent to) each parking meter for the purpose of designating the parking space for which each meter shall be used, and each vehicle must park within the lines or markings so established. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter to park such vehicle in such position that the same shall not be entirely within the area so designated by such line or marking. 
C.  Rates; Parking In Excess Of Maximum Time: Each meter panel installed as provided herein shall show thereon the maximum time limit for parking in the space for which each meter panel is installed. Each meter panel shall provide for the insertion and deposit of United States money in the form of a coin or coins and shall indicate thereon the period of parking time covered by the coin or coins. The rate established at this time shall be as follows: (i) a charge of two dollars ($2.00) for a 24-hour parking period within the city's parking deck located east of Third Street and north of the Union Pacific Railroad main line, and (ii) a charge of one dollar and seventy-five cents ($1.75) for a 24-hour parking period for the parking lot lying east of Illinois State Rte 31 and south of the Union Pacific Railroad main line. There shall be no parking charge within the city's parking deck during the following periods: (a) 4:00 p.m. to 11:59 p.m., Monday through Friday, and (b) 12:00 a.m. on Saturday to 11:59 p.m. on Sundays. It shall be the duty of any person parking any vehicle in any parking space herein provided for to deposit in such meter a coin or coins sufficient to cover the period of time such vehicle is continuously parked in such space. It shall be unlawful to park or cause to be parked any vehicle in any space provided for herein for a period in excess of the maximum time affixed for continuously parking by this chapter or any amendment to this chapter. 
D.  Deposit Of Coin Required: When any vehicle shall be parked in any space designated as a parking zone, the operator of said vehicle, upon entering the parking space, shall immediately deposit a coin or coins of the United States, and failure to deposit a coin or coins sufficient to put the meter in operation shall constitute a violation of this chapter and shall subject such person to the penalties herein described. 
E.  Meters Kept In Good Order: It shall be the duty of the corporate authorities of the city to keep the meters in good working order and to provide for supervision, inspection and necessary repair thereof. 
F.  Damaging Meters Prohibited: It shall be unlawful and a violation of the provisions of this chapter for any person to deface, injure, tamper with, open or willfully break, destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking meter installed under the provisions of this chapter. 
G.  Depositing Slugs Prohibited: It shall be unlawful and a violation of the provisions of this chapter to deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking meter any slug, device or mechanical substitute for a coin or coins of the United States. 
H.  Head-In Parking: It shall be unlawful and a violation of the provision of this chapter to park any vehicle in a parking space in other than a head-in position, except where parallel parking is provided, so that the front of a vehicle is at or near the curb or retaining bumper of a parking space. (1975 Code App. B § 4; amd. 2003 Code; Ord. No. 2010-27, § 1, 5-17-2010; Ord. No. 2010-33, § 1, 8-16-2010; Ord. No. 2012-57, § 1, 12-17-2012) 
8-7-5: - PERMIT PARKING ZONES: 
A.  Permit Parking Areas: Permit parking area signs shall be erected in permit parking areas. Such signs shall be of such character as to inform motorists that designated areas require permits. 
B.  Only vehicles displaying a parking permit authorized by this chapter may park in a permit parking area, except on Saturdays, Sundays and City observed holidays. 
C.  Issuance Of Parking Permit; Display: Upon the applicant's payment of permit fee set forth below and the submission of a completed and validated parking permit application, the applicant shall receive one (1) parking permit. An applicant for a parking permit must be the holder of a valid driver's license. No parking permit shall be issued to an applicant who has one (1) or more delinquent and unpaid parking ticket or citation with the City. Such parking permit shall be displayed from the rearview mirror of the vehicle. Failure to display said permit parking tags shall be a violation of this chapter and subject to the penalties set forth below. 
D.  Application; Contents: An application for a parking permit on which the applicant is to provide the following information for one (1) vehicle to receive a parking permit shall include: 
1.  The name and residential address of the owner of the vehicle; home and work telephone numbers of the applicant; and 
2.  The signature of the applicant. 
E.  Parking Permit Fee: Parking permits shall be issued by the police department of the City on a quarterly basis, i.e., first quarter (September through November), second quarter (December through February), third quarter (March through May), and fourth quarter (June through August). Each quarter year parking permit or tag shall be color coded. The permit parking fee for each quarter year shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) for residents of the City of Geneva and one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00) for non-residents. The fee shall be prorated at one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50) per business day for each partial quarter thereof. 
F.  Renewal Of Parking Permits: Upon a parking permit holder's payment of a renewal fee, the return or surrender of the old parking permit and his fulfillment of all applicable provisions of this chapter controlling the issuance renewal of a permit on or before the expiration date of the existing parking permit, the holder shall receive a new parking permit for the next quarter. The police department shall mail to existing permit holders notices of expiration and renewal not less than two (2) weeks prior to the commencement of a new quarter. It shall be the duty and responsibility of existing permit holders to reapply for renewal of permits and the failure of a holder to reapply within two (2) days of the permit expiration date shall result in forfeiture of any right or interest to a renewal permit. No renewal permit shall be issued to an applicant or permit holder for a vehicle which has any delinquent and unpaid parking ticket or citation in the City. 
(1975 Code, App. B, § 5; Amd. 2003 Code; Ord. No. 2008-20, § 1, 4-21-2008; Ord. No. 2016-23, § 2, 6-20-2016) 
8-7-6: - RESERVED PARKING SPACES: 
Four (4) vehicular parking spaces (reserved spaces), located at the southwest corner of the city owned parking lot commonly known as the former Seigle lumber yard and generally located at the southwest corner of Crescent Street and South Fourth Street, are hereby reserved for daily parking permits to residents of the City of Geneva, subject to the following conditions: 
A.  A person, over the age of eighteen (18) years, who maintains a personal residence within the corporate limits of the City of Geneva may apply, at the Geneva police station (Twenty Police Plaza, Geneva, Illinois), for the issuance of one daily parking permit per day for a reserved space, at a fee of two dollars fifty cents ($2.50) per day, on a first come, first served basis. No such resident may apply for a daily permit earlier than fourteen (14) days prior to the date requested for such permit. No such resident may apply for more than five (5) daily permits at one time. 
B.  The daily permit issued by the City shall be valid only for the day applied for and may only be used by the resident or his/her immediate family member residing at the residence. A permit shall not be transferable or resold to any other person. A resident may obtain an application form from the police department or the city's internet web site (www.geneva.il.us), however, all application forms must be submitted, in person, to the Geneva police department. At the time of submittal of the application, the applicant must provide proof of his or her personal residency within the corporate limits of Geneva such as a valid state of Illinois driver's license. 
C.  Upon issuance of a permit, a permit holder must prominently display the permit in the vehicle by hanging the permit from the rearview mirror. A permit holder shall be permitted to park his or her vehicle between the hours of six forty five o'clock (6:45) A.M. and twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight on the designated permit date. 
D.  It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle in a reserved parking space without a permit, except on a Saturday, Sunday or holiday. 
E.  Any person accused of a violation of this section may settle and compromise the claim of violation against him or her by paying to the city, within ten (10) days of the time such alleged violation or offense was committed, the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) for each such violation or offense. Consecutive violations of the aforesaid violations or offenses shall be treated as separate offenses. In addition to the aforestated penalty, the police department and all members thereof assigned to traffic duty are hereby authorized to remove and tow away or have removed and towed away by a commercial towing service pursuant to the provisions of section 7-3-9 of this code, any motor vehicle parked in violation of this section. (Ord. 2003-22, 4-7-2003) 
8-7-7: - COLLECTION OF MONIES: 
The city council shall appoint a collector and shall designate such methods as are necessary to properly collect all coins deposited in the parking meters. All money so collected shall be deposited with the city treasurer. (1975 Code App. B § 6) 
8-7-8: - OVERTIME OR PROHIBITED PARKING VIOLATIONS: 
A.  Each police officer or member of the police department shall attach to such a vehicle a notice to the owner or operator thereof that such vehicle has been parking in violation of a provision of this chapter and shall instruct such owner or operator to report to the police station of the City in reference to such violation. 
B.  Any person accused of a violation of section 8-7-4 of this chapter, or any subsection thereof, prohibiting parking a vehicle in a parking meter zone, or restricting the length of time a vehicle may be parked therein, may settle and compromise the claim against said person for such illegal prohibited parking by paying to the city, within ten (10) days of the time such alleged offense was committed, the sum of: 
Prohibited parking or exceeding the time limit of the metered zone $10.00 In the event such claim is not paid within 10 days after the issuance of a citation therefor, the claim for each said offense 20.00  
If the aforesaid claims are not paid within thirty (30) days, a warrant (summons) for the arrest of the offender will be issued without further notice. Such payment of claims or fines shall be made at the police station of the city, or in the fine/deposit boxes located upon the streets of the city, and such funds shall be promptly turned over to the city treasurer to be credited to the general corporate fund. 
In addition to the fine set forth in this subsection, members of the police department are hereby authorized to remove, or have removed, a vehicle from the permit parking zone to a storage impound location designated by the police department when a vehicle is parked within a parking permit zone and no parking permit is properly displayed as required and provided in subsection 8-7-5C of this chapter. Whenever an officer removes or has removed a vehicle from a permit parking zone, such officer shall prepare a notice to such owner of the fact of such removal and the reasons therefor and place a notice upon the vehicle. In the event such vehicle is stored in a storage impound, a copy of such notice shall be given to the proprietor of such impound. In the event the owner does not claim the vehicle within three (3) days after issuance of the notice, then and in the event the officer shall send or cause to be sent a written report of such removal, by mail, to the state department whose duty it is to register motor vehicles, and shall file a copy of such notice with the proprietor of the vehicle impound in which the vehicle may be stored. Such notice shall include a complete description of the vehicle, the date, time and place from which removed, the reasons for such removal and the name of the vehicle impound or place where the vehicle is stored. No person shall recover any vehicle removed in accordance with this section except as provided herein. Before the owner or person in charge of such vehicle shall be allowed to recover it from the place where it has been placed or impounded, he shall present to a member of the police department evidence of his identity and the right to possession of the vehicle, shall sign a receipt for its return, shall pay the cost of removal, and shall pay any cost of storage accrued. 
C.  It shall be the duty of the police department to keep a record of each vehicle removed in accordance with this section. The record shall include a description of the vehicle, its license number, the date and time of its removal, where it was removed from, its location, the name and address of its owner and operator, if known, its final disposition, and the parking violation involved. 
(1975, Code App. B, § 8; amd. 2003 Code) 
8-7-9: - APPLICABILITY OF CHAPTER: 
This chapter shall not be construed as repealing any other chapter or section or provision thereof regulating use of the streets or traffic thereon, or fixing a maximum time limit for continuous parking upon any street or part thereof, and said chapter shall apply only to parking meters located on the streets described on exhibit A, which is on file in the office of the city clerk. (1975 Code App. B § 9)

CHAPTER 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
SECTION: 

9-1-1: - APPLICATION FOR SERVICE: 
A.  Application: Application for any municipal utility services or uses, including, potable water, sanitary sewer, and/or electric (collectively referred to as "municipal utility services") requested, pursuant to this title shall be made in writing to the Finance Division. Every application shall contain a unilateral agreement by the applicant to abide by and accept all of the provisions of this title as conditions governing the use of and/or service from the city's utility services. 
B.  Service Deposits: 
1.  Amount Of Deposit: The amount of the deposit shall be: 
Residential customer: (houses, mobile homes, apartments, permanent multi-family dwellings): A deposit of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be collected at time of application for each service applied for, e.g. potable water, sanitary sewer or electric. Potable water and sanitary sewer service shall be considered, for the purpose of a deposit, one (1) service. A deposit may be waived by the Finance Manager or designee if the applicant is a current Geneva customer moving to a new residence within the city and has demonstrated satisfactory payment history at the former address during two (2) of the past five (5) years. The deposit requirement may be waived by the Finance Manager or designee for landlords where the property will be transferred to their name for a short period of time. 
Commercial or industrial customer: A deposit of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) shall be collected at time of application for service for each service applied for, e.g. potable water, sanitary sewer or electric. Potable water and sanitary sewer service shall be considered, for the purpose of a deposit, one (1) service A deposit may be waived by the Finance Manager or designee if the applicant is a current Geneva business/industrial customer moving to a new location within the city and has demonstrated a satisfactory payment history at the former address during two (2) of the past five (5) years. The deposit requirement may be waived by the Finance Manager or designee for landlords where the property will be transferred to their name for a short period of time. 
2.  The following applies to all service deposits referenced in 9-1-1 B. 
a.  Apply To Delinquent Bills: A deposit may be applied to any bill for any usage which is delinquent more than thirty (30) days. 
b.  Forfeiture of Deposit: When a customer's account is delinquent and assigned to a collection agency, the deposit will be forfeited by the customer and the unpaid balance of the account will be turned over to a collection agency. 
c.  Return of Deposit: After a period of two (2) consecutive years of satisfactory payment for service or upon termination of all municipal utility services with no outstanding account balance, any deposit balance shall be returned to the customer without interest. In an instance where real property has been abandoned and there is unpaid, delinquent account, the deposit shall be forfeited to the city as an administrative termination service fee and the unpaid account balance shall remain due, owing and subject to collection. 
d.  Vacation of Premises By Renter: Where a renter (tenant) has vacated the real property to which utility service is being furnished and no new renter is in possession, then the account in question will be transferred into the name of the owner (landlord) of the real property. 
(Ord. No. 2013-36, § 1(Exh. A), 10-21-2013; Ord. No. 2014-15, § 1, 6-2-2014; Ord. No. 2016-46, § 1, 12-19-2016; Ord. No. 2018-10, § 1, 5-7-2018; Ord. No. 2018-11, § 1, 5-7-2018) 
9-1-2: - BILLING PROCEDURES: 
A.  Meter Readings: Meters will be read periodically. For the purposes of this section, the term "periodic" or "periodically" shall mean the period between any two (2) consecutive regular meter readings taken, which reading may occur during intervals of less than, or more than, thirty (30) days. The customer shall be billed after each meter reading. 
B.  Date Of Billing; Payments: Bills for service or use of the city's utilities shall be dated and sent monthly, by mail, electronically or such other means which is acceptable to the city and the customer. Bills shall be due and payable within twenty (20) days after the date of the bill. 
1.  Delinquent Payment: A delinquent payment charge of ten percent (10%) of the unpaid bill shall be added to the bill after twenty (20) days from the issuance date of the bill. Two (2) delinquent payment charges per calendar year may be waived by the finance manager or designee at the request of the customer. Additional delinquent payment charges may be waived by the city administrator or designee only in extenuating circumstances at the written request of the customer. The decision to grant additional waiver of delinquent payment charges rests solely with the city administrator or designee. 
2.  Dishonored Checks: Any customer who presents a check to the city which is subsequently returned by the customer's bank for any reason shall be subject to charges and fees set forth the provision of Section 1-8-9 of the City Code. 
C.  Liability For Payment: The owner of the premises being provided municipal utility service, the occupant thereof and the customer who uses the municipal utilities shall be jointly and severally liability for payment of any bill rendered by the city for such service or use. 
1.  Vacation Of Premises By Renter: Where a renter has vacated or abandoned the premises to which municipal utility service is being supplied, and no new renter is in possession, then the municipal utility service account for the premises shall be transferred to and in the name of the owner of the premises. 
D.  Delinquent Bills: 
1.  Discontinuation Of Service. The city shall have the right to discontinue its municipal utility services, or any of them, to the customer, on due notice, and to remove its property from the customer's premise whenever the utility bills are in arrears, or when the customer fails to comply with or perform any of the conditions or obligations of this title. 
a.  Disconnection And Reconnection Fees. In the event utility bills(s) is in excess of fifty dollars ($50.00) remains delinquent and unpaid for a period of thirty (30) days, the finance division shall order the subject utility service to be discontinued due to nonpayment of the bill and an administrative fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) shall be paid to the city before service is reconnected and reinstated to the delinquent customer; provided, however, (i) if service is reinstated between the hours of 2:30 p.m. and 11:59 p.m., the administrative fee shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00), (ii) if service is reinstated between the hours of midnight and 6:59 a.m., on a Sunday, or on a designated city holiday, the administrative fee shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00). All administrative fees shall be in addition to payment in full for all outstanding monies owed by the delinquent customer, including any late charges or fees. 
b.  Exceptions To Disconnection Of Electrical Utility Service: No electric service furnished by the City to residential users shall be terminated for nonpayment of bills on: 
1.  Any day when the National Weather Service's forecast for the following twenty-four (24) hours covering the Geneva, Illinois area includes a forecast that the temperature will be twenty degrees Fahrenheit (20°F) or below; or 
2.  Any day when the National Weather Service's forecast for the following twenty-four (24) hours covering the Geneva area includes a forecast that the temperature will be 95 degrees Fahrenheit (95°F) or above. 
c.  Exceptions To Disconnection Of All Municipal Utility Services: The disconnection of municipal utility service to a customer will not be performed on the day prior to or immediately following a city observed holiday or a weekend (Saturday and Sunday). 
d.  Disconnection Of Certain Multi-Family Residences: Pursuant to the Rental Property Utility Service Act [765 ILCS 735/0.01 et seq.] the city shall not terminate any municipal utility service to buildings with three (3) or more residential apartments which are served by a common system of water, sewer or electrical services that goes through a common meter in a single building, until such time as the property has been posted no less than ten (10) days prior to the date of termination of said service. 
e.  Disconnection of Multi-Tenant Commercial/Industrial Properties: The city shall not terminate any municipal utility service to buildings with three (3) or more commercial/industrial units which are served by a common system of water, sewer or electrical services that goes through a common meter in a single building, until such time as the property has been posted no less than ten (10) days prior to the date of termination of said service. 
2.  Collection of Delinquent Accounts: In addition thereto, costs shall be assessed against each lien filed and recorded. These costs shall include the direct costs incurred by the city as assessed by the statutory notification requirements and county recorder and include a release of lien fee in the amount as assessed by the county recorder; the city, at no additional costs to the user, shall obtain, on user's behalf, the release of lien. 
E.  Turn-On And Turn-Off Charges (Water): Whenever the water supply to a water connection is shut off at the request of the owner of the premises on Saturday or Monday-Friday between the hours of 2:30 p.m. and 11:59 p.m. the city shall charge an administrative fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for water turn-off. If reinstatement of the water connection is completed within two (2) hours of the water turn-off, no fee will be charge for reinstatement. Should a reinstatement take longer than two (2) hours an additional administrative fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) will be assessed. Requests for connection shut off occurring between the hours of midnight and 6:59 a.m., or a Sunday, or on a designated city holiday, the administrative fee shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). If reinstatement of the water connection is completed within two (2) hours of the water turn-off, no fee will be charged for reinstatement. Reinstatements taking longer than two (2) hours will be assessed an additional administrative fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
All fees shall be assessed to the utility account. 
(Ord. No. 2013-36, § 1(Exh. A), 10-21-2013; Ord. No. 2015-19, §§ 1, 2, 7-20-2015; Ord. No. 2018-04, § 1, 2-20-2018; Ord. No. 2018-18, §§ 1, 2, 6-18-2018) 
CHAPTER 2 - MUNICIPAL ELECTRICAL SERVICE 
SECTION: 

9-2-1: - MUNICIPAL ELECTRIC UTILITY ESTABLISHED: 
There is hereby established a municipal electrical utility for the City of Geneva ("city"), referred to herein as the "municipal electric utility", a division of the public works department of the city, which shall have charge of the generation and/or purchase, distribution and sale of all electrical energy within the corporate limits of the city, or distribution lines connected to the electrical distribution system outside the corporate limits of the city, for the purpose of interconnecting and looping of the distribution system; to exercise all the powers of a municipal electrical utility as set forth in the Illinois Municipal Code. [2] 
(Ord. No. 2013-36, § 1(Exh. A), 10-21-2013) 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
65 ILCS 5/11-117-1 et seq. 

9-2-2: - APPLICABILITY OF CHAPTER: 
The general conditions set forth in this chapter shall apply to all customers served by the municipal electric utility. 
(Ord. No. 2013-36, § 1(Exh. A), 10-21-2013) 
CHAPTER 2 
MUNICIPAL ELECTRICAL SERVICE 
ARTICLE A. - DEFINITIONS; CONDITIONS OF SERVICE 
SECTION: 

9-2A-1: - DEFINITIONS: 
A.  Customer: Any person, partnership, corporation or other legal entity that has a contractual or other arrangement with the municipal electric utility whereby the municipal electric utility provides electric service to customer premises. 
B.  Customer's Premises: Any land, space or area, e.g., single-family residence, apartment, condominium, store, office, factory, etc., which is to be occupied by a customer and which is served by one or more separate customer electrical distribution systems. 
C.  Service: "Service" or "electric service" is used in its broadest and most inclusive sense, and includes not only the use or accommodation afforded customers, but also "any product or commodity furnished by the municipal electric utility; and the plant, equipment, apparatus, property and facilities employed by, or in connection with, municipal electric utility performing any service or in furnishing any product or commodity and devoted to the purposes in which municipal electric utility is engaged and to the use and accommodation of the public. 
D.  Electric Distribution System: All plants owned by the electric utility that is used to provide electric service to its customers, including, but not limited to, switches, transformers, poles, pedestals, meters, wires, cables, anchors, junction boxes, vaults, manholes, hand holes and street lights. 
(Ord. No. 2013-36, § 1(Exh. A), 10-21-2013) 
9-2A-2: - INTERRUPTION OF SERVICE: 
The municipal electric utility shall not be responsible for damages, including consequential or incidental damages, for any failure to supply electricity or for interruption or reversal of the supply except in those instances when the interruption or reversal of supply is caused because of the willful misconduct of the City. 
(Ord. No. 2013-36, § 1(Exh. A), 10-21-2013) 
9-2A-3: - ACCESS TO PREMISES: 
The properly authorized agents of the municipal electric utility shall at all reasonable hours have free access to the customer's premises for the purpose of reading, examining, repairing or removing the utility's meters or other property. 
(Ord. No. 2013-36, § 1(Exh. A), 10-21-2013) 
9-2A-4: - CONDITIONS OF SERVICE: 
A.  Ownership Of Property And Equipment; Maintenance: All meters, transformers, poles, structures and other facilities placed on the customer's premises by the municipal electric utility for the purpose of rendering electric service to such premises, unless otherwise expressly provided, shall be and remain the property of the municipal electric utility, and the customer shall exercise reasonable care to protect such property from loss or damage. When there is a change in the customer's operation or construction, which in the judgment of the municipal electric utility makes the relocation of the facilities necessary, or if relocation is requested by the customer, the municipal electric utility will move such facilities at the customer's expense to a mutually acceptable location on the premises. Customers shall be required to grant a public utility easement for any electric or fiber installation on their property. 
B.  Use Of Other Service Prohibited; Exception: No other electric light or power service shall be used by the customer on the same installation in conjunction with the municipal electric utility service, either by means of a "throw over" switch or any other connection, except in cases where the customer has electric generating equipment which is utilized only in the event of interruption in the utility service or by permit of the superintendent of electrical services. Customer shall pay for any special ("net") metering arrangements required to allow for proper operation of the generating equipment as determined by the utility. See city's interconnection policy for more information. 
C.  Furnishing Electricity For Resale: The city will not furnish electricity for resale by any customer. 
D.  Use Of Existing Transformer Facilities: The city's policy on the use of existing transformer facilities will be as follows: 
1.  Any new customers as of November 1, 2013, if the transformer is downstream of a primary metering installation, shall be responsible for all maintenance and replacement costs of such transformer. If there is no primary metering installation, then the city is responsible for maintenance and replacement costs of the transformer. All commercial and industrial customers own and maintain all secondary wire from the transformer to the building whether it is primary or secondary metered. Exceptions to this policy exist at 2089 Pillsbury Drive, 300 Glengarry Drive, and 737 Peyton Street where the customer owns all facilities downstream of the primary metering. 
It shall be the responsibility of institutional, commercial and light industrial customers to pay for all transformer equipment, except metering equipment. Large industrial customers requiring transformers larger than 2500 KVA shall furnish such transformer equipment and the municipal electric utility's metering equipment shall be placed on the primary side of the customer's transformers. 
2.  Any additional transformer capacity required by the customer shall be provided for at the customer's expense. 
3.  Existing rental agreements between the city and industrial customers shall be valid for the duration of such agreements. 
(Ord. No. 2013-36, § 1(Exh. A), 10-21-2013) 
CHAPTER 2 
MUNICIPAL ELECTRICAL SERVICE 
ARTICLE B. - SERVICES, RATES AND CHARGES 
SECTION: 

9-2B-1: - APPLICATION OF ARTICLE: 
The following rates are hereby established and applicable to all customers served by the municipal electric utility, except that outstanding electrical service contracts dated prior to the date of this section shall remain in force until the expiration date of said contracts. The city council may extend or amend any outstanding contracts with customers within the city prior to the original expiration date of the outstanding contract. The following alphabetical designations used in this article shall have the meaning assigned to each: kW = kilowatt, kWh = kilowatt hour. 
(Ord. No. 2013-36, § 1(Exh. A), 10-21-2013) 
9-2B-2: - DEFINITIONS: 
For the purposes of this article, the following words or terms shall be defined as follows: 
A.  Residential Customers And General Service Commercial Customers With Demand Up To 25 kW: 
1.  Energy Charge: Variable/energy cost component of the wholesale purchase of electric power from generator. 
2.  Demand Charge: Fixed/demand cost component of wholesale purchases of electric power from generator. 
3.  Transmission Demand Charge: Transportation cost to transfer electric power from wholesale generator to city's electric substations. 
4.  Distribution Charge: Costs incurred by the city to provide service and maintenance of its electric utility distribution system. 
5.  Total Energy Charge: Total cost to provide electric power to the customer's meter. 
6.  Customer Charge: Cost to read meters and prepare bills as well as maintain customer service connections and metering installations. 
B.  All Customers With Demand Of 25 kW Or Over: 
1.  Energy Charge: Variable/energy cost component of the wholesale purchase of electric power from generator. 
a.  Supply Charge: Cost of wholesale energy purchases of electric power from generator. 
b.  Losses: Electric energy consumed in delivery of electric power to customer's meter. Varies by class of customer. 
c.  Total Energy Charge: Total cost to provide electric power to customer's meter. 
2.  Demand Charge: 
a.  Supply Costs: Fixed/Demand cost associated with the purchase of electric power from generator. 
b.  Transmission Costs: Costs associated with delivery of electric power from the generator plant to the City's substations. 
3.  Customer Charge: Cost to read meters and prepare bills as well as maintenance of customer service connections and metering installations. 
(Ord. No. 2013-36, § 1(Exh. A), 10-21-2013) 
9-2B-3: - ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT: 
A.  Furnished And Maintained By Customer: Except as otherwise provided herein, all wiring and other electrical equipment on the premises or connecting the premises with the municipal electric utility's service, furnished by the customer shall be suitable for the purpose thereof, and shall be installed and maintained by the customer at all times in conformity with the requirements of the National Board of Fire Underwriters and the current edition of the National Electrical Code. 
B.  Interference By Equipment: Any customer served whose utilizing equipment has characteristics which, in the municipal electric utility's judgment, may cause interference with service of other customers or result in the operation at a lower power factor below eighty-five percent (85%) lagging, the customer shall, at the request of the superintendent of electrical services provide suitable facilities to preclude such interference or improve such power factor, or both, as the case may be. Otherwise, the utility shall have the right to provide, at the expense of the customer, the facilities necessary to preclude such condition or conditions. Where, for any reason, facilities in excess of a normal installation are provided by the utility, such facilities shall be installed, maintained and operated in accordance with a properly executed agreement with the city. 
(Ord. No. 2013-36, § 1(Exh. A), 10-21-2013) 
9-2B-4: - GENERAL CONDITIONS GOVERNING ALL USERS: 
A.  Tax Adjustment Charge: A charge shall be made in addition to the above charges, based upon the percentage tax on total utility revenue imposed by the state. 
B.  Term Of Service: The customer's term of service shall commence when service is established and shall continue not more than ten (10) days after notice is received to discontinue service. 
C.  Minimum Bill: The minimum bill shall be the customer charge as designated in the table of rates. 
D.  Rate, Per Month: Customer, energy, transmission and distribution charges for kilowatt hours (kWh) and demand (KW) charges supplied on a monthly basis shall be as set out in the rate table. For the purposes hereof, the summer months shall be the customer's first monthly billing period with an ending meter reading date on or after June 15, and the three (3) succeeding monthly billing periods. 
(Ord. No. 2013-36, § 1(Exh. A), 10-21-2013)

A.  The following table incorporates electric energy and demand rates for residential, general service and industrial customers for the period commencing May 6, 2013. Rates are in effect until otherwise modified.

B.  Power Cost Adjustment Clause: Energy charges for the current month shall be adjusted by the amount of a power cost adjustment factor to reflect the preceding calendar month's cost of power as compared to a base cost as described below: 
Power cost adjustment factor = PCAF = Fm/Sm - PCAC base factor 
The PCAC base factor is $0.07556 
Where Fm = the cost of power in the preceding calendar month includes: 
1.  The cost of wholesale purchased power. 
2.  The charges and credits as billed or credited by the regional transmission operator. 
3.  Charges for fuel actually used at Geneva Generation Facility. 
4.  Charges for transportation of fuel used at Geneva Generation Facility. 
5.  Other variable Geneva Generation Facility expenses related to generation. 
Where Sm = all kWh retail sales for the preceding billing month. 
(Ord. No. 2013-36, § 1(Exh. A), 10-21-2013; Ord. No. 2014-14a, § 1, 6-16-2014) 
9-2B-6: - RESIDENTIAL RATES: 
A.  Availability: The residential service rate shall be available to all meters servicing a residential dwelling used solely for residential purposes, other than total space heating during heating season. 
B.  Service Facilities: A normal installation shall consist of single-phase facilities only, except that a 3-phase service drop and meter will be furnished and installed if reasonably available, and 3-phase transformer capacity will be provided in lieu of equivalent single-phase facilities if the customer pays the additional cost of facilities for 3-phase service if reasonably available. 3-phase service will be provided only upon prior approval of the superintendent of electrical services. 
C.  General: The customer's wiring shall be so arranged that all service hereunder may be supplied through a single metering installation. Service hereunder will be furnished only to a single occupancy, and where service to an apartment building is desired, each apartment shall be treated as a separate customer and served through a separate metering installation; provided, however, that in apartment buildings containing six (6) or fewer apartments, hall lights and building operating equipment, including no motor larger than one horsepower and not more than six (6) horsepower for all motors, may be connected to the metering installation for one of the apartments, or service for such lights and equipment may be furnished under this rate to the building operator as a separate customer. All rates are subject to all general policies affecting the collection, administration and operation of the city municipal electric utility. 
(Ord. No. 2013-36, § 1(Exh. A), 10-21-2013) 
9-2B-7: - GENERAL SERVICE RATE: 
A.  Availability: The general service rate shall be available to all commercial, institutional, industrial and for common house meters in multi-dwelling residential uses for all electric use up to twenty-five (25) kW in demand. Also, the general service rate shall be available to institutional consumers with more than twenty-five (25) kW demand by special permission of the city. 
B.  Service Facilities: A normal installation shall consist of single-phase facilities only, except that a 3-phase service drop and meter will be furnished and installed where reasonably available and 3-phase transformer capacity will be provided in lieu of equivalent single-phase facilities where reasonably available. The size of transformers furnished by the electric utility shall be as stated in subsection 9-2A-4D of this chapter. 
C.  General: The customer's wiring shall be so arranged that all service hereunder may be supplied through a single metering installation. Service hereunder will be furnished only to a single occupancy customer and for billing purposes each metering installation shall be billed as a single customer. Meter readings of various locations will not be combined for billing purposes. 
(Ord. No. 2013-36, § 1(Exh. A), 10-21-2013) 
9-2B-8: - MEDIUM GENERAL SERVICE RATE: 
A.  Availability: The medium general service rate shall be available to all customers with demands in excess of twenty-five (25) kW, but less than four hundred (400) kW. 
B.  Billing Demand: The billing demand shall be the maximum measured 30-minute integrated demand in the month. 
C.  Measurement Of Demand And Energy: When there are two (2) or more demand and energy metering installations on the customer's premises, the metered quantities shall be combined for billing purposes. Demands should be added in a manner to determine the combined 30-minute coincident peak. However, maximum kW demands and kWh supplied at two (2) or more premises will not be combined for billing purposes. 
D.  Secondary Metering Adjustment: The city shall have the option of metering at the primary or secondary side of the transformers. When the measurement of demand and energy is at 7200-volts or higher, no adjustment shall be necessary since the rate schedule is intended for primary service When the measurement of demand and energy is below 7200-volts, the metered quantities shall be increased by two percent (2%). 
E.  Service Facilities: A normal installation shall consist of a single-phase or 3-phase service drop and metering installation. Service voltage shall be 120/240 single-phase, 120/208 three-phase, 480/277 three phase or 12,470/7200 wye three phase. The customer pays for all transformation unless the service drop is at 12470/7200 volts in which case no transformation is needed. All primary metering equipment will be furnished and maintained by the city. Where an additional point of delivery is required other than for the convenience of the customer, the facilities incident thereto shall be furnished by the city as part of a normal installation. Each normal installation shall include facilities for one standard transformation. All transformers up to 2500 KVA shall be furnished by the city and paid for by the customer. Other than the above, the type of facilities comprising a normal installation, including meters, shall be determined by the city's customary policies and practices. The customer pays for all labor, equipment and material required to install service to the facility. Any new customers as of November 1, 2013, if the transformer is downstream of a primary metering installation, shall be responsible for all maintenance and replacement costs of such transformer. 
F.  General: The customer's wiring shall be so arranged that all service hereunder may be supplied through a single metering installation. Service hereunder will be furnished only to a single occupancy customer and where service to multi-occupancy premises is desired hereunder, each customer shall be treated as a separate customer and serviced through a separate metering installation. The combination of meter reading at several premises for billing purposes will not be permitted. Each meter installation shall be treated as a separate customer for billing purposes. This rate is subject to all general policies affecting the collection, administration and operation of the city municipal electric utility. 
G.  Governmental Outdoor Lighting: The demand charge for customers providing outdoor lighting intended for governmental recreational purposes, shall be suspended when said governmental outdoor recreation lighting use occurs after 6:00 p.m. Said use shall be subject to voluntary interruption of service at the request of the superintendent of electrical services based upon the need to avoid coincidental peak demand with the city's electric distribution system. If the customer refuses to voluntarily interrupt service, the demand charge shall be applied. Said notice of interruption shall be given to the user(s) at least two (2) hours in advance of the interruption. In order to qualify for said demand suspension, the customer metering and wiring configuration shall segregate the outdoor lighting use to provide for separate metering and billing, which metering and configuration shall be made at the customer's expense. 
(Ord. No. 2013-36, § 1(Exh. A), 10-21-2013) 
9-2B-9: - LARGE GENERAL SERVICE RATE: 
A.  Availability: The large general service rate shall be available to all customers with demands in excess of 400 kW, but less than 2,000 kW. 
B.  Billing Demand: The billing demand shall be the maximum measured 30-minute integrated demand in the month. 
C.  Measurement Of Demand And Energy: When there are two (2) or more demand and energy metering installations on the customer's premises, the metered quantities shall be combined for billing purposes. Demands should be added in a manner to determine the combined 30-minute coincident peak. However, maximum kW demands and kWh supplied at two (2) or more premises will not be combined for billing purposes. 
D.  Secondary Metering Adjustment: The city shall have the option of metering at the primary or secondary side of the transformers. When the measurement of demand and energy is at 7,200-volts or higher, no adjustment shall be necessary since the rate schedule is intended for primary service. When the measurement of demand and energy is below 7,200-volts, the metered quantities shall be increased by two percent (2%). 
E.  Power Factor Adjustment: For power factor less than eighty-five (85) lagging, the monthly maximum measured demand used to calculate the billing demand will be adjusted for monthly average lagging power factor in accordance with the following formula: 
Adjusted Demand = Measured Demand x 85/Average Lagging Power Factor in %. 
F.  Service Facilities: A normal installation shall consist of a single-phase or 3-phase service drop and metering installation. Service voltage shall be 120/240 single-phase, 120/208 three-phase, 480/277 three phase or 12,470/7200 wye three phase. The customer pays for all transformation unless the service drop is at 12470/7200 volts in which case no transformation is needed. All primary metering equipment will be furnished and maintained by the city. Where an additional point of delivery is required other than for the convenience of the customer, the facilities incident thereto shall be furnished by the city as part of a normal installation. Each normal installation shall include facilities for one standard transformation. All transformers up to 2500 KVA shall be furnished by the city and paid for by the customer. Other than the above, the type of facilities comprising a normal installation, including meters, shall be determined by the city's customary policies and practices. The customer pays for all labor, equipment and material required to install service to the facility. Any new customers as of November 1, 2013, if the transformer is downstream of a primary metering installation, shall be responsible for all maintenance and replacement costs of such transformer. 
G.  General: The customer's wiring shall be so arranged that all service hereunder may be supplied thorough a single metering installation. Service hereunder will be furnished only to a single occupancy customer and where service to a multi-occupancy premises is desired hereunder, each customer shall be treated as a separate customer and serviced through a separate metering installation. The combination of meter reading at several premises for billing purposes will not be permitted. Each meter installation shall be treated as a separate customer for billing purposes. This rate is subject to all general policies affecting the collection, administration and operation of the city's electric utility. 
H.  Governmental Outdoor Lighting: The demand charge for customers providing outdoor lighting intended for governmental recreational purposes, shall be suspended when said governmental outdoor recreation lighting use occurs after 6:00 p.m. Said use shall be subject to voluntary interruption of service at the request of the superintendent of electrical services based upon the need to avoid coincidental peak demand with the city's electric distribution system. If the customer refuses to voluntarily interrupt service, the demand charge shall be applied. Said notice of interruption shall be given to the user(s) at least two (2) hours in advance of the interruption. In order to qualify for said demand suspension, the customer metering and wiring configuration shall segregate the outdoor lighting use to provide for separate metering and billing, which metering and configuration shall be made at the customer's expense. 
(Ord. No. 2013-36, § 1(Exh. A), 10-21-2013) 
9-2B-10: - LARGE INDUSTRIAL RATE: 
A.  Availability: The large general service rate shall be available to all customers with demands in excess of two thousand (2,000) kW. 
B.  Billing Demand: The billing demand shall be the maximum measured 30-minute integrated demand in the month.

Adjusted demand = Measured demand x 85/Average lagging power factor in %
