CHAPTER 1 - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
SECTION: 

10-1-1: - SHORT TITLE: 
This title, including the rules and regulations it adopts by reference, is entitled the BUILDING CODE. The requirements of this title apply to the administration and enforcement of this building code, other pertinent ordinances and laws applicable to any regulated building, structure, part or appurtenance thereof. (1975 Code App. A §§ 101, 109; amd. 2003 Code) 
10-1-2: - BUILDING AND ZONING DIVISION:[1] 
    The building and zoning division is created within the department of community development and the staff employee in charge thereof shall be known as the building and zoning commissioner. 
(Ord. No. 2010-34, § 2, 8-16-2010) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2010-34, § 2, adopted August 16, 2010, amended section 10-1-2 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, section 10-1-2 pertained to the building commissioner and zoning enforcement officer, and derived from the Code of 1975, App. A §§ 104 and 109, and amd. 2003 Code. 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
See also section 1-6E-1 of this Code. 

10-1-3: - BOARD OF APPEALS: 
The board of appeals shall consist of the aldermen of the city council sitting as a committee of the whole; provided, however, that the mayor shall exercise his power to vote on said board in the event of: a) a tie vote of the board; or b) one-half (1/2) of the aldermen then holding office vote in favor of a motion before the board. A simple majority of the city council shall constitute a quorum for any hearing of the board. (1975 Code App. A § 112) 
10-1-4: - COMPLIANCE AND INTERPRETATION OF REGULATIONS: 
A.  Maintenance: All buildings and structures, and parts and appurtenances thereof, both existing and hereafter erected or installed, shall be so maintained that the occupants and users thereof and others are reasonably safe from the hazards of fire, explosion, collapse, contagion and spread of infectious disease. If found not so maintained, the necessary corrective work, repair, replacement or removal may be ordered. 
B.  Minimum Requirements: The rules and regulations contained in this title set forth requirements which are considered reasonable and are held in every instance to be the minimum for the promotion of public health, safety and general welfare. (1975 Code App. A § 102) 
10-1-5: - BUILDING PERMITS: 
A.  Permits Required: 
1.  A permit shall be obtained, in advance, and all other requirements of the building code be complied with, whenever a building or structure, or parts or appurtenances thereof, including but not limited to, water supply, sewage disposal, plumbing installation and electrical installation, and any other improvements that are regulated by this title, including all codes adopted by reference under section 10-3-2 hereof, is erected, installed, altered, converted, remodeled, structurally repaired, moved or changed to real property located in the city. 
B.  Application For Permit: 
1.  A building permit application, signed by owner or authorized agent, shall be in writing on forms provided by building commissioner. 
2.  The application may be amended during course by permission of the building commissioner. 
3.  Any alterations and additions after completion will require another permit. 
C.  Contents Of Application: The following information shall accompany and be a part of the application: 
1.  Descriptive material, in drawn and written form, as to location and design of buildings, structures, water supply systems, sewage disposal systems, plumbing and electrical installations, as required by the building commissioner to assure compliance with the rules and regulations of this code. 
2.  Two (2) copies of a plat of a building plot, unless shown on the construction plans, showing existing and proposed buildings, structures and underground facilities. 
3.  For construction, alterations and other work: three (3) copies of construction plans (more if required by building commissioner), specifications and tests, to show compliance with regulations. Scale of plans not less than one-eighth inch to one foot ( 1/8 " = 1'). Plans may be waived for minor alterations not involving structural changes and for residential accessory buildings not over five hundred (500) square feet in area, if sufficiently described in application. 
D.  Fees: Payment of the required fee shall be made with the application as required in the schedule of fees set out in section 10-1-6 of this chapter. 
E.  Examination Of Application And Plans: Examination of the application and accompanying plans shall be made within thirty (30) days by or under direction of building commissioner. 
F.  Action On Permit: Action on permit after filing and examination of application shall be as follows: 
1.  Permit shall be denied if plans of proposed work do not conform to requirements of this building code, or other pertinent laws and ordinances. Denial with reasons shall be given in writing upon request. 
2.  If proposed work conforms to requirements of this building code and other pertinent laws and ordinances, a permit shall be issued in writing to proceed with work, returning one set of plans and specifications, endorsed by building commissioner, to be kept on job at all times. 
3.  Permit placard is to be furnished with permit or as the permit itself, which is to remain conspicuously posted on premises during course of work. 
4.  Permit lapses if a substantial start is not made in six (6) months, if substantial progress is not made in a one year period, and after two (2) years unless extended. 
5.  A certificate of occupancy which must be secured before a building is permanently occupied, is to be issued by the building commissioner when an inspection following the completion of the work shows that all construction is in compliance with this building code and permit. 
6.  Temporary occupancy permit may be issued for a building or portion thereof if it is found that the condition of the building and the lighting, heating, water supply, sewage disposal and other sanitary facilities available to the occupant provide a reasonable degree of safety. Evidence or assurance of reasonably prompt completion shall be furnished. Permit may be revoked if work to complete is not diligently pursued. (1975 Code App. A §§ 102, 109; amd. 2003 Code; Ord. No. 2009-33, § 1, 10-26-2009) 
10-1-6: - BUILDING PERMIT FEES: 
The fees with respect to applications for the issuance of permits for, and the review, inspection and supervision of, the construction, alteration and repair of buildings and other structures, in enforcing the building code are as follows: 
A.  Plan Review Fees: There shall be a minimum plan review fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for all applications for the issuance of a permit except permits issued under subsection G of this section. 
B.  New Residential Construction: New residential construction, attached and detached garages, basements, and crawl spaces fee per square foot is: 
$0.26 for building department 
$0.02 for fire department 
C.  New Commercial And Industrial Structures: For new commercial and other new nonresidential structures the permit fee per square foot is: 
$0.38 per square foot of floor area 
New industrial fee is: 
$0.38 per square foot for the first 10,000 square feet of area 
$0.18 per square foot thereafter 
D.  Residential Additions: Additions for residential building and accessory buildings over four hundred (400) square feet: 
$50.00 plus $0.28 per square foot plus a plan review fee of $50.00 
E.  Commercial And Industrial Additions: Additions for commercial and industrial buildings and accessory buildings over four hundred (400) square feet: 
$50.00 plus $0.38 per square foot plus a plan review fee of $50.00 
Additions less than four hundred (400) square feet shall be calculated as in subsection F of this section. 
F.  Remodeling: Remodeling permit fees for commercial, industrial, and residential buildings: 
$75.00 for the first $1,000.00 of the project costs 
$10.00 per $1,000.00 or fraction thereof for the first $100,000.00 project cost 
$8.00 per $1,000.00 or fraction thereof for the second $100,000.00 project cost 
$6.00 per $1,000.00 or fraction thereof for any amount over $200,000.00 cost 
G.  Addition And Remodeling: If a residential project is a combination of an addition and remodeling, the permit fee will be calculated at twenty eight cents ($0.28) per square foot for the new square footage. In addition thereto, the following amounts shall be added to the permit fee if work is included in any of the following portions of the residence: 
Bathroom $100.00 Kitchen  150.00 Any area not a bathroom or kitchen   50.00  
Example: The addition of 750 square feet of new floor space (750 square feet × $0.28 = $210.00) plus the remodeling in 1 bath, a kitchen and 2 bedrooms = $100.00 + $150.00 + $100.00 = $350.00 
New $210.00 Remodel  350.00 Occupancy permit   50.00 Total $610.00  
H.  Other Projects: The following project types shall be assessed the following fees: 
1. Deck, gazebo, pergola $150.00 2. Patio  100.00 3. Pool  150.00 4. Roofing and siding   75.00 5. Driveways, walks and parking lots  100.00 6. Shed   75.00 7. Irrigation  100.00 per lot 8. Demolition  300.00 9. Sandwich board signs   50.00 10. Sidewalk cafe   50.00 11. Signs $1.50 per square foot   60.00 minimum fee 12. Fences   75.00 13. Furnace, AC, water heater replacement   50.00 14. Window and exterior door replacements, per project   75.00  
I.  Occupancy Permits: Occupancy permits for permits issued under subsections B, C, D, and E of this section shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). 
J.  Change Of Occupancy/Tenant Finish Permits: Fees are based upon project costs. See subsection F of this section; minimum fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
K.  Units Of Local Government, Religious Corporation, Public And Private Schools, Or General Not For Profit Corporations: No building permit fees shall be assessed to units of local government, religious corporations, public or private schools for Illinois general not for profit corporations maintaining a viable internal revenue code section 501C(3) certification. 
L.  Reinspection Fee: 
Residential $75.00; 
Commercial $100.00 for first occurrence; 
Each consecutive occurrence increase by $25.00 per occurrence. 
M.  Sewer, Water, And Electrical: Sewer, water, and electrical connection charges are in addition to any of the fees stated in this section. 
N.  Consultants: The city reserves the right to retain the services of independent consultants to provide plan reviews, evaluations, and/or inspections when it is deemed necessary. All costs and fees related to the performance of special professional inspections or professional plan reviews or evaluations shall be borne by the building permit applicant at the time of the issuance of the building permit for plan review services or prior to the issuance of the certificate of occupancy for any inspections or evaluation type services, as the case may be, including an administrative service fee of ten percent (10%) of costs incurred by the city for such professional services or inspections. (Ord. 2007-30, 7-16-2007; Ord. No. 2009-34, § 1, 10-26-2009; Ord. No. 2013-14, § 1(Exh. A), 4-15-2013) 
10-1-7: - INSPECTIONS: 
A.  The following inspections by the building commissioner shall be made of all buildings, structures and parts and appurtenances thereof governed by the building code: 
1.  Building structures and parts or appurtenances thereof, including wells and sewage disposal systems, shall be located on building site before construction is started. 
2.  Footing form shall be inspected before footing is poured. 
3.  Forms shall be inspected before any slab is poured, including garage slab. 
4.  Foundation shall be inspected before installing any steel or wood beams or any floor joist and before backfilling outside of foundation, but after any required waterproofing. 
5.  When the building, structure or part or appurtenance thereof has been framed, roofed and rough wiring and plumbing installed, and before any lath or inside wall covering is installed and before the basement floor is poured, an inspection shall be made. 
6.  All sewage disposal systems, where installed, are to be inspected before backfilling. 
7.  A final inspection shall be made when the building, structure or part or appurtenance thereof shall have been completed in accordance with the building code. No such building, structure or part or appurtenance thereof shall be occupied or used until a certificate of occupancy has been issued by the building commissioner as provided for by the building code. 
8.  Where connection will not be made to city water mains, a copy of approved water analysis of the Illinois public health department or an approved testing laboratory must be furnished the building commissioner before a certificate of occupancy will be issued. 
B.  No further work shall be done at any of the above stages wherein inspections are required until after a certificate of said inspection shall have been issued by the building commissioner for each respective inspection. 
C.  The building commissioner shall make the aforesaid inspections within thirty six (36) hours after being notified by the owner or his authorized agent that the building, structure or part or appurtenance thereof is ready for the respective inspections herein provided for. (1975 Code App. A § 111) 
10-1-8: - AMENDMENTS: 
This title may be amended from time to time at any regular meeting of the city council, or at any special meeting of said governmental body, called for the purpose of considering an amendment to this title. (1975 Code App. A § 110) 
10-1-9: - PARTIAL INVALIDITY: 
Should any section, clause or provisions of this title be declared by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, such decision shall not affect the validity of the building code as a whole, or any part thereof, other than the part so declared to be invalid. 
Wherever in the building code it is provided that anything must be done to the approval of or subject to the direction of or as required, specified or allowed by or acceptable to or subject to the acceptance of the building commissioner or which he may require to be done, these provisions shall be construed to give such officer only the power to determine whether the rules and regulations established by the building code have been complied with and shall not be construed as giving such officer discretionary powers. (1975 Code App. A § 107) 
10-1-10: - VIOLATIONS; PENALTY: 
A.  Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this building code, including provisions adopted by reference, or who refuses to remedy a violation of any such provision or to remedy a hazard of fire, explosion, collapse, contagion or spread of infectious disease found to exist and duly ordered eliminated, shall be fined as provided in the general penalty in section 1-3-1 of this code for each offense, and each day upon which such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. (1975 Code App. A § 106; amd. 2003 Code) 
B.  A person licensed or registered by the state or a subdivision thereof to do work regulated by this title or to render professional architectural or engineering service in connection therewith, who violates the law or ordinance under which licensed or registered, or who violates this building code while carrying out such work or rendering service in connection therewith shall be reported by the building commissioner to licensing authority. 
C.  A reinspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be charged to the holder of a building permit, and payment thereof shall be made in full before the issuance of any occupancy permit, for each reinspection made by the building commissioner or his building inspectors, necessitated by either of the following conditions: 
1.  That the construction work to be inspected was incomplete at the time the building commissioner or building inspector arrived at the construction site for a scheduled inspection and the holder of the building permit failed to provide reasonable notice to cancel said scheduled inspection. 
2.  That the construction in progress, after inspection by the building commissioner or building inspector, is determined by said commissioner or inspector not to satisfy the minimum standards of the building, electric, fire prevention, subdivision control or zoning regulations of the city and, therefore, must be corrected, reinspected and approved before additional work on the structure can proceed or an occupancy permit can be issued. 
D.  Any person who commences work on any type of construction, alteration or remodeling subject to the provisions of this title, without first obtaining a building permit, shall be required to pay twice the calculated amount for the required building permit. This fee shall be exclusive of any other fines or penalties assessed for work not in compliance with the requirements of this title. (1975 Code App. A § 106) 
E.  It shall be unlawful for any firm, person, partnership or entity to work on a subject property once a stop work order has been issued for the property. Failure on the part of the firm, partnership, or entity to stop work, as ordered by the building commissioner, chief of the fire prevention bureau, fire chief or his/her designee, shall subject the owner of the property to a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). (Ord. 2005-53, 11-7-2005) 
CHAPTER 2 - GENERAL REGULATIONS 
SECTION: 

10-2-1: - OCCUPANCY PERMITS: 
All persons planning to occupy and improve property within the city shall first obtain an occupancy permit at the time a person applies for electrical service within the city. It is the sole intent of the city in requiring such permit to determine that all persons occupying improved property within the city are complying with the zoning ordinances of the city. (1975 Code § 8-1) 
10-2-2: - CONSTRUCTION RESTRICTIONS: 
A.  Use Of Streets: The use of streets for the storage of materials in the process of the construction or alteration of a building or structure may be granted by the superintendent of streets and walks where the same will not unduly interfere with traffic and will not reduce the usable width of the roadway to less than eighteen feet (18'). No portion of the street other than that directly abutting on the premises on which work is being done shall be used except with the consent of the owner or occupant of the premises abutting on such portion. (1975 Code § 8-2) 
B.  Construction Site Regulations: As defined: The term construction is broken down into categories: 
1.  General Construction Site: A site in which construction is being done by a contractor for a person, firm, corporation, etc., for profit; general construction sites can be either residential or commercial. 
2.  Residential Construction Site: A site in which the owner of residential property, is undertaking a project by oneself and not employing more than one trade for hire. 
3.  Construction Site: In itself, refers to both types mentioned above. 
4.  Residential Remodeling Sites: Sites where projects such as, but not limited to, decks, pools, sheds, fences, are undertaken. 
C.  Construction Hours: No construction projects, or residential remodeling projects, shall be carried on, nor shall construction personnel be present on the site that a permit has been issued before seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. or after eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. Monday through Friday and before eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. or after eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. Saturday, Sunday or city recognized holidays. 
D.  Construction Restrooms: All construction sites shall have present on site temporary/portable restroom units (porta-potties) from the commencement of construction until occupancy is granted or facilities inside the structure are usable. 
E.  Construction Debris Disposal: All construction sites shall have dumpsters installed on site for the disposal of all construction debris. In the event the builder has permits for homes abutting each other, both properties can share one dumpster. At no time shall a construction site have construction debris present not in a dumpster while construction personnel are not present or at the end of each business day. Dumpsters shall be removed and replaced once full. Dumpsters shall be on site until the final inspection is completed. 
F.  Waiver: Subsections D and E of this section may be waived if, in the opinion of the building commissioner, they are not applicable to the project. 
G.  Construction And Residential Remodeling Debris On Public Or Private Streets During Construction: All mud, stone, clay, gravel, concrete, or other foreign matter from the construction site shall be removed from any and all public or private streets, roads, alleys, or drives at least twice a day by means of mechanical or manual sweeping method. The repair of any damage that is found to be caused by the deposits listed above shall be the responsibility of the permit holder of the project. 
H.  Safety Precautions Required: It shall be the duty of the person doing any construction, altering or wrecking work in the city to do the same with proper care for the safety of persons and property. Warnings, barricades and lights shall be maintained whenever necessary for the protection of pedestrians or traffic, and temporary roofs over sidewalks shall be constructed whenever there is danger from falling articles or materials. 
I.  Construction Fence: At the time of the issuance of the building permit for general construction projects and before the construction activity commences on all commercial general construction sites and residential general construction sites, a minimum of a six foot (6') high chainlink type temporary fence shall be erected and shall remain on site until the final grade has been approved by the city of Geneva engineering department. Gates on said fence, providing vehicle access to the site, will be required. The location of such gate shall be approved by the fire chief or the building commissioner. 
J.  Owner To Post Construction Rules: At the time of building or demolition permit issuance for all general construction sites, a sign indicating the rules of construction shall be affixed to the fence next to the gate and visible from the street. Said sign shall remain on site and on the fence until final grade approval. 
K.  Subdivisions And PUDs: Subsections I and J of this section shall not be applicable to newly platted subdivisions and planned unit developments unless specifically required by the building commissioner as a condition of the issuance of the permit. 
L.  Demolition Standards: The following items shall accompany all applications for demolition permits: 
1.  Dated stamped IEPA ten (10) day notice requirement. 
2.  A plan showing the location of the structure to be demolished on the property. 
3.  A plan showing proposed site condition postdemolition. 
4.  A plan indicating the seed rate for the subject property post-demolition. 
5.  A plan showing the location of all utilities and a description of how said utilities would be terminated. 
6.  A plan showing the proposed location of the silt and security fence. 
7.  A "letter of intent to conform" signed by the owner, applicant, and contractor indicating their respective understanding of the regulations for demolition. 
M.  Owner To Post Contact Information Sign On General Construction Fence: Said sign shall contain the name(s) and twenty four (24) hour phone number(s) of the person or persons responsible for the site/project. The scheduled date of demolition shall be clearly posted on said sign. 
N.  Construction Site Vegetation: Vegetation on construction sites shall be kept to a maximum height of eight inches (8"). (Ord. 2007-30, 7-16-2007) 
10-2-3: - HAZARDOUS BUILDING OR CONSTRUCTION CONDITIONS: 
It shall be the duty of the building commissioner when he finds, or any citizen represents, that the doors, stairways, corridors, exits or fire escapes in any theater, church, school or public building, factory, workshop or other place of employment are insufficient for the escape of occupants in case of fire, panic or accident, or do not comply with the provisions of this title, or that the funnels, flues, fireboxes or heating apparatus in any building in the city are insecure or dangerous, or that any part of any building in the city is in an unsafe or dangerous condition, or in anywise in contravention of this title, to make an examination of such place or building, and if such representation is found to be true, the building commissioner shall, by direction of the city council, give notice in writing to the owner, occupant, lessee or person in possession, charge or control of such place or building to make such changes, alterations or repairs as public safety or the ordinances of the city may require and it shall be unlawful to continue the use of such building until the changes, alterations or repairs found necessary by the building commissioner to make such building or part thereof safe or to bring it into compliance with the provisions of the city ordinances, shall have been made. If the owner, occupant, lessee or person in possession, charge or control of such place or building, when so notified, shall refuse, fail or neglect to comply with and conform to the requirements of such notice, upon the expiration of the time therein mentioned, the city council may order the owner, occupant, lessee or person in possession, charge or control of said building or structure prosecuted as a violator of the provisions of this title, and may order and direct said building commissioner to alter, change, tear down, close or cause to be torn down such part of such building or structure as is maintained in violation of this title, and shall charge the expense to the owner, occupant, lessee or person in possession, which shall be recovered from the owner by appropriate legal proceedings. If the owner of such building or structure or the person in charge, possession or control thereof, cannot be found or his whereabouts cannot be ascertained, the building commissioner shall attach or cause to be attached to said building or structure a notice of the same import as that required to be sent to the owner, or person in charge, possession or control thereof, where the owner is known; and if such building or structure shall not have been made to conform to this ordinance and placed in a secure, safe and substantial condition, in accordance with the requirements of such notice, within thirty (30) days after such notice shall have been attached to such building or structure, the city council shall order and direct the building commissioner, to alter, change, tear down or cause to be torn down such building or structure, or such portion thereof as is constructed and maintained in violation of the provisions of this title in accordance with the notice, and nothing herein contained shall prevent the building commissioner from adopting such precautionary measures as may be necessary or advisable in case of imminent danger, in order to place such building or structure in a safe condition, the expense of which shall be charged to and recovered from the owner of such building or structure, or person in charge, possession or control thereof, in any appropriate legal proceedings therefor. (1975 Code App. A § 109) 
10-2-4: - TRAILERS, MOBILES HOMES AND MOTORIZED MOBILE HOMES USED AS RESIDENCES: 
It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to use or permit the use of any trailer, mobile home or motorized mobile home as a residence in any place in the city. (1975 Code § 19-12) 
10-2-5: - DANGEROUS BUILDINGS: 
A.  Definition: The term "dangerous building", as used in this section, shall mean and include any building, shed, fence, excavation or other manmade structure which: 
1.  Is dangerous to the public health because of its construction or condition, or which may cause or aid in the spread of disease or cause injury to the health of the occupants thereof or of neighboring structures; 
2.  Because of faulty construction, age, lack of proper repair or any other cause is especially liable to fire and constitutes or creates a fire hazard; 
3.  By reason of faulty construction, age, lack of proper repair or any other cause, is liable to cause injury or damage by collapsing or by a collapse or fall of any part of such structure; or 
4.  Because of its condition or because of lack of doors or windows is available to and frequented by malefactors or disorderly persons who are not lawful occupants of such structure. (1975 Code § 8-16) 
B.  Nuisance Declared: Any dangerous building in the city is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
1.  Maintain Or Permit Occupancy: It shall be unlawful to maintain or permit the existence of any dangerous building in the city, and it shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant or person in custody of any dangerous building to permit the same to remain in a dangerous condition, or to occupy such building or permit it to be occupied while it is or remains in a dangerous condition. (1975 Code § 8-17) 
2.  Permit To Stand: It shall be unlawful for the owner to permit any dangerous building or any building or structure to remain in a dangerous condition or to remain in the city after it has been damaged to the extent of fifty percent (50%) of its value. (1975 Code § 8-19) 
C.  Abatement: 
1.  Whenever the building commissioner and zoning enforcement officer, the fire chief, the health inspector or any other officer or employee of the city shall be of the opinion that any building or structure in the city is a dangerous building, he shall file a written statement to this effect with the city attorney. The city attorney shall thereupon cause written notice to be served upon the owner thereof, and upon the occupant thereof, if any, by registered mail or by personal service. Such notice shall state that the building has been declared to be in a dangerous condition, that such dangerous condition must be removed or remedied by repairing or altering the building or by demolishing it, and that the condition must be remedied at once. 
2.  If the person receiving such notice has not complied therewith within ten (10) days from the time when the notice is served upon such person by personal service or by registered mail, the fire chief may, upon orders of the mayor, proceed to remedy the condition or demolish the dangerous building. (1975 Code § 8-18; amd. 2003 Code) 
10-2-6: - MOVING BUILDINGS: 
A.  Permit Required: Any person, whether licensed or otherwise, moving any building or other structure of either wood, metal, stone or concrete, measuring over eight feet six inches (8'6") wide and twelve feet (12') high, measuring from the surface of the roadway, along any street or highway or across any public place within the city shall file a written notice with the building commissioner, not less than five (5) days prior to the moving time, the place from and to which the building or structure will be moved, the route proposed to be taken in such movement, and shall not in any manner damage any trees or shrubs planted in any street or highway, along such route, and shall deposit a sum sufficient to cover the cost of inspection and any damage that may result therefrom. The building commissioner shall have the authority to refuse the issuance of a permit or change the route if such moving will cause damage to any property. (1975 Code § 8-42) 
B.  Approval Of Permit; Fee: Upon approval by the city council of the intended route, a fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each day or fraction thereof that it is intended that the building shall occupy any such portion of any public place shall be paid to the building commissioner, and the permit issued. An additional payment of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each day or fraction thereof, over and above the time stated on the permit during which any building shall occupy such public place, shall be paid. (1975 Code § 8-43) 
C.  Bond: Every person applying for a permit under this section shall submit with his application a cash bond in the amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) with a lawful corporate surety to be approved by the city council, conditioned on his compliance with all of the provisions of this section, and agreeing to pay and hold the city harmless from any claim which may be made against it by reason of occupation of any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place by the building or structure being moved. (1975 Code § 8-44) 
D.  Moving Regulations: 
1.  Lights And Warnings: Whenever a street or alley is blocked by a house or structure which is being moved, warnings to that effect shall be placed by the police department so as to warn vehicles and persons from entering that portion of the street so blocked. The person moving any building through the streets shall keep warning signs and lanterns or lights at night on the building so as to guard against any person or vehicle colliding with it. (1975 Code § 8-45) 
2.  Cutting Wires: Whenever it shall be necessary to interfere with wires or cables of a public utility in moving a building, the terms of any special or franchise ordinance governing it shall apply and the bond therein specified shall be given. If no such terms apply, then the director of public works shall estimate the expense of fixing the wires and the bond to be given to cover the expense. (1975 Code § 8-46) 
10-2-7: - NONCONFORMING BUILDINGS OR STRUCTURES: 
A.  Definition: A nonconforming building or structure is an existing building or structure or part or appurtenance thereof not in conformance with the building code. 
B.  Repairs: Repair work requires a written application and permit. Work limited to necessary repairs only unless building or part is made to conform in whole or part with the requirements of this title. 
C.  Alterations: Altering or enlarging shall be done in a manner conforming with this title. (1975 Code App. A § 109) 
10-2-8: - SETTLEMENT OF VIOLATIONS: 
Any person accused of a violation of this chapter, may settle and compromise the claim of violation against him by paying to the city, within ten (10) days of the time such alleged violation or offense was committed, the sum of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each such violation or offense. Consecutive violations of this chapter shall be treated as separate offenses. Payment of such claim or claims shall be made at the police station of the city, or in the fine/claim deposit boxes located upon the streets of the city. The funds received from such compromised claims shall be promptly turned over to the city treasurer to be credited to the general corporate fund. In the event such claim or claims are not paid within ten (10) days of the time of the alleged offense, a notice to appear or a warrant (summons) may be issued for the arrest of the offender. (1975 Code § 8-5) 
CHAPTER 3 - BUILDING CODES 
SECTION: 

10-3-1: - RULES ADOPTED BY REFERENCE; INTERPRETATION: 
The books or pamphlets described and referred to in this title, and the regulations and standards contained therein or in the described portions thereof, modified in some cases as noted herein, are hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this building code. In the event of a conflict between this title or any part thereof, and such regulations and standards adopted by reference, the provisions of this title shall govern and prevail. (1975 Code App. A § 103) 
At least one copy of each code, regulation or standard adopted by reference herein shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk for public inspection. (2003 Code)

Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-33, § 6, adopted October 1, 2018, repealed § 10-3-2, which pertained to Building Codes Adopted. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
10-3-3: - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE: 
A.  Adoption: Adopted by reference and applicable to all buildings and structures and portions thereof are the standards set forth in the 2003 international property maintenance code published by the International Code Council, Inc., 5203 Leesburg Pike, Suite 708, Falls Church, VA 22041-3401. 
B.  Amendments: Notwithstanding the foregoing, the following sections of the 2003 international property maintenance code are hereby amended as follows: 
Section 103: Is deleted. 
Section 104: Is deleted. 
Section 106: Is deleted. 
Section 107: Is deleted. 
Section 111: Is deleted. 
Section 302.2: Grading And Drainage 
All properties in the city shall be graded in strict conformance with an approved site grading plan or a plat of survey illustrating the flow of storm water from the property onto abutting properties or accessing an engineered element of a storm water management system or part thereof. Further they must be in conformance to the city of Geneva storm water management ordinance. 
Section 302-2a: 
All foundation drainage discharge points shall discharge into a component of a city managed storm water management system. If a subsurface connection is available, that connection shall be made. If a subsurface connection is not available, surface discharge is permitted. In no case shall the discharge point be closer than fifteen (15') feet from a property line; further, it shall be prohibited from allowing soil saturation due in part or in full with the surface discharge. 
Section 302.3 Sidewalks And Driveways And Roadway: 
All sidewalks, driveways, walkways, stairs, parking spaces, private drives, alleys, lanes or any other item functioning in the same manner and purpose of the above, shall be kept in a good state of repair, and maintained free from any hazards, defects, holes, cracks or other obstructions. All stairs shall comply with all applicable sections of the international building code or the international residential code. 
Section 302.3A. Parking Lots: 
a. All off street parking lots/spaces shall be maintained in a condition free of any deterioration or defects such as but not limited to: cracks and/or holes. All off street parking lots/spaces shall be maintained free of snow, ice or debris. 
b. All off street parking lots/spaces shall be lined/striped to provide the required number of spaces designed for the use as approved. 
c. Parking lots/spaces that have been allowed to wear to a point that the striping is not discernable to the code compliance officer, the property owner shall cause the striping or re-striping to occur. 
d. All off street parking lots shall have the required number of accessible spaces as determined by the state of Illinois accessibility code, signed and labeled as required by the state of Illinois accessibility standards 
Section 302.4: Is deleted. 
Section 303.3: Is deleted. 
Section 304.3: Is deleted. 
(Ord. 2005-53, 11-7-2005) 
Section 302.3.B Temporary Storage/Disposal Unit: 
Temporary Storage/Disposal Unit is hereby defined as: A unit or container that is designed and intended for the storage or disposal of household goods or materials. When these units are located in any yard on any residential property located in the city there is a maximum time period not to exceed thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. 2008-14, 2-19-2008) 
Section 304.7 Roofs And Roof Drainage. 
All roofs or portions of roofs and its flashings shall be maintained in a sound, condition, weather-tight and free of defects and in a condition to prevent the entrance of rain or other exterior elements into the interior of the structure. Roof drainage shall be designed and maintained in a manner so as it will not be diverted, discharged, drained or otherwise create a public nuisance. The discharge point of any roof drainage system, gutter system, or downspout, sump pump discharge, or foundation drain system components shall be a minimum of fifteen (15) feet from any property line. Roof drains and gutters shall not discharge onto any sidewalk, roadway or alley. 
Section 304.7.1 Storm Sewer System. 
Drainage of roofs, paved areas, and subsoil perimeter foundation drain tile (sump pump) systems shall be discharged into the city storm sewer system. In the event connection to the city of Geneva storm sewer system is not possible discharge of the storm water must occur on the owner's private property and in no case closer than fifteen feet (15') to any property line. The subject property shall be graded to adequately drain the storm water to a designed overland storm water management drain system adequately designed, constructed and maintained to prevent the standing of storm water longer than is designed. 
Section 304.14 Windows, Window Frames, Doors And Door Frames 
Glazing And Screens: All windows, window frames, doors and door frames shall be kept in sound condition free from rot, rust, peeling paint and be weather tight to prevent the infiltration of the elements into the structure. All habitable buildings or structures shall have operable windows (other than approved fixed windows) that open and close easily and are capable of being held in a position either closed or open by use of approved window hardware. All operable windows and all doors opening to the exterior of the structure, building, or home shall have affixed insect screens from April 1 to November 1 of each year a minimum of 16 mesh per inch. All exterior-swinging doors shall have a self-closing device installed and maintained in good working order. All basement type emergency escape and egress windows shall be maintained free from obstruction and in sound working order and not be locked in any fashion. Any and all glazing shall be free of holes or cracks. 
Section 304.17 Guards For Basement Windows. 
Guards for basement windows that require the use of a key, tool or any special knowledge to get out of the basement shall be prohibited. 
Section 403.5 Clothes Dryer Exhaust. 
Clothes dryer venting systems shall be independent of all other systems and shall be vented in accordance with the dryer's manufacturer's instructions. The use of plastic/vinyl spiral wire-type venting is prohibited. 
Section 404.2: Minimum Room Widths. 
A habitable room, other than a kitchen, shall not be less than seven (7') feet in any plan dimension. Kitchens shall have a clear passageway of not less than three (3') feet between the counter fronts and appliances or counter fronts and walls. 
Section 404.3 Minimum Ceiling Heights. 
Habitable spaces shall have a clear ceiling height of not less than 7 feet 0 inches, including hallways, corridors, laundry areas, bathrooms, toilet rooms and kitchens. 
Exceptions 
1. Beams or girders spaced not less than 4 feet on center and projecting not more than 6 inches below the required ceiling height, provided that the minimum clear height is not less than 6 feet 8 inches. 
2. Dropped or furred ceilings over not more than one-half of the minimum floor area required by this code, provided that no part of such dropped or furred ceiling is less than 7 feet in height. 
Section 404.4.1 Area For Sleeping Purposes. 
Every room occupied for sleeping purposes by one occupant shall contain at least 100 square feet of floor area and every room occupied for sleeping purposes by more than one person shall contain at least 70 square feet of floor area for each occupant thereof. Up to a maximum of 3 persons 
Table 404.5 Minimum Area Requirements

Section 404.7 
A. Food Preparation 
All spaces to be occupied for food preparation purposes shall contain suitable space and equipment to store, prepare, and serve foods in a sanitary manner. There shall be adequate facilities and services for the sanitary disposal of food wastes and refuse, including facilities for temporary storage. 
B. Dwelling Unit Defined 
A dwelling unit shall be defined as a space in a building, structure or home that has electric, gas, water, and sewer utilities to the space. A dwelling unit will also be defined as a space that has facilities for cooking, eating, sleeping and bathing. 
Section 602.2 Heating Facilities. 
Heating facilities shall be provided in buildings, structures and homes as required in this section. 
Residential Buildings 
Every dwelling, whether owner-occupied, rented, leased, or let, shall be provided with heating facilities capable of providing and maintaining a minimum room temperature of 65 degrees Fahrenheit in all habitable rooms including, bathrooms and toilet rooms from the dates of October 1 through May 31 of each year during the hours of 6:30 A.M. and 10:30 P.M. each day and not less than 60 degrees Fahrenheit from 10:30 P.M. and 6:30 A.M. each night. Exceptions to this requirement shall be when the exterior temperature is below the designated temperature found in the building code adopted by the city and the equipment installed is operating at full capacity and not restricted by any mechanical or manual means. The measurement of this requirement shall be taken at a point three (3') feet from the nearest exterior wall at a level of three (3') feet above the floor. Furnaces for single family dwellings shall not be located in any garage. 
Non-Residential Buildings 
Every enclosed, occupied workspace shall be supplied with sufficient heat during the period from October 1 through May 31 of each year to maintain a minimum temperature of 65 degrees Fahrenheit during all working hours. The exception to this requirement is when the function, operation, process being conducted or the storage of product, supplies, equipment, material, etc. is required to maintain a temperature lower than that required by this section, the measurement of this requirement shall be taken at a point three (3') feet from the nearest exterior wall and at a level three (3') feet above the floor. 
Section 602.3: Is deleted. 
Section 604.2.1 Defective Electrical Service 
Defective Electrical Service. Where it is found that the electrical system and/or service in a structure, building or home is a hazard to the occupants by reason of inadequate service size, improper over-current protection, insufficient outlets, improper wiring or installation of service equipment, deterioration or damage, or for similar reasons, the code official shall require the defects repaired or corrected to eliminate the hazard. Failure to correct or eliminate the hazard, the code official has the authority to declare the service disconnected until such time as repairs or corrections are made and approved by the code official. 
Section 701: Fire And Life Safety Requirements 
General. All buildings, structures, or homes shall be provided the minimum standards for fire safety. This section shall establish the minimum standards necessary. This section will also establish the minimum fire safety equipment standards every owner of every building, structure, or home shall provide and maintain for its occupants the minimum fire safety equipment requirements as establish in this section. 
Exits Or Means Of Egress 
All buildings structures or homes shall have adequate unobstructed means of egress from the area being occupied to the exterior or public way. The capacity of and the minimum number of these means of egress shall be established by the building code adopted by the city of Geneva. All exit signs that identify the exits shall be lighted and all means of egress shall be lighted by battery or other approved method if the building power is interrupted. Locking, chaining, barricading, or otherwise impeding a person's ability to safely exit a building, structure or home shall be prohibited and punishable as a felony. 
All fire protection systems shall be maintained as installed and designed and in good working condition. Any and all valves associated with the proper operation of these systems shall be left in the open position unless authorized testing or maintenance of the system is underway. 
Any smoke or heat detectors installed in the building, structure or home shall be maintained as required by the building code and applicable by state statute. 
Section 703: Is deleted. 
Section 704: Is deleted. 
(Ord. 2005-53, 11-7-2005)

10-3A-1: - BUILDING CODE; ADOPTED: 
The provisions of the "2009 edition of the International Building Code," compiled by the International Code Council, Inc., 4051 West Flossmor Road, Country Club Hills, Illinois, 604785795, (hereinafter referred to as the IBC) of which not less than three (3) copies of which have been and now are filed in the office of the city clerk, are hereby adopted together with the special regulations listed below modifying said "IBC" "International Building Code, 2009" as the regulations governing the construction of buildings except single-family residences, in the City of Geneva, Kane County, Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 2011-32, 6-20-2011) 
10-3A-2: - SPECIFIC AMENDMENTS TO THE CODE: 
The International Building Code, 2009, as herein above adopted by reference, is specifically amended by the following: 
In IBC Section 101.1 insert "the City of Geneva." 
Revise Section 101.4.1 to read: Gas. The provisions of the National Fuel Gas Code/NFPA 54 (the most current edition) shall apply to the installation of gas piping from the point of delivery, gas appliances and related accessories as covered in this code. These requirements apply to gas piping systems extending from the point of delivery to the inlet connections of appliances and the installation and operation of residential and commercial gas appliances and related accessories. 
Revise Section 101.4.2 to read: Mechanical. The provisions of the 2006 edition of The International Mechanical code shall apply to the installation, alterations, repairs and replacement of mechanical systems, including equipment, appliances, fixtures, fittings and/or appurtenances, including ventilating, heating, cooling, air conditioning and refrigeration systems, incinerators, and other energy-related systems. 
Revise Section 101.4.3 to read: Plumbing. The provisions of the State of Illinois Plumbing Code as currently enforce by the State of Illinois shall apply to the installation, alteration, repair and replacement of plumbing systems, 
Revise Section 101.4.4 to read: Property Maintenance. The provisions of the 2006 Edition of the International Property Maintenance code shall apply to existing structures and premises; equipment and facilities; light, ventilation, space heating, sanitation, life and fire safety hazards; responsibilities of owners, operators and occupants; and occupancy of existing premises and structures. 
Revise Section 101.4.6 to read: Energy. The provisions of the International Energy Conservation code as currently enforced by the state of Illinois shall apply to all maters governing the design and construction of buildings for energy efficiency. 
Add Section 101.4.7 Electrical. The provisions of the 2005 edition of The National Electric Code shall apply to the installation of electrical systems, including alterations, repairs, replacement, equipment, appliances, fixtures, fittings and appurtenances thereto. 
Delete Section 102.4 and insert therefore: 
102.4 Referenced Standards: Except where specifically amended in this document, the standards referenced in Chapter 35 of this IBC Code shall be considered part of the requirements of this Code to the prescribed extent of such reference. Where differences occur between the provisions of this Code and referenced standards, the provisions of the more restrictive codes or standards shall apply. 
Delete Section 103 
Revise Section 105.1 to read: Required. Any owner or authorized agent who intends to construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, demolish, or change the occupancy of a building or structure, change the tenancy of a building or structure, or to erect, install, enlarge, alter, repair, remove, convert or replace any electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system, the installation of which is regulated by this code, or to cause any such work to be done, shall first make application to the building official and obtain the required permit. 
In Section 105.2 Delete exceptions 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 9, 10 
Add Section 105.3.2.1 Payment of fees: In the event an application is abandoned, the applicant shall pay all reasonable fees related to the administrative processing and review of the application. 
Revise Section 105.7 to read: Placement of permit. The building permit or copy shall be kept on the site, visible from the street, until the completion of the project. 
Revise Section 107.2.5 to read: Site plan. The construction documents submitted with the application for permit shall be accompanied by a site plan showing to scale the size and location of new construction and existing structures on the site, distances form lot lines, the established street grades and the proposed finished grades and, as applicable, flood hazard areas, floodways, and design flood elevations; and it shall be drawn in accordance with an accurate boundary line survey. In the case of demolition, the site plan shall show construction to be demolished and the location and size of existing buildings to remain on the site or plot and how the site or plot will be restored after demolition. The building official is authorized to waive or modify the requirement for a site plan when the application for permit is for alteration or repair or when otherwise warranted. 
Add Section 107.6 Electronic media. When required by the building official, construction drawings and documents shall be provided in electronic format. 
Delete Section 109 Fees. 
Add Section 110.3.11 Required Inspections: 
In addition to the inspections listed in this Section, also refer to Title 10 Chapter 1 - 7 of the City Code for additional required inspections. 
Delete Section 113 and insert therefore: 
See Title 10 Chapter 1-3 of the City Code. 
At the end of Section 114.4 Violation Penalties, add: 
Also refer to Title 10 Chapter 1 Section 10 of the City Code. 
Delete Section 115.3 and insert therefore: 
115.3 Unlawful Continuance: Any person who shall continue any work in or about the structure after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe conditions, shall be liable to a fine of not less than $250.00 or more than $750.00. Each occurrence shall be considered a separate offense. 
In Section 202, add the following Definitions: 
Condominium: A condominium is a form of ownership. Buildings, or portions thereof, constructed under the Building Code shall be in keeping with its use and occupancy. Each condominium shall classify as a separate tenant. 
Crawl Space: An area of a building or structure, above or below grade less than five feet in height. Any areas exceeding five feet in height shall be included in all calculations as usable floor area of the building or structure. 
Gross Area: Where used in this Code, this shall be the combined area of all floors including floor areas created by mezzanines and basements. 
Townhouse/Rowhouse: A townhouse or rowhouse or structure by any name performing the same function is a single family dwelling unit attached to another dwelling unit only on the horizontal plane. Such buildings shall be constructed as single family housing with a two-hour fire-resistance rated wall between living units. The number of dwellings attached in this manner shall not exceed six single family units." 
Revise Section 303.1 to read: 303.1 Assembly Group A. Assembly Group A occupancy includes, among others, the use of a building or structure, or a portion thereof, for the gathering of persons for purposes such as civic, social or religious functions; recreation, food or drink consumption or awaiting transportation. 
  Exceptions: 
1  A building or tenant space used for assembly purposes with an occupant load of less than 20 persons shall be classified as a Group B occupancy. 
2  A room or space used for assembly purposes with an occupant load of less than 20 persons and accessory to another occupancy shall be classified as a Group B occupancy or as part of that occupancy. 
3  A room or space used for assembly purposes that is less than 300 square feet in area and accessory to another occupancy shall be classified as a Group B occupancy or as part of that occupancy. 
4  Assembly areas that are accessory to Group E occupancies are not considered separate occupancies except when applying the assembly occupancy requirements of Chapter 11. 
5  Accessory religious educational rooms and religious auditoriums with occupant loads of less than 50 are not considered separate occupancies. 
Delete the exceptions listed in Section 403.3. 
Revise Section 403.5.3 to read: Stairway door operation. Stairway doors other than the exit discharge doors shall be permitted to be locked from the stairway side. Stairway doors that are locked from the stairway side shall automatically unlock simultaneously without unlatching upon a signal from the fire command center or activation of the building automatic fire alarm system.

The floor of the parking area shall be separated from the remainder of the building or structure with a minimum four inch raised curb of concrete or similar noncombustible and nonabsorbent materials. For purposes of accessibility, ramping between levels is permitted.

The floor of the parking area shall be separated from the remainder of the building or structure with a minimum four inch raised curb of concrete or similar noncombustible and nonabsorbent materials. For purposes of accessibility, ramping between levels is permitted.

1.  Where required by Section 903.2 or 
2.  Where located beneath other use groups. For the purposes of this Section, a roof used for the parking or storage of motor vehicles shall not constitute a story. 
Revise Section 505.1 to read: General. A mezzanine or mezzanines in compliance with Section 505 and separated from the remainder of the building with one hour fire rated construction shall be considered a portion of the story in which it is contained. Such mezzanines shall not contribute to either the building area or number of stories as regulated by Section 503.1. The area of the mezzanine shall be included in determining the fire area defined in Section 902. The clear height above and below the mezzanine floor shall not be less than 7 feet.

All required water fire suppression and standpipe systems shall be provided with a four inch 'Storz' type fire department connection in accordance with the applicable standards. Exception: Where the local fire department approves the elimination for limited area sprinkler systems serving 20 or less heads.

[F]905.5 Hose Connection Valves. 
Where standpipe systems are required in this Code, each hose connection shall be provided with a two and one-half inch valve and two and one-half to one and one-half inch reducer. Threaded connections shall be National Standard Threads except where connecting to the supply piping. 
Add Section [F]907.1.3.1 Duct smoke detectors. Where required in this ordinance, duct smoke detectors shall provide fan shut down but shall not be interconnected with the building fire alarm system. Test switches for duct detectors shall be mounted in a readily accessible location. 
Revise Section [F]907.2 to read: Where required. An approved manual and automatic system shall be provided in Sections 907.2.1 through Section 907.2.23 and the following; 
a)  Residential Uses: In all buildings where used as hotels, motels, lodging houses, dormitories, apartments and similar occupancies. 
b)  All buildings having mixed uses including residential use. 
c)  Assembly and Educational Use Groups including those with fifty (50) or less occupants. 
d)  Other uses: All other buildings over one story in height and one story buildings over 1500 gross floor area shall be equipped with an approved fire alarm system. 
e)  All buildings or occupancies with automatic fire suppression systems. 
Exception: Where automatic sprinkler protection is provided, automatic heat detection required by this section shall not be required.

In Section [F]907.9.1 Delete Exceptions. 
Revise Section [F]907.6.5 to read: Monitoring. All fire alarm systems shall transmit alarm, trouble and supervisory signals to an approved location from which the fire department will be immediately notified. All circuits which carry alarm signals shall be constantly supervised in a method approved by the fire official. Approved methods of monitoring shall include direct phone line (reversed polarity) connections and AES/Keltron radio monitoring in which the signal are transmitted directly from the protected premises to the approved monitoring agency without the use unsupervised telephone or internet connections. 
Exception: In uses groups B, F, M, S, R, S and U, where not required by this Code to be sprinklered with an NFPA Standard 13 system, the fire official may allow the use of digital communication monitoring. 
Add Section [F]907.6.3.1.1 Zone maps. Where non-addressable fire alarm control panels are installed or maintained, a diagram showing detection device locations shall be placed in a location specified by the fire official. 
Add Section 909.1.1 Where required. In addition to those specific locations noted elsewhere in this code, smoke control systems shall be provided: 
1  In all sprinklered buildings with a gross (combined floor area of all floors) floor area exceeding 40,000 square feet and including all unlimited area buildings. 
2  In all buildings over three (3) stories or 35 feet in height. 
3  In covered mall buildings including individual tenant spaces and anchor stores. 
Add Section 909.2.1 Mechanical smoke venting: Mechanical smoke venting may be calculated in accordance with Sections 922.2 through 922.2.2.1 or shall provide a minimum of two (2) air changes per hour. 
In Section 1006.1 Delete Exception 1. 
In Section 1006.3 Add: 6. All restrooms, toilet rooms, water closets or any other room performing the same function. 
Add Section 1007.1.1 Conflicts with other requirements. Where the requirements of the Illinois Handicapped Accessibility Code conflicts with the requirements of this section, the stricter of the two shall apply. 
Revise Section 1008.1.4.5 to read: Security Grills. Horizontal sliding or vertical security grilles which are part of a required means of egress shall be openable from the inside without the use of a key or special knowledge or effort. The grilles shall remain in the full open position during the period of occupancy by the general public. Grilles shall not be brought to the closed position when there are more than ten (20) persons occupying a space served by a single exit or fifty (50) persons occupying spaces served by more than one exit. Where two or more exists are required, not more than one-half of the exits shall be equipped with horizontal sliding or vertical security grilles. 
In Section 1008.1.9.3 Delete options 2, 2.1, 2.2 and 2.3 
In Section 1008.1.9.10 Delete Exception 3 
Add Section 1009.9.1 Exception: A spiral stairway may be used as a secondary exit from the second floor only in existing buildings with a maximum occupant load of twenty (20) persons. 
In Table 1015.1 change MAXIMUM OCCUPANT LOAD for A, B, E, F, M, S, U to 20. 
Delete Section 1021.2, and insert therefor: 
1018.2 Buildings with One Exit: Buildings with one exit and stories above the first floor with one exit: In Use Groups B and S, only one exit shall be required at the floor of exit discharge and for one floor directly above or below the level of exit discharge when meeting all of the following conditions: 
1  The entire building is provided with a fire alarm system in accordance with this Code and the Fire Prevention Code. 
2  The gross floor area does not exceed 2000 square feet. 
3  The occupant load does not exceed twenty (20) persons. 
4  The exit is of one hour fire rated construction and discharges directly to the exterior of the building without passing through another tenant space, foyer or lobby. 
Delete Table 1021.2 
Add Section 1018.2.1 Dwelling Units. Only one exit shall be required from individual dwelling units when meeting all of the following conditions: 
1  The building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 906.2.1. 
2  The required means of egress is one hour fire rated construction which discharges directly to the exterior of the building. 
Revise Section 1022.9 to read: Smokeproof enclosures and pressurized stairways. In buildings required to comply with Sections 403, 405, buildings more than two stories in height above the level of exit discharge or buildings more than 30 feet (9144mm) below the level of exit discharge serving such floor levels shall be a pressurized stairway in accordance with Section 909.20. Pressurization shall activate automatically upon activation of the automatic fire alarm system. 
Revise Section 1028.5 to read: Interior balcony and gallery means of egress. For balconies or galleries having a seating capacity of over 20 located in Group A occupancies, at least two means of egress shall be provided, one from each side of every balcony or gallery, with at least one leading to directly to an exit. 
Delete Chapter 11 in its entirety and insert therefor: Accessibility. New and existing construction shall conform to the requirements set forth Illinois Handicapped Accessibility Code. 
Delete Section 1807.1.4. 
Delete Section 1809.12 
Add Section 2308.8.2.1.1 Protection. Floor and/or ceiling framing consisting of Engineered I-Joists shall have 5/8 Type X drywall placed at the underside of joists with paper-tape embedded in compound over joints and covered in additional compound to provide protection of concealed space in accordance with NFPA 13. 
Revise 2801.1 to read: Scope. Mechanical appliances, equipment and systems shall be constructed, installed and maintained in accordance with the International Mechanical Code and NFPA Standard 54. Masonry chimneys, fireplaces and barbeques shall comply with the International Mechanical Code and Chapter 21 of this code. 
Delete Chapter 29 in it's entirety and insert therefor: Chapter 29 Refer to the State of Illinois Plumbing Code, Current Edition." 
Revise Section 3002.4 to read: Elevator car to accommodate ambulance stretcher. In buildings three (3) stories in height or more, at least one (1) elevator shall be provided for Fire Department emergency access to all floors. Such elevator car shall be of such a size and arrangement to accommodate a 24-inch by 76-inch (610 mm by 1930 mm) ambulance stretcher in the horizontal, open position and shall be identified by the international symbol for emergency medical services (star of life). The symbol shall not be less than 3 inches (76 mm) high and shall be placed inside on both sides of the hoistway door frame. 
Revise Section 3401.3 to read: Compliance with other codes. Alterations, repairs, additions and changes of occupancy to existing structures shall comply with the requirements for new structures. 
Delete Section 3401.5 
Revise Section 3403.1 to read: Existing buildings or structures. It shall be unlawful to increase the height or area of an existing building or structure, unless the building or structure is of a type of construction permitted for new buildings or structures of the increased height and area as regulated by Section 503.0 and made to conform with the requirements of this Code in respect to means of egress, fire protection, light and ventilation. 
Revise Section 3408.1 to read: Conformance. No change shall be made in the use or occupancy of any building that would place the building in a different division of the same group of occupancies or in a different group of occupancies, unless the building is made to comply with the requirements of this code for such division or group of occupancies. For purposes of this section, the physical division of a single tenant, single use building into multi tenant building shall constitute a change in use. Subject to the approval of the building official the use or occupancy of existing buildings shall be permitted to be changed and the building allowed to be occupied for purposes in other use groups without conforming to all the requirements of this code for those groups, provided the new or proposed use is less hazardous, based on life and fire risk, than the existing use.

Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-33, § 1, adopted October 1, 2018, repealed the former Art. B, §§ 10-3B-1-10-3B-4, and enacted a new Art. B as set out herein. The former Art. B pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 

10-3B-1: - INTERNATIONAL RESIDENTIAL CODE FOR ONE-AND TWO-FAMILY DWELLINGS ADOPTED: 
That a certain document, copies of which are on file in the office of the Clerk of the City of Geneva located at City Hall, 22 S. First Street, Geneva, Illinois 60134, being marked and designated as the International Residential Code, 2015 Edition, including Appendix A - Sizing and Capacities of Gas Piping, Appendix B - Sizing of Venting Systems - Appliance, Appendix C - Exit terminals of Mechanical Venting Systems, Appendix D - Procedure for Safety Inspection - Existing Appliances, Appendix F - Radon Control Systems, Appendix J - Existing Buildings and Structures, Appendix K - Sound Transmissions, and Appendix M - Home Day Care R-3 Occupancy, as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the Residential Code of the City of Geneva, Illinois for regulating and governing the construction, alteration, movement, enlargement, replacement, repair, equipment, location, removal, and demolition of detached one- and two-family dwellings and multiple single family dwellings (townhouses) not more than six in number or three stories in height with separate means of egress as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of the International Residential Code, 2015 Edition on file in the office of the Clerk of the City of Geneva are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this ordinance, with the additions, insertions, deletions, and changes, prescribed in section 10-3B-2 of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2018-33, § 1, 10-1-2018) 
10-3B-2: - AMENDMENTS: 
The following sections of the International Residential Code, 2015 Edition are hereby amended as follows: 
Section R101.1 , is amended to replace "[NAME of JURISDICTION]" with "the City of Geneva." 
Section R105.2 Work exempt from permit , is amended to delete numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 10 under the heading "Building." 
Section R105.2.3 Public service agencies , is deleted in its entirety. 
Section R105.5 Expiration , is amended in its entirety as follows: 
Every permit, except demolition permits, shall become invalid unless the work authorized by such permit is commenced within 180 days after its issuance, or if the work authorized by such permit is suspended or abandoned for a period of 180 days after the time the work is commenced. Demolition must commence within 10 days and completed within 30 days of issuance a demolition permit, otherwise the demolition permit shall become invalid. For any permit, including demolition permits, the building official is authorized to grant, in writing, one or more extensions of time, for periods not more than 180 days each. The extension shall be requested in writing and justifiable cause demonstrated. 
Section R105.7 Placement of permit , is amended in its entirety as follows: 
The building permit shall be kept on the site of the work and be visible from the street until a certificate of occupancy is issued by the jurisdiction, or a final inspection is performed by the jurisdiction. 
Section R105 Permits , is amended in part to add the following section: 
Section R105.10 Permit issuance restrictions. Despite any provision of Title 10 (Building Regulations), Chapter 3 (Building Codes), Article B (Residential Code) to the contrary, the jurisdiction shall not issue a permit to any person who has been adjudicated by the jurisdiction's administrative hearing officer or a court of competent jurisdiction of violating one or more provisions of Title 10 (Building Regulations), Chapter 3 (Building Codes), or any prior version of the jurisdiction's Building Codes, two or more times in the five year period immediately preceding the date the permit application is submitted to the jurisdiction. 
Section R106.1.4 Information for construction in flood hazardous areas , is amended in its entirety as follows: 
For buildings and structures in flood hazard areas, as established by local floodway rate maps, construction documents shall include all documentation required by applicable flood plain ordinances. 
Section R106.3.1 Approval of construction documents , is amended in its entirety as follows: 
Where the building official issues a permit, the construction documents shall be approved in writing or by stamp. One set of construction documents so reviewed shall be retained by the building official in either paper or electronic form. The other set shall be returned to the applicant, shall be kept at the site of work, and shall be open for inspection by the building official or a duly authorized representative. 
Section R106.3 Examination of documents , is amended in part to add the following: 
Section R106.3.4 Pre-demolition conference: Before a demolition permit is issued, the person seeking the demolition permit for a building is required to attend a conference with the building official and other jurisdiction staff, as determined by the jurisdiction to discuss the jurisdiction's building demolition and reconstruction requirements. 
Section R108.2 Schedule of permit fees , is amended in its entirety as follows: 
A permit shall not be valid until the fees prescribed by Title 10 (Building Regulations), Chapter 3 (Administration and Enforcement), Section 10-3-6 (Building Permit Fees) of the jurisdiction's Code have been paid, nor shall an amendment to a permit be released until the additional fee, if any, has been paid, as prescribed by Title 10 (Building Regulations), Chapter 3 (Administration and Enforcement), Section 10-3-6 (Building Permit Fees) of the jurisdiction's Code. 
Section R108.3 Building permit valuations , is amended in its entirety as follows: 
Building permit valuation shall include total value of the work for which a permit is being issued, such as electrical, gas, mechanical, plumbing, equipment, and other permanent systems, including material and labor. If in the opinion of the building official the valuation provided in the permit application underestimates the total value of the work for which the permit is sought, the building official shall deny the permit, unless the applicant provides written estimates, quotes, and other evidence, which in the opinion of the building official, substantiates the applicant's permit valuation. 
Section R109.1.3 Flood plain inspection , is deleted in its entirety. 
Section R110.1 Use and occupancy , is amended to delete Exceptions 1 and 2. 
Section R110.3 Certificate issued , is amended to delete numbers 3, 5, 7, 8, and 9. 
Section R112 Board of Appeals , is amended to delete Sections R112.1 General, R112.2 Limitation on authority, R112.3 Qualifications, and R112.4 Administration and replaced with the following: 
R112.1 General . Appeals of orders, decisions, or determinations made by the building official relative to the application and interpretation of this code, are governed by Title 10 (Building Regulations), Chapter 1 (Administration and Enforcement), Section 10-1-3 (Board of Appeals) of the jurisdiction's Code. 
Section R202 DEFINITIONS, ACCESSORY STRUCTURES , is amended in its entirety as follows: 
ACCESSORY STRUCTURES. See the definition of "Accessory Structure" in Title 11 (Zoning), Chapter 2 (Definitions), Section 11-2-2 (Definitions of words and terms) of the jurisdiction's Code. 
Section R202 DEFINITIONS, HEIGHT, BUIDLING , is amended in its entirety as follows: 
HEIGHT, BUILDING. See the definition of "Building Height" in Title 11 (Zoning), Chapter 2 (Definitions), Section 11-2-2 (Definitions of words and terms) of the jurisdiction's Code. 
Section R202 DEFINITIONS, MANUFACTURED HOME , is amended to change the title from MANUFACTURED HOME to MANUFACTURED/MOBILE HOME. 
Section R202 DEFINITIONS, TOWNHOUSE , is amended in its entirety as follows: 
A single family dwelling unit constructed in a group of three or more attached units in which each unit extends from foundation to roof and with a yard or public way on not less than two sides. Townhouses not more than six in number or three stories in height are governed by this code. Townhouses more than six in number or three stories in height are governed by Title 10 (Building Regulations), Chapter 3 (Building Codes), Article A (Building Code) of the jurisdiction's Code. 
Table R301.2 (1) Climatic and Geographic Design Criteria , is amended in part. The table is amended in its entirety as follows. The notes and explanations that follow Table R301.2(1) are retained and not amended.
